PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE:
PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES BILL 1997 HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES) BILL 1996
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 February, on motion by Senator Herron:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to discuss in some detail the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill, the Health Legislation Amendment (Private Health Insurance Incentives) Bill, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance Incentives) Bill. It is very difficult to cover the broad scope of these bills within the time that will be allowed, but we will certainly make a reasonable attempt at it.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I proceed, I would like to foreshadow two second reading amendments. The first amendment is to the Health Legislation Amendment (Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill); and the second amendment is to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2). Those amendments have been circulated, or should be in the process of being circulated. In essence, they are the same as those already proposed in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriate time to move those, Senator Neal, is at the conclusion of your speech.

—I was not moving them, Mr Acting Deputy President; I was just foreshadowing them in case they had not previously been brought to the attention of the Senate. The first two bills have the major effect of providing an incentive for those in the community who are believed to be in a low income area who seek private insurance. These incentives cut in at $35,000 for singles and at $70,000 for couples with an additional allowance of $3,000 per child.

SPEECH.PARA: These incentives are not being opposed by the opposition. We can see that these will be extraordinarily popular and will go some way to making it a little easier for members of the community to afford private health insurance. The major difficulty that we see with this proposal and the levy on high income earners is that, firstly, it does not deal with the fundamental problem of the collapse of the private health insurance industry, and, secondly, it does nothing to offset the difficulties being experienced in the public health system. In some ways, because of the way the promises of this government are being resourced, it may well be that these proposals will make the situation worse for private hospitals. That is where our major concern is in this entire package.

During the election, the coalition promised that these incentives would not be funded from the public health system and that health grants to the states—other than the $50 million that came from the better practice program—would not be reduced. This has been shown in the first budget to be completely wrong. We are very fearful that there will be further cuts to health funding, particularly in the public health system, when the next budget comes out in only two months time.

The fact is that the coalition has cut, in an attempt to fund these unfunded incentives, $1.5 billion over three years. I am sure that everyone in the community would be well aware that taking out a large hunk of funding like that is not going to be insignificant, that the effect of taking out this sort of funding will mean that there will be a reduction in the level of services being provided to the community. The coalition has also cut $3 million over four years to hospital funding. This, again, is going to have a major effect on the types of services that are being provided.

One of the issues we must look at is that although the provision of these sorts of incentives to singles, couples and families who take out private health insurance will be welcomed, will they have the effect of increasing the number of people who take out private health insurance or will they have the effect of reducing the number of people who are leaving private health insurance? I think that issue is extremely debatable.

I suppose the incentive of $125 for singles is a reasonable amount of money. But when you look at it in relation to what it actually costs you to take out private health insurance, it is really rather paltry. Obviously our private health insurance varies in cost, but most schemes for singles will cost well in excess of $1,000 a year. So we are looking at singles being paid an incentive of about one‐tenth, or possibly less, of what they will pay out of their own pockets in order to get health insurance. I think a lot of people—and I think this is a fairly accurate observation—if they are earning less than $35,000, would think twice about spending another $900 to get private health insurance even with the incentive, particularly in light of statements that have been made in the media about the lack of value in private health insurance at the moment.

By the same token, families earning less than $70,000 are going to seriously consider, even with the additional allowance of $3,000 for each child, whether an incentive of up to $450 for couples with children makes taking out private health insurance worth while when private health insurance may well cost them between $1,300 and $1,800 per year. As maybe one of those rather silly people who do have private health insurance, I can assure the Senate that, when you see a lot of money go out of your wages every month, the small proportion that you may get refunded as a result of this bill really does not make a huge amount of difference.

The conclusion that can be drawn is that these incentives will not encourage a lot of people earning low incomes to take out private health insurance or to alter their original decision to leave private health insurance. It is not a bad thing that these incentives are being provided, but it is sad that they will not bring about the result hoped for: that they will not decline the state of the private health insurance industry.

Late last week the Productivity Commission brought down a paper in relation to the private health insurance industry. It is rather interesting reading but, as we are aware, it is only a discussion paper. Even though the department of health put a number of proposals in their submission to the Productivity Commission, as we were informed at an estimates hearing last week, these could not be seen as the views of the government or the minister and that any suggestion made by the health department was only of an exploratory nature. In fact, they did not see that they would be proceeding along those lines.

I can see and understand the caution being exercised by this government. One of the major views being put forward by the department of health is that there should be a change to something that has been generally considered quite sacred: the community rating system. It is a fairly complicated name but, really, it is a fairly simple issue. Under community rating, the cost of private health insurance is spread across the community generally so that those who are a higher risk—the elderly, the frail, pregnant women perhaps—do not have to pay greater premiums for their health insurance than those who are maybe a lesser risk—the young, the healthy and the athletic in our community.

Despite this government stating very clearly during the last election that they would not change that proposition, this issue now appears to be open for discussion as the department of health raised it with the Productivity Commission and it is being commented on by them. The department of health are proposing that we should look at changes to the way premiums are determined and possibly introduce a system of what they call life community rating. In my view, the term `life community rating' is really a misnomer because apparently including the words `community rating' somehow makes life community rating the same as, similar to or only a slight variation of community rating.

This is entirely untrue. There will be a fundamental change if life community rating is introduced in that the date that people take out life insurance will determine the premium they will pay. For example, if a 21-year-old joins, they will pay a lower premium if they continue with that life insurance company. If a person joins when they are 65, they will pay a much higher premium.

I suppose if we looked at this in absolute basic terms we could say the premium we would be paying would not be related to risk, but in fact it would be. There is very much a direct connection between the age at which someone takes out health insurance and how likely they are to get sick. In fact, the younger people are when they join, the lower the risk is of their becoming ill and costing their private health insurance company a lot of money. As time passes people get older and at the same time their risk of becoming ill and the risk of costing their insurer a large amount of money go up. I just wanted to take this opportunity to very much put forward my view that the introduction of a life community rating is very much contrary to the original community rating and to the original promises made by this government about retaining community rating.

Let us go back to the original problem which this legislation is attempting to deal with: the declining membership of private health insurance and where the industry is headed. Certainly that is a major difficulty. The sums have been done by those people who fiddle with numbers, and apparently every one per cent of people who drop their private health insurance cost the community, as I recall, $300 million. At the moment participation in private health insurance is declining quite rapidly, relatively unchecked. There is a major concern in the community, and with this legislation the government has attempted to deal with it.

We in fact attempted to deal with the problem in an entirely different way, and that was through legislation introduced late in our government which allowed for contracting between private health insurers and, firstly, hospitals that provide a service to patients and, secondly, doctors. Though there has been quite some success and quite a large number of contracts concluded between hospitals and private health insurers, the major area where there has been no success—largely as a result of coordination provided by the AMA—has been in the complete failure for any contracts to be reached between the doctors and the insurers.

When the Senate Community Affairs Committee took evidence, I think there was an indication that fewer than half a dozen doctors had entered into contracts. The difficulty this has created is that, even though there has been the commencement of containment of costs in relation to hospitals, there has been absolutely no containment in the cost that patients expend outside of what they receive from their insurer when they use a doctor to treat them. That means, of course, that every time a privately insured patient goes into hospital they still have no idea what they may have to pay when they come out, not to the hospital—as I have said, there are many contracts in place—but to the doctor.

A lot of people feel that, if you are paying maybe up to $1,800 a year for private health insurance, the whole point of that is to reduce your risk. If you become ill and go into hospital, you have covered yourself; you have transferred to the private health insurer your risk of becoming ill. But, as the scheme presently functions, even though you have paid up to $1,800 or so a year for your private health insurance, when you go in and are treated by a doctor, you may well find that you still have to pay a substantial amount of money out of your pocket to your doctor. I think that is why a lot of people in the community feel that private health insurance just is not worth it.

The government has sought to deal with what has occurred with the higher income earners in a slightly different fashion. For those higher income earners it is not only a carrot approach, with their incentives, but also a stick approach in that if a higher income earner does not take out private health insurance they will be charged an additional Medicare levy. As you can see, this can appear on the face of it to be quite attractive and a lot of people would say, `For those who have an ability to pay, why shouldn't it be that they pay a little more? Why shouldn't they be providing a little bit more towards our health system?'

That is where the rub is; isn't it? The way this legislation is framed, any additional Medicare levy that is paid does not necessarily go towards our health system. In fact all it does is go into consolidated revenue. While the high income earners are paying additional funds, the amount of money as a total going into our health system is declining, as I stated previously.

I think if you explained that to the community—that, yes, certain people are going to be paying more if they do not take out private health insurance, but in fact the health system will not be any better funded, the amount of money being provided to the states is declining and the amount of money going to the states for health funding is declining—they would be a little shocked and horrified to hear that that is the case. I think they would see there was not really a huge point in collecting this extra levy when it does not result, firstly, in an improvement to our health funding and, secondly, in an increase in the number of people taking out private health insurance.

In conclusion, this package of bills does not solve the problem. It does not increase the number of people taking out private health insurance, it does not improve the level of funding provided to our health system and it will not give the community a better health system overall. As such, we register our complete disappointment at the approach that this government has taken. In respect of the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill, I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:
(a) deplores the Federal Government cuts to public hospitals, pharmaceuticals and public dental services which have been made to fund these incentives in direct breach of an election promise;
(b) is dismayed by the inefficiency of the measures which will do little to ease the funding pressure on public hospitals; and
(c) is firmly of the opinion that the $1.7 billion would be better spent in providing extra Federal Government funding for public hospitals and direct subsidies for private hospital accommodation".
In respect of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2), I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate is of the opinion that all of the revenue raised by the measures in this bill should be used to increase Federal Government funding for public hospitals".

I would like to take the opportunity to read out our amendment to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2), just to make it clear that in essence it is an attempt to try to redress the problem that we see—that the extra money being collected will not be directed to the health system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years the Australian Democrats have made no secret of their dissatisfaction with tax breaks, or indeed subsidies of any sort for private health insurance. We went into the last federal election with an election health platform called `Five better ways to spend half a billion dollars on health'. That was developed in direct response to the coalition's election promise of tax rebates for private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: We simply suggested a better way of spending some $500 million—a far better way than subsidising the private health insurance industry. We suggested that the five underfunded priority areas where the money could be better spent were public hospitals, public dental services, indigenous health, rural health services and mental health services. What we have actually seen in the last budget are cuts to or, in the case of the dental service, a wipe‐out of these services. Presumably these cuts and the removal of the dental health scheme were in order to pay for the measure that we are here debating today.

The Democrats believe that that is an unacceptable trade‐off. We remain convinced that spending half a billion dollars on these critical areas would be a much better way to spend the money than putting it into private health incentives, such as this package does.

BREAK.PARA: No‐one denies that the decline in private health insurance membership is having an impact on the public sector, and, in particular, on our public hospitals. There is considerable dispute about the extent of that impact. The various excuses the states are giving for taking even more money out of the public hospital system are only worsening what we are seeing in that area. Some claims of the actual extent of the impact, I think, are exaggerated. Nevertheless, there certainly is an impact, and that is being felt by the states and, more especially, by the patients, who are now either waiting longer times for services in our public health system or are no longer able to access those services.

In some instances this is because of additional costs. Also, questions are beginning to be asked about a range of practices, including early discharge in some public hospitals. But that does not mean that throwing half a billion dollars a year at the private health insurance industry is going to fix those problems. Surely it is far better to fix them directly. In fact, in terms of addressing the problems facing Australia's public hospital system, these incentives are likely to be, as Jeff Kennett put it last week, `money down the drain'. It is rare that I agree with Mr Kennett, but on this one I think he has got it right. It is hard to find anyone outside the federal government and, of course, the private health insurance funds themselves and their spokespersons, who think that these incentives are sound from either an economic or a health perspective. I point you there to recent statements by the AMA.

This is a government that talks a lot about the budget bottom line and about being fiscally responsible. This is a government which abolished a dental health program for low income earners, and pulled hundreds of millions of dollars out of the public health system. Yet here it is, putting up an astronomically expensive package which, compared with the other options available to it, simply is not going to deliver a better health care system to Australians. For a start, these rebates are simply not going to be high enough to encourage a significant number of people to take up private health insurance. They may not even be high enough to encourage people to stay in private health insurance. A rebate of $450 a year for a family, for example, is not necessarily sufficient incentive for that family to take out insurance when they are faced with a premium of maybe $1,700 a year.

I cannot see the take‐up being anywhere near as high as many pundits are suggesting. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) is himself hoping for two per cent over the next three years; I think the Industry Commission is predicting around five per cent. Others are reading the minister's comments in the lower house as around six per cent. But even a five per cent take‐up is highly unlikely, as the Industry Commission pointed out in its draft report, `to cost effectively relieve pressure on the public system'. The reasons for this are, the commission said:
People who take up private insurance as a result of the incentives are more likely to be lesser users of the public system.
Privately insured people may still make use of the public system—
as they are deciding to do now—
as public patients . . .
In other words, they do not declare their insurance status, particularly if they go in in an emergency or for a major operation.
Rebates for ancillaries will have very little impact on the public system as most ancillaries are not available under Medicare.

In short, the overall budgetary impact of the rebate will inevitably be negative, because the savings to Medicare are going to fall a long way short of the cost of the rebate. The savings we are looking at may be as little as $20 million a year—the commission would not go as far as to put a figure on it. So, for $600 million, you save maybe $20 or $30 million. Very strange accounting indeed.

A further and significant problem with these incentives is that they do absolutely nothing to address those structural issues which are the cause of rising premiums and out‐of‐pocket expenses. We have already seen significant increases in premiums since these incentives were actually announced. You would have though that it would have been in the interests of the funds to try to hold off increases until at least this incentive measure was in place and until people had had an opportunity to feel its impact; but no, we have had substantial increases. Indeed, if you look at these increases, we are seeing a rise in private health insurance of roughly 3½ times CPI inflation since 1990.

What do these incentives do to halt that rise? The answer is: absolutely nothing. In fact, it is not unfair to assume that the likely result of pumping such a massive amount of money into private health insurance will be that the private sector will further increase premiums and that other costs will go up; the demand will increase for those at the demand end of the system. The obvious question is: why should Australian taxpayers subsidise this industry when they get no or very little control over fees, prices and costs within the industry in return for that investment?

I also have to question the notion that private health insurance is a necessary item. It is not. It is an optional extra which people choose to purchase over and above their Medicare contribution and entitlement. It is a product which, fairly obviously, many Australians are choosing not to buy. As such, it is difficult to see why, other than on ideological grounds, the majority of Australian taxpayers are now being asked—that is, the majority who have decided to opt out of this product or who decided not to buy it in the first place—to subsidise those people who have decided to buy it. Surely, if the government can find $600 million a year to spend on health, it is fairer all round if the money goes towards the system which the majority of Australians are using—the public system. I note here—I will explain further at the end—that I intend to move one small amendment to the Labor Party's two second reading attachments to make sure that we are not just talking about this money going to public hospitals, but also into the public health services. In particular, I wish to re‐target dental health and mental health services.

I will say again that the Democrats make no apologies for supporting public funding for health care. It is the fairest, most efficient and most effective way of delivering health services to all Australians—delivering services not on the ability to pay but on the basis of need. We have always said that we believe that ideally Medicare should simply cover everyone for their choice of doctor in a private or public hospital bed, with private insurance restricted to ancillaries or luxuries. We believe this is a sensible, fiscally responsible and healthy solution but, given that such an approach is unlikely to be accepted in the short to medium term, we can only argue for a much stronger commitment from government, particularly this government, towards the public system.

I now turn to look at the Medicare levy surcharge. For several years now the Democrats have called for higher income earners to pay a higher Medicare levy by making it more progressive. We have also, I might add, called for the levy to more accurately reflect the actual expenditure on health—in other words, decrease general taxation and lift the levy until you balance it out so people can actually see what it is we are putting into our health system. I understand the objection to this approach—that the whole idea of making it progressive, some have argued, turns it into a one or maybe two or three tiered system. I believe when you have a health system that is so clearly crying out for additional resources it is appropriate that progressively higher income earners are asked to pay a greater share of the burden.

The problem with the government's approach is threefold. Firstly, it effectively penalises people for not buying something. The obvious question is: why should any Australian be penalised by the government for refusing to purchase something that they do not want? If the government wants high income earners to pay more for their health care, then they should simply increase the Medicare levy. Do not link it to a failure to do anything else—in this case a failure to buy health insurance. Increase the levy and put it directly into the public system.

Secondly, the surcharge is basically an additional tax on the use of the public system by a group of people who already contribute to that system more than the average taxpayer. Just look at the levy. The higher income you earn the more you pay into a system and now those people are being penalised if they do not pay even more. Finally, it may not be a sufficiently high penalty, given the high price of premiums, to encourage high income earners, particularly those with an ideological commitment to Medicare, to take out private health insurance. I think we are only looking at about 17 or 18 per cent of people in those high income brackets who do not already have private health insurance. I would argue that many of them do not have it because they have a commitment to Medicare. These people may simply prefer to cop the additional levy rather than paying out even more to take out private health cover.

The Democrats will be proposing amendments to this legislation to break the link with private health insurance whilst still requiring higher income earners to make that higher contribution. Our proposal would raise an additional $350 million a year, some $300 million more than the government's proposal—money which could and should be directed into the public health system, into our hospitals, into our community health services and into mental health services in particular for young people.

Looking at the strain on our community health services, with the changes to hospital funding, particularly in my home state, the pressure of early discharge is placing a burden on our community health services that they simply cannot now meet. Looking at mental health services, I recently spent some time in Whyalla. For young people at least there are now mental health services, which is a start. But young people in that area who have already been assessed as in critical need of mental health services—many of these young people have attempted suicide; they have major behavioural problems—have to wait 14 months to access that mental health service. There are many places where the money that has been poured into private health insurance should be going.

In relation to the rebate, we will be moving an amendment which sets up a sunset clause on the legislation. Unless an increase of at least three per cent take‐up in private health insurance is achieved over the next three years—in other words, unless this actually does what the government says it is going to do—then this will lapse. If the government really believes a rebate will put a floor under the drop‐out rate and is prepared, as it seems to be, to back that assertion with $1.7 billion worth of taxpayers' money over the next three years, then surely it will be prepared to back its judgment by letting this legislation collapse if that does not happen.

Finally, on one of the other bills in this package, we will again be voting against the proposal to increase the medical expenses rebate threshold. As none of these so-called incentives are directed at those who self‐insure, it should be up to us to make the decision to self‐insure. We should not be forced into private health insurance. Therefore, it is surely more important than ever for this government to encourage people to be prepared to self‐insure; in other words, for people to make a conscious decision that even though they do not have private health insurance they will not burden the public system. They will take themselves off to the private system perhaps for day surgery.

To see this back in here is most disappointing at a time when the government is supposedly concerned about the pressure on the public system by people who are using it who should have private insurance—or maybe who do have it. Here in this very package is something that is working in the other direction. In this package is a measure that is saying, `No, we are not going to encourage you to look after yourself.'

I will just outline the amendments that we wish to move to Senator Neal's amendments. I will deal first with the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1996. We simply wish to add to part (c) after `public hospitals' the four words `and public health services'. Part (c) will now read:

(c) is firmly of the opinion that the $1.7 billion will be better spent in providing extra Federal Government funding for public hospitals and public health services and direct subsidies for private hospital accommodation.
I move:
Paragraph (c), after "public hospitals", add "and public health services".
The amendment I wish to move to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 is at the very end. It is the addition of the same four words so it will read:
"but the Senate is of the opinion that all of the revenue raised by the measures in this Bill should be used to increase Federal Government funding for public hospitals and public health services".
I move:
After "public hospitals", add "and public health services".

Today I have outlined the urgent need in a wide range of public health services. Those needs are not just underfunded by this government but, in the case of dental services, defunded by this government in order to pay for this package that is before us today. I think that is absolutely disgraceful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of sadness that I rise today to speak on these four Medicare and health related bills. It is with sadness because this is the first act of emasculation of the health care system as we know it in this country. The government is finally beginning to implement Son of Fightback. This is a great tragedy for those in this country who have health care needs.

SPEECH.PARA: The government made much during the election campaign about how wonderful this incentive package would be—people would be able to take out private health insurance—and how they were going to encourage the low income earners to take out private health insurance. That is one of the nastiest things that have been perpetrated on the lower income people in this country that I can think of, because what private health insurance buys you is bills.

Whom have we heard that from in recent times? None other than the Australian Medical Association. They even went as far last week as to urge people to drop their private health insurance. I will not suggest that they might have some personal reasons of their own for that; maybe it is because they do not want the private health insurance company insurers monitoring and lobbying against some of the charging tactics of some of the members of the AMA as well, because they are pretty rampant in disregarding the needs of people with some of their pricing policies too.

Let us look at these private health insurance incentives. The amounts of money that are being offered to people to take out private health insurance go nowhere towards the purchasing of private health insurance. I think it would cover about a quarter—maybe less—of the amount of money that people would have to pay to take out private health insurance. Whilst you are giving people incentives to take out private health insurance, to do so they are having to expend two or three times more than what they are going to get back.

I know the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the other place quoted Mr Kennett, the Victorian Premier, as saying late last week that this was a good idea. It is a pity that Mr Howard, in his usual form, was not living in the future—as usual, he was living in the past—because about Thursday of last week, Mr Kennett described the rebates as` money down the drain' and `good money after bad'. Even Mr Kennett is able to see through his Liberal colleagues' shenanigans. Even Mr Kennett is prepared to stand up and say, `This is not a good piece of legislation. This is about wasting taxpayers' money because the amount of money that it is going to cost the government to implement this scheme is more than what they will actually reduce their expenditure by.' It is actually going to cost money to save money. They will save less money than they are actually going to spend to save it.

That sounds to me like more black hole stuff. They are getting pretty good at this black hole. They have been in 12 months and they have managed to black hole something like $4½ billion or $5 billion. That is not bad going. That is a pretty good annual rate. By the end of three years, they will be up to $15 billion, if not more. Pretty shocking!

We have also seen a fast one pulled because this government when in opposition for 13 years had more health policies than some people have had hot dinners. It has even cost shadow ministers their positions and things like that. After they had been in for a while, they thought they knew so little about it that they had better have an inquiry, so they set up the Productivity Commission inquiry.

What about that one? We had the draft report. We were told that there was going to be a report out last Friday. There is every indication that the report has gone to the government. Is it not funny that the government, while we are busy discussing this legislation, while we are debating this critical and crucial legislation about the direction of health in this country, chooses to pass this legislation prior to the public release—

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got it.

—They have got it, but I am talking about the public release. They do not want us to know what is in their Productivity Commission report so we can debate this legislation informed. They are expecting us to make decisions in an uninformed manner, which raises two points.

SPEECH.PARA: In a legal situation, we are being asked to enter into an agreement when we are not fully informed of all of the facts. Out in the real world, if this were any other thing such as a contract, that would render that particular agreement null and void because it was made without cognisance and understanding of the full facts. But that does not bother this mob. One has to wonder why they have not released it. I will wager they have not released it because it shows that what they are trying to do is not going to address the needs of the community and certainly is not going to address the needs of the budget.

This is sloppy and slapdash work by this particular government. They obviously do not have any understanding—neither do they care; they are just ideologically driven. They will drive this through, come hell or high water. Too bad what we on this side of the parliament might say. They will just ride over us while taking no cognisance of our amendments. Too bad even what the inquiry they have set up might say.

I do not know; maybe the inquiry agrees with everything they are doing. But I would have thought, if that were the case, we would have seen its results being published very quickly. They would have been in here trumpeting those results. They would have had a list of speakers a mile long—all 30‐odd of them on the speakers list—to say, `Hey, isn't this great? Our actions are being vindicated; we're being proven right.'

There is one person from their side on the speakers list. They have not released the document publicly. What does that tell you? It tells me, or leads me to think, that it is a bit crook in Rookwood. It smells. I think they are not being totally honest with us. As I say, if everything in that commission report had vindicated their position, their stance, their legislation—or even half done so—what would they have been doing? Every one of them would have been in here with copies of the report; they would have been waving those copies around and literally belting us around the ears with them.

There is silence—silence. They have the bare minimum number of members in the chamber, and there is silence. They are not even raising an interjection, which is most unlike at least one or two of the members opposite.
Senator Ellison interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Ellison. At least I have drawn one mild protest—and for you, that is very mild. I rest my case on that particular issue because I know these gentlemen and ladies opposite. If they believed that their position had been vindicated by that report, politically it would be naive for them to sit there and say nothing about it. Politically, obviously it is a bit smelly and does not agree with them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the other things they have done in health. First of all, their coalition policy A Healthy Future contained the following promise:

The incentives will not be funded from the public hospital system or health grants to the States. Other than the $50 million which will be reallocated from the Better Practice Program, the incentive will be funded entirely from savings outside the Health and Human Services Portfolio.

Go and have a look at what has happened to health in the last 12 months: grants to the states have been slashed by $1.5 billion over three years, which is a cut of about $500 million in state health funding each year, representing approximately one‐third of health expenditure; they have made direct funding cuts to public hospitals of more than $300 million over four years; and there have been other massive cuts to health policy totalling more than $3 billion over four years. All this has been for a promise that incentives will not be funded out of the public hospitals system. What they have done? They have taken a machete—you cannot even say a razor blade, as that is too polite—to the health system and the health budget.

We see headlines in the local papers of all of the states about problems in the health system—and everybody keeps blaming the states. I will tell you who is to blame for the problems in the health system: this federal government, because they have taken a machete to everything. This Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has tried to defend a lot of these cuts to the public hospital funds on the basis that they are an attack on cost shifting. Why is it then that the state that suffers the biggest cut in funding is New South Wales? Also, why is it that, at estimates when we asked this question, the state that was into cost shifting in the biggest way was Victoria, although it did not suffer the biggest cuts? The government is looking after its mates as well.

This is an appalling situation—just appalling. It ignores a lot of things. It ignores the fact that costs were shifted the other way. It ignores the fact that hospitals have been forced by conservative state governments to accept further cutbacks and to shift costs—and they have done so to protect staff and keep beds open. Further cutting to funding will only make things worse.

I do not know of anybody in this country, particularly any doctor—with the exception of Dr Wooldridge—who thinks public hospitals get too much money. Nobody thinks that. The government also have made cuts to programs that were going to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals. Also, they have made cuts to programs that cover things like palliative care. But they do not seem to care about these things; they do not bother them—not at all. And what are we seeing?

TALK.START.PARA: —Cuts to pharmaceutical benefits.

—Cuts to pharmaceutical benefits, as my colleague says. What about the dental health program? Really and truly, this government puts itself up as a caring government. It wants people to feel comfortable. I do not know where people who are sick are going to feel comfortable. If they are to feel comfortable, it certainly will not be with any thanks to this government—and particularly if people do not have significant amounts of private health insurance and significant income levels.

SPEECH.PARA: The cuts to public hospitals alone equate to the closing of a thousand beds or turning away 66,000 people waiting for operations. This is a government, as I said, that just does not care about people. It is ideologically driven. It does not mind having two‐tier systems, and I will get on to that in a minute. The government is ideologically driven and it just wants to make cuts. As I say, this will do absolutely nothing at all to assist those people who are low income earners to have private health insurance.

We notice that the values of the rebates and benefits, since being announced by this government in the budget, are being eroded because all the health funds are putting up their premiums. The Prime Minister got very worried about that; he actually intervened. He now personally has to approve every health fund increase. Not too many have been refused, I might add.

The government even used the visit of the President of the United States to hide a couple of approvals for increases. Medibank Private and MBF managed to get some pretty large cuts through that week. Recently MBF has been closing branches in rural New South Wales. All I can say is that that is not much good for the provision of private health insurance out there. It is a problem. The government is not addressing it correctly.

I now turn to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Taxation Laws Amendment (Private Health Insurance Incentives) Bill. Again, here goes another broken promise. We do not know whether or not it was a core promise, but it was a broken promise on the part of the government. They promised that there would be no new taxes or no increase in taxes. Those of you who have been around for a while well recall the questioning of Senator Short when he was the minister and now Senator Kemp as the minister representing the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) to try to get them to define what is a tax, what is not a tax, what is a levy and why a levy is not a tax. I do not know why a levy is not a tax. All I know is that if there is a levy on something, you and I and everybody else still have to dig into the hip pocket to pay.

This is the second increase in the Medicare levy. We have no objections to one increase. We support the gun buyback program that this has been used for. It is a real worry. This proposal is a masquerade, a facade and a mirage. It is designed to impose a one per cent Medicare surcharge on individuals with taxable incomes greater than $50,000 or families with combined taxable incomes greater than $100,000 who do not have private patient hospital cover for themselves and all family members.

For the first time we have actually seen the government attacking Defence Force families, because they have refused to exempt Defence Force personnel. You could well have a situation where Defence Force families will be having to pay, when they should have been exempted because the personnel themselves have health cover in their job. If a single person has an income over $50,000, they are up for the levy. A couple with a combined taxable income of over $100,000 are up for it as well. But the government could not care less.

As I said, this is a mirage. We can look at the number of people who will be affected. Figures from the department show that about 110,000 singles and 100,000 couples and families will be affected. Less than one quarter of a million of the population of this country will be affected by this proposal. Most of this group have private health insurance. If they do not, they have made a deliberate choice not to have private health insurance and to privately cover their own costs. So it is a real mirage.

The other crazy thing is that it will be possible to get around this and save yourself some money by taking out the minimum amount of private health insurance that has some hospital cover in it. That will cost you less than the one per cent surcharge. It will do absolutely nothing to increase people's access to hospitals and things like that. This levy is just the thin edge of the wedge. By refusing to index the threshold, more and more people will go into this category and will be forced to pay the penalty levy.

I have a great deal of concern about this because I think this is the first step towards a two‐tiered health system—one for the rich and one for the poor. We have already seen that this government is not averse to two‐tiered systems. We have seen it this year with the introduction of being able to buy your way into university and being able to buy your way into higher education if you have the wherewithal and the means. Those who do not have the financial means will be penalised. We are also seeing it with nursing homes. They are heading towards creating a two‐tiered system.

As I said, these are four pieces of legislation that we should not be debating here today. We should be waiting until we see the results of the report that the government commissioned. Why will you not table this report so we can debate this issue in the full knowledge of what the advice to you people has been? You are too scared because your legislation is crook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak today in support of my colleagues. What seems to have escaped the notice of the coalition parties is that the public strongly supports Medicare. I supported it and I know the people of Tasmania did. They were under the impression that the Liberal Party did too. I was mistakenly under the impression that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) had come to the realisation that the public was strongly committed to Medicare and wanted to see a viable, strong public hospital system. This is obviously not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is an attempt to encourage people to retain or obtain private health insurance. As the shadow minister for health articulated in the other place on 24 February, we will not be blocking this legislation, because we do not want to stop contributors receiving the payments that were announced prior to the election. I have to say, however, that Australians have been sold out with this policy. They believed that they were going to get some support for their private health insurance as a result of the subsidy. Of course, we already know that this is not the case.

I would like to take the opportunity to point out that the legislation is fundamentally flawed in concept and will not achieve its objectives in halting the drift away from private health insurance. This change began with the advent of Medicare in 1984. Since then, more and more people have voted with their feet in favour of Medicare. The government likes to put this fact in a negative light. I, and the Labor Party, are proud to say that we are pleased that the people see Medicare in a positive way and that they support Medicare, understand what lies behind Medicare and want the public hospital system strengthened.

The government still does not understand, even though on the surface it has said it supports Medicare, that Medicare is supposed to offer universal health insurance. People are supposed to feel comfortable with universal health insurance. They are not supposed to feel guilty that they rely on the public system. That is what Medicare offers them and that is what the government offered before the election—that it would strongly support Medicare.

The coalition parties have clearly misunderstood the contract that was entered into with the Australian people when Medicare was introduced. Medicare was designed to be a universal system that everybody would share in, regardless of their wealth. It was deliberately designed for that purpose. It was deliberately designed to reduce the number of people with private health insurance, many of whom could not afford that private health insurance, many of whom had no cover because of the system that existed at that time.

BREAK.PARA: When we got into government in 1983, the health system, by everyone's assessment in this country, was a shambles. It was a shambles that, sadly, we look set to return to. Under the Fraser and Howard governments, conservatives lurched through five chaotic health systems in seven years with five changes as they progressively dismantled Whitlam's Medibank. It would seem that the Howard government would like to return to those times.

I am sure that lots of people who voted Liberal in the last election, maybe for the first time in their lives, were worried about what might happen to health care under a Liberal government. That commitment from John Howard might have pushed them to the limit and helped convince them that the Liberal Party could be taken on trust with the commitments they made to keep Medicare.

The most likely effect of this legislation, of course, is going to be the underpinning of rises in the premiums for private health insurance, and we have already seen significant evidence of this. Some funds have already raised their prices in anticipation of the introduction of subsidies. So individual consumers are not going to be better off and taxpayers will have to pay the additional costs.

These latest price rises are part of an established pattern which has seen private health insurance premiums rise by 3½ times the CPI rate of inflation since 1990. The effect of rising premiums has, not surprisingly, in turn, caused lower risk members to drop out of health funds at a greater rate than do the higher risk members, resulting in higher costs for insurance companies and further premium rises.

The Industry Commission pointed out just before Christmas that, even without increased premiums, the savings to Medicare will fall considerably short of the costs of the rebate. That is yet more evidence of the conceptual problems of this policy. These measures do absolutely nothing to address one of the major causes of the decline in private health insurance, which is the high out‐of‐pocket costs for medical treatment provided in hospitals to privately insured individuals. Due to the complexity of the existing private health arrangements and entitlements, many consumers are unsure about the benefits of their insurance.

None of these concerns are addressed in this legislation. Nor does the legislation do anything to reduce the cost of health care in the private sector, which in turn is driving the costs of private health insurance. It is also likely that any impact of the subsidy will be to assist people who are already privately insured rather than to encourage into private insurance those who now rely on Medicare. Of course, this has been the government's primary objective.

You have to think about that for a moment—the length of time that Australian families will think about this policy. A family is not going to pay $2,000 per annum to get a small subsidy of $450 per annum. They would rather know that, if they needed to go into a public hospital, they could do so.

For Liberal Party members to suggest that a single pensioner will magically find $800 to take out private health insurance simple to get the benefit of a $125 incentive is ridiculous. It is the same sort of logic that has the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, claiming that pensioners who are being forced to pay an extra 50c for every script will not suffer hardship. I have had a lot of people in my electorate office who have grave concerns about what seems to Dr Wooldridge a small amount of money. To those people, it is not a small amount of money.

Various estimates have been given of the likely increase in private health coverage as a result of the subsidies provided in this legislation. They range from the department's estimate of two per cent for $1.7 billion of taxpayers' money to the Industry Commission's estimate of five per cent. This is hardly a major achievement, particularly in view of the substantial cost of $1.7 billion. This is a huge sum and it is far greater than the amount the government estimates will be obtained through the Medicare surcharge.

This contrasts starkly with the government's slash and burn approach to health and community services generally, introduced in the last budget. There is no doubt that this money could have been used more effectively to directly assist people who need operations in public hospitals, if it had been directed straight to the public hospitals. We know that the $1.7 billion comes from this government's slashing of public hospital funding by $800 million, destroying the Commonwealth dental program—and again in my home state of Tasmania quite drastically—and increasing the cost of essential medicine. All of this is going to a few people to basically protect them against further increases in health insurance.

An additional outcome of this legislation will be cost shifting. In some cases hospitals have had to cost shift onto the Commonwealth just to keep their waiting lists under control, to try to make sure that people who are on those waiting lists are not in pain. Dr Wooldridge comes in and declares that cost shifting is taking place, instead of giving more money to the public hospitals to fix the problem. Dr Wooldridge must be the only doctor in Australia who thinks he has solved the problem by giving less money to the public hospitals.

What you are going to see with this legislation is the first of many steps from this government that will undermine Medicare. This is the first step that undermines the universality of Medicare. Once the principle is openly accepted that Medicare is only intended to serve a section of the community, not all Australians, it will be easy to define that group more and more narrowly so that in the end Medicare becomes a residual program for those who cannot afford private health coverage.

Most people will remember what it was like to line up at outpatient clinics before Medicare and before Medibank. What you had to do was prove that you were poor enough to get into the public system. We do not support any move back to that system. We do not think there should be the need to prove you are poor just to get the charity of the taxpayer. That is not what Medicare is about. Medicare, as we already have said, is about making sure that when it comes to health care we are treated as equals.

This government would see our private health system strengthened at the expense of the public system. It attacks our public system because of its cost. It is a fallacy to assume that private health care is cheaper than public health care. In fact, this coalition government has demonstrated its lack of commitment to elderly people in the Australian community who will now have to pay money. People on very low incomes will now have to pay money for a service that they have previously received free of charge. In many cases, it will not be a matter of how much people can afford to pay. They will not be able to get into programs run by the state governments, so they will have to wait, in some cases for years, before they get treatment.

Let us have a look at a couple of figures. In 1995, health services expenditure in Australia, with a predominantly public system, was 8.4 per cent of GDP. In Britain, with an even larger public system, it was 6.9 per cent. In the United States, with a predominantly private system, it was 14.5 per cent. If anything is going to send this country broke, it will be its private health insurance, and its private health insurance and health care costs are the single greatest cause of bankruptcy.

Before Medicare was introduced in 1984, we had almost two million Australians with no health care coverage at all and many others who were uninsured. It is incumbent on all in this chamber to make sure there is no move in this parliament that encourages a recurrence of that disgraceful situation. Were that to happen, the Australian community would not forgive nor forget. It would certainly not forget the government that went to them saying they supported Medicare but on the anniversary of their first year in office began to destroy Medicare.

The Australian community values Medicare highly; indeed, it is one of the most highly valued Commonwealth programs. Medicare has its problems but this legislation does not address them. We need to fight to maintain Medicare. We need to fight to ensure that the public hospital system is strong enough to cope with the demands upon it. Spending $1.7 billion on private health subsidies and ensuring that wealthy people have an incentive to leave the system signifies the last nail in the coffin of Medicare.

We certainly think that, in hindsight, the government should come clean and admit that it would have been better for us to have spent this money directly on helping people who were sick, in making sure many operations were performed, in making sure that operating theatres were operating longer and making sure that all Australians got a benefit from the expenditure of this $1.7 billion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me at the outset congratulate my colleague Senator Denman for such an excellent contribution to the debate on the health legislation that is now before the Senate. Senator Denman has quite correctly recognised that what we are witnessing here is once again the ideological obsession of the coalition parties with dismantling Medicare. We are witnessing the breaching of election promises to the people made in the federal election campaign last March.

SPEECH.PARA: When people look back at past governments, as no doubt they will look back at the 13 years of the Labor government and the short period of time that this current government will occupy, they will make assessments about what are the big achievements, the notable issues, that such governments directed their attention to. Amongst the many great achievements of Labor governments in the 1970s and, more recently, since 1983, was the provision of universal, affordable health care for all Australians—something which sets our country apart from just about every other country; that is, that ordinary Australians continue to have, and should have, access to an affordable health system.

What we are going to see when history comes to judge the performance of this government, as it has done in the past, is that they are about undermining the public health system. They are about trying to prop up and give advantage to the vested interests of the private health system, particularly the insurance companies.

The election promises made last March by the now government, the then opposition, went to two specific issues. In their policy document A Healthy Future they promised solemnly to maintain Medicare in its entirety. Moreover, they promised a package of $1.7 billion as additional expenditure in order to enable more Australians to take out private health insurance.

The Labor Party has never been opposed to the existence of a dual system of universal health cover through Medicare on the one hand and a complementary system of private health insurance on the other. What we are vehemently opposed to are measures which, on the one hand, seek to undermine, to slash funding to the public health care system in this country and, at the same time, provide dubious benefits in terms of health care to the private health system. That is what we are getting from this government. The policy document A Healthy Future, speaking about the incentives for taking out private health insurance, states:

The incentive will not be funded from the public hospital system or health grants to the States. Other than $50 million which will be reallocated from the Better Practice Program, the incentive will be funded entirely from savings outside the Health and Human Services portfolio.

Of course, that core promise was abandoned by this government very shortly after. Indeed, what a misnomer to call their policy A Healthy Future . No Australian today feels comfortable and relaxed about this government's approach to health policy. If ever there is a time when you would wish to feel comfortable and relaxed, it is at a time when you are ill and you are in hospital. This is a time when you do not want to have to worry too much, if at all, about how you are going to pay for these things.

In August last year, within five months of the election, this government brought down a budget which slashed some $1.5 billion in financial grants to the states over three years. That represented a reduction of around $500 million to the states with respect to health funding. Ultimately, it is the states that are responsible for the delivery of the public health system to Australians. That is a massive cut in the funding to the states for health care.

Further, we know that there have been other cuts. The dental health program has been abolished. There have been changes to benefits and assistance for people suffering from psychiatric illnesses as well as direct cuts to the public hospital systems in the states. In total, there will be a reduction in health care funding of around $3 billion or more over the next four years.

Yet this government promised that it would maintain Medicare and further fund its private health insurance initiatives out of other areas, other than cuts to overall health care funding. That is a shameful broken promise on one of the most important, if not the most important, areas of community concern for ordinary Australians. My colleague Senator Denman has quite adequately covered the dangers in this legislation and the overall approach adopted by this government with respect to health funding and the continuation of Medicare.

The people did vote for this government, for a change of government after 13 years of the Labor government, but they voted for this government in the belief that it would continue with Medicare. I do not think they are feeling terribly comfortable and relaxed about what is in store for them in the future.

I will now deal very quickly with some of the key features of this legislation that this government is putting before the parliament. The key feature of this whole package is the proposal to provide a rebate to individuals and families who take out private health insurance. A family that takes out health insurance, with both hospital cover and medical cover, may receive a rebate of up to $450 per annum; couples may receive a rebate of up to $250 per annum; and individuals may receive a rebate of up to $125 per annum.

It has been well documented and commented on, but I need to remind senators again, that this proposal just does not make financial sense in terms of changing the minds of people who at the moment do not believe it is in their financial or health care interests to take out private health insurance. As has been asked: why would a family or an individual elect to spend up to $2,000 per year on health care insurance in order to get back through the system a rebate of $450? If they are in the position, as many Australians and increasingly many more Australians are, of not having private health insurance, they are in that position because they frankly do not believe that private health insurance is good value, and I have to agree with them. It is not good financial sense for many people to make a decision to spend $2,000 if they are only going to get back $450 when at the present time they are not spending any money at all on private health insurance.

I was listening to a talkback radio program the other day on which this issue was being discussed. A woman rang in and said that her family had had private health insurance for some years. They had been paying somewhere between $1,500 and $2,000 per year—a fairly healthy family. When she finally came to make a claim for a refund on a dental procedure, something available under private health insurance coverage but not covered by the public health system, she got back in the vicinity of $75 for a procedure which cost $500. She asked the question, quite obviously, `What was the value? I have been paying all this money for all these years and when it finally came time to make a claim on a dental procedure, all I got back was $75 out of $500.' That is the situation that faces many Australians.

What we have seen, of course, is the position where health costs, particularly for surgery, whether it be medical or dental, are set at levels by the professions way in excess of what the funds will refund to individuals taking out insurance. Furthermore, the funds place limits upon the number of claims that may be made in areas such as physiotherapy, dental or other procedures which are generally covered under optional or extra health insurance coverage and which are clearly not Medicare related procedures. I know from my own experience—we all know from people telling us—that when you go to hospital, you come out after an operation with a bill for, say, $2,500 and you get back a total of, say, $800 based upon the schedule fee. There is no real value in having insurance in situations like that.

People are increasingly electing to have their own bank accounts specifically ear marked to cover health costs as they may arise in the future and rely upon the public health system, particularly for emergency treatment. Of course, whilst that is happening, what we see this government doing is providing this very dubious benefit to people who may already have private health insurance or—this is most unlikely—those who may elect to take out health cover, and at the same time slashing hundreds of millions of dollars out of the public health system.

The other point I wish to make is in relation to the surcharge. If ever we have seen a con trick this is it; this is the Costello con. Here we have a proposal which, firstly, is a breach of another promise. It is the imposition of a tax, albeit there may not be that many people who actually have to pay it in the end. But it certainly is the imposition of a new tax; that is, a tax on families who have an income of over $100,000 and who do not currently have private health insurance, and a tax on individuals with an income of over $50,000 who do not have private health insurance. They are going to be taxed a surcharge of one per cent on their income. This surcharge is supposedly designed to encourage those people to take out private health insurance. It is also designed apparently to try to recoup some revenue towards the health budget.

We know from the Treasury's estimates that this measure is going to have very little, if any, impact in turning around the decline in private health insurance coverage in this country. It will not have much impact at all, the main reason being that many people in those categories are the people who can afford to have private health insurance, given the current cost of such insurance, and do so. So the number of people that would get caught in this surcharge net is very limited.

Moreover, this really is a spurious proposition, a tinkering at the edges, when we see the real problems being created by this government through its slashing, as I said, of expenditure and funding for the states in the area of health care. I do not believe, and I do not think the Australian people believe, notwithstanding the Prime Minister's solemn promise at the last election, that this government has a real commitment to universal health care. It does not have a real commitment to Medicare.

This government knows, however, that it cannot stand up and state publicly and clearly that it wishes to abolish or dismantle Medicare. At least they were honest about that some years ago. They learned the lesson that the Australian public would never accept that so what they are doing is, through other means, dismantling the excellent public health system we have in this country and doing nothing to make it any more attractive for people to take out private health insurance.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, has the Howard government sought a copy of the legal advice referred to by Premier Borbidge yesterday on the Sunday program? Has the government sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department on the application of section 15 of the constitution? Has the Prime Minister contacted Mr Borbidge demanding he withdraw from his declared intention to breach section 15 of the constitution?

—I know of no request to Premier Borbidge seeking a copy of his legal advice. I know of no request of our Attorney-General as to his views. I would have thought that section 15 of the constitution is pretty clear cut. I did not know there was a lot of dispute about it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has Mr Borbidge explained to the federal government why he sought advice at this time in relation to Senator Colston's position? Is Mr Borbidge acting on advice from the federal government relating to Senator Colston's future? If section 15 of the constitution is, in the minister's words, `pretty clear cut', was Mr Borbidge completely wrong?

—I do not know why Mr Borbidge sought advice on the matter. That is obviously his business. He certainly was not acting on any request from the Common wealth government. We were unaware that he intended to make those comments. The third question you asked was, if it was clear cut—
—Whether you repudiate it.
—His view does not accord with my understanding of the constitution.

—My question is directed to my colleague and friend Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer, in his capacity as representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to media reports which show growing business confidence and a strengthening of the Australian economy—supported by the latest business survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Will the minister elaborate on the results of the survey and indicate those factors which have led business to be more confident about the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question. It shows his continuing interest in small business, and I am sure it will be of great interest to many members of the public. The ACCI released the results of its national survey of business expectations for the 1997 March quarter earlier today.
—Just table the answer and sit down.

—The survey, Senator Ray, presents more good news for the Australian economy, good news for business and good news for the Australian public. But, given the reaction we constantly get from the other side, it is presumably bad news for the Australian Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: The survey points to another factor of what the Prime Minister has called `a rare conjunction of very positive circumstances as far as our economic future is concerned'. The ACCI says the results represent `an unmistakable improvement in economic conditions'. It furthers says:
A strong lift in business confidence during 1996 has only now translated into an improvement in the actual level of activity.

The latest survey results show that not only is confidence improving but so too are actual outcomes. The improvement can be seen in actual outcomes for general business conditions, sales revenue, exports, overtime and investment. Beyond the actual outcomes, the expectations data show that the current improvement is expected to continue. The data show expectations of an even better performance in the quarter to come for general business conditions—sales, exports, profits, employment and investment.

Turning to the details of the survey, the net balance of sales revenue is strongly positive. Exports are strongly positive, with a net balance of plus 15.5 per cent. Profits data show an expected increase in the next quarter and there is a positive net balance in both the actual and expected series of investment in building. The good news goes on and on.

We make no apologies for putting in place policies which are good for business, especially for small business—policies which allow these businesses to grow and prosper. These policies are absolutely vital because better business conditions are a necessary prerequisite for getting higher jobs growth and tackling unemployment.

Our policies tackle Labor's budget deficit blow-outs; take the pressure off interest rates; keep inflation low such that wages do not need to continue to grow at rapid rates trying to catch prices; reform the labour market and repeal Labor's job destroying unfair dismissal laws; lift the burden on small business by giving substantial benefits through the CGT rollover relief; and give business the confidence to invest in the future by both building up investment and hiring new employees. The government is confident about the economy. We are putting in place the policies to grow and to tackle Labor's worst legacy—the legacy of very high unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the minister to elaborate on the March quarter figures, with particular emphasis on investment in plant and machinery. Would the minister mind outlining to the Senate the positive benefits that are going to flow in terms of investment in plant and equipment?

—I thank Senator Watson again for his interest. The survey results show a growing level of investment in plant and equipment in the last quarter, recording a balance of 10.3 per cent and a similar balance for the quarter to come. So on the investment front, as Senator Watson has indicated, the news is very good. It is good for Australia, good for business, good for jobs but bad for the Labor Party.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, do you agree with the statements of the Chief Justice of the High Court Sir Gerard Brennan, in his letter to the Deputy Prime Minister, that `public confidence in the constitutional institutions of government is critical to the stability of our society'? Can you explain, Minister, how the continuing criticism of the High Court by the Deputy Prime Minister and by the Queensland Premier, including their personal attacks on High Court judges, can in any way at all be conducive to the maintenance of public confidence in one of our most important constitutional institutions?

—I certainly do not know of any personal attacks on High Court judges, and I would not agree with it. It is important for the community to maintain confidence in the constitution and confidence in the High Court. But that does not mean that one is not allowed to criticise particular judgments. I certainly have not agreed with every judgment that has been given in the High Court. When I disagree, I am happy to argue my case. In this instance, no doubt those that you refer to were doing just that.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you trying to tell us that Mr Fischer's accusations of the High Court indulging in `unacceptable activism', Mr Borbidge's description of—
—Who?

—Sir Gerard Brennan's defence of the Hight Court as `pathetic and lamentable' and Mr Borbidge calling some High Court judges `dills' are not criticisms that undermine public confidence in the High Court? Minister, it has been some eight weeks since Sir Gerard Brennan's letter to Mr Tim Fischer. When will the Prime Minister show some leadership on this issue and defend the High Court against some of these unwarranted attacks?

—I think Senator Bolkus was referring to Mr Borbidge. That is the trouble when you read your leader's questions without checking them first, Senator. I think there has been nothing illegitimate in what Mr Fischer has said. I do not think anything Mr Fischer has done has had any effect to undermine public confidence in the court. The whole issue of judicial activism is one that rises from time to time, and really it depends a little bit on your interpretation of the judgment.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. My question relates to jobs and improved services in regional and rural Australia. Minister, will you inform the Senate as to the benefits for regional Australia resulting from the government's restructuring and expansion of Social Security's teleservice centres and facilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome Senator Patterson's question on this matter. As we all know, she has long had a very keen interest in improving the efficiency of the Department of Social Security and the services that it offers to Australians in need. She is also very well aware that the teleservice system that we inherited from the previous government was in a disgraceful state. Anybody who has tried to contact the department through the teleservice network in the last couple of years will tell you that it was frustrating and time consuming. I am sure the previous minister must have had the sort of correspondence that I have received from colleagues and members of the public expressing frustration at the mess.

ANSWER.PARA: The previous government set up that service with inadequate research and certainly without enough people or money to make it work effectively. In December and January we finalised about 60,000 calls a day, which is pretty terrific except when you recognise that we were receiving about 400,000 attempted calls in a day. That is a measure of what we inherited. The previous government was not prepared to recognise that or do anything about it. They did not acknowledge that people prefer using this method of doing business if they possibly can.

Not only have we recognised the reality but we have set about trying to do something about the problem. On Friday last I announced that a further 500 jobs in regional Australia are to be created in the teleservice system. Effective telephone contact with Social Security for people in regional and remote areas of Australia is of course of vital importance. They cannot just trot down the street and see their local, friendly regional office. This government recognises that that service will be improved for regional Australia as a result of our initiative. Those 500 jobs come on top of the 300 that we announced in South Australia and Victoria late last year, and they form part of an overall package and strategy designed to improve telephone access to our customers while at the same time, importantly, increasing employment in regional Australia.

New centres are to be established in Port Macquarie and Wendouree outside Ballarat. Over 100 jobs will be created in each of those two centres.
