We are also significantly expanding existing teleservice centres at Gosford, Toowoomba, Townsville and Geelong, and each of these centres will have their employee numbers boosted to around 100 in each centre, meaning an increase of about 200 new jobs in those centres.

A further purpose‐built service of 100 new jobs is currently being considered and, once again, these jobs will go to an area with high unemployment. That is in addition to the other improvements being made to enhance teleservice facilities in the Department of Social Security through the better training of staff, through the upgrading of technology and through initiatives such as giving customers receipt numbers over the telephone so they have proof of their call when a call is finalised.

This government is determined to try to do something to improve the telephone service. It will not happen overnight—I do not want false expectations raised—but we have recognised the reality of the mess that Labor created and we are determined to improve the service to our customers. At the same time, this will provide badly needed new jobs in regional Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to the denial by the minister for industry, Mr Moore, that he had had any personal involvement in a campaign to lobby a hit list of cabinet ministers to maintain tariffs on textiles, clothing and footwear. Is it true that Mr Moore hosted and chaired a meeting between his departmental officials and senior TCF industry association executives in Canberra on 13 February? Is it true that at that meeting Mr Moore's officials advised the lobbyists present to confront key cabinet ministers with threats of job losses in their electorates and home states if industry protection was cut? Did the hit list include Mr Fahey, Mr Reith, Mr Costello, Mr McLachlan and Mr Downer? Does this constitute personal involvement by Mr Moore and is this the way Howard government ministers go about advancing the interests of mainstream Australia? (Time expired)

—The minister advises that the report in Saturday's Australian is incorrect and without substance. He also says that there was no attempt to seek a response from him before the article went to press. I shall refer your question to the minister. If he has anything further to add, I will advise you accordingly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Are you aware of a recent Austrade survey of 423 companies co‐sponsored by the British Overseas Trade Board and conducted by the London Business School showing that determination is the key to export success? The study said:

QUESTION.PARA: High performers are likely to visit their export markets to better understand them, and build close, trusting, long-term partnerships with their foreign distributors.
People who enjoy travel and thrive on the challenges of new market environments are likely to do best.

Given that the study highlights the primary importance of visiting export markets, why has the government sought to make the cost of airfares incurred in the pursuit of export business no longer claimable under the export market development grant scheme? Everyone knows that face-to-face contact is the most effective for small and medium sized businesses. Won't this measure particularly hurt small to medium sized businesses who need to rely more heavily on travel because they do not have on‐the‐ground bases or contacts in other countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of how much Australia can afford to pay in contribution towards our exporters' efforts in expanding their markets. Regrettably, if you have to meet a deficit of $8,000 million to $10,000 million as we had to, you have to very significantly reduce public expenditure. You cannot have it both ways.
—This scheme actually makes money for Australia. Is that why you're cutting it?
—Part of your approach was to spend more and more public money, but it did not work.
—It makes money for the country, you dope.
—The current account continuously got worse. Inflation went up. Interest rates went up. Your solution—
—This makes profit.

—Senator Cook, you had your chance and you failed. That is why you were thrown out of office. We have taken an alternative approach and it is relevant for Australian exporters. Firstly, we have tried to get the domestic economy into shape by reducing interest rates, and providing a climate in which interest rates can be reduced, inflation kept down and pressure kept off taxation. If you give our exporters the opportunity to compete within a competitive do mestic economy, then they have a chance. Secondly, we have put our effort into opening overseas markets through good diplomacy and the like, and supporting them through organisations such as Austrade and, as you have acknowledged—although perhaps not to the extent that you would like to see, Senator—through direct assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: Out of that blend—and we believe we have got the blend about right—exporters have the best chance to succeed in markets, provided they have that ingredient that you have identified as essential, and that is determination. In our view a lot of Australian exporters have got that. But what has held them back in the past has been primarily that they have had to compete within a domestic economy that is uncompetitive, and secondly that they have not had adequate access to markets. So our emphasis is on those two directions rather than specifically on the one you are referring to in your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I do understand there is a limited budget, but how have you prioritised industry assistance measures? In the list of EMDG needed assistance, travel is one of the highest needs. What I would like to hear from you is the way in which the needs under the scheme have been prioritised and why travel does not feature better.

—You can argue all day as to the priority that ought to be put before it, and we have had that debate in the estimates. We have chosen the mix of support through the EMDG system that we believe can best contribute, from a government perspective, to exporters within the budget constraints that we now face.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given Senator Parer's answer to Senator Cook's question, do you accept that, if Mr Moore hosted and chaired a meeting between his departmental officials and senior TCF industry association executives, that does not constitute personal involvement? Can you confirm, Minister, that your cabinet col leagues are infuriated by Mr Moore's action in presiding over a campaign to lobby them to maintain assistance to the TCF industry? What has been the reaction of those on Mr Moore's hit list and do you agree with the unnamed minister who described Mr Moore's action to the Weekend Australian as `unbelievable' and `a sacking offence'?
—I thought Senator Parer's answer to that question was excellent and I have nothing further to add.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that Mr Alan Wood, the economics editor of the Australian , described Mr Moore's antics as `astonishing behaviour by a minister of the Crown and his departmental officials who are obliged to act in the interests of all Australians not narrow vested interests'? Aren't Mr Moore's actions directly contrary to the principles of cabinet solidarity and collective responsibility? Why hasn't Mr Howard got the gumption to discipline Mr Moore for yet more treachery on his part?

—Senator Faulkner, for his purposes, finds Mr Moore guilty first and then determines the processes that can achieve that goal. In fact, as has been said, there were inaccuracies in that article and therefore the premise to the question is false.

—My question is addressed the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. I refer the minister to the fact that the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 has reverted to the use of gender specific language such as `chairman', and also to the fact that this appears to conflict with statements made by the Attorney‐General in his second reading speech to the Statute Law Revision Bill 1996 in which he confirmed that changes to insert feminine as well as masculine pronouns were part of the process of altering gender specific language in legislation. I ask: does this apparent change in policy indicate any broader government policy change with respect to the use of gender neutral language? If so, when can we expect to be advised of any specific government policy in this regard? Are you, perhaps, considering delaying this announcement to coincide with International Women's Day this Saturday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, your humour has lost you today. To suggest that, were such a decision to be made, it would be announced on International Women's Day is hardly humorous. I have not had a look at the Productivity Commission Bill closely. I will have a look at it. I will refer the matter to the Attorney‐General and, if he has got something to say about it, I will give you his comments.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can you please confirm or perhaps take it on notice that this is verbal instruction being given by the Prime Minister to revert to gender specific terminology but without a specific written policy as yet? Would you not consider that, if this were the case, if would go against the concept of open government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take it on notice. If anybody I refer it to has got something to say about it, I will put an answer on the record for you.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Minister, is it appropriate for the Treasurer, Mr Costello, to undermine the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, by publicly disparaging his industrial relations changes by saying that they do not go far enough? Does the government endorse the Treasurer's view? Has the government also adopted Mr Costello's view that unemployment will only be reduced if workers' wages are able to be driven lower?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that any of that has been said. The fact is that it is the government's view that the changes that we negotiated through the Senate last year do go a very substantial way down the track. Certainly they honour our election promises. We would very much expect over time that there will be a very significant change in the culture of the workplace. But let me stress that the last thing we would want is an approach that involved the cutting of wages. Certainly I would be very surprised if anyone in the government sees that as the major way of achieving labour market reform.

ANSWER.PARA: The aim of the game should be to achieve much greater flexibility in the workplace so that people are able to negotiate direct with their employers without having your preselection committee looking over their shoulders and telling them how to call the shots. They ought to be able to do it on a basis of trust; not have your crowd undermining them and telling them not to trust anyone, particularly employers. They ought to do it on a basis where they are able to share in the increased productivity that inevitably derives from much more sensible approaches to workplace relations than you lot were ever prepared to contemplate.

We do not have your baggage. We simply take the view that around the world it has been shown time and again that, if you can have genuine negotiations at the workplace that not only take account of the practicabilities of people's working requirements but also give them a slice of the action, the last thing you are talking about is driving wages down: you are talking about increasing productivity and ensuring that everyone else is able to benefit as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Alston, does this mean, therefore, that you reject the view of Mr Costello? Because implicit in his argument is that greater labour flexibility means the ability to have lower wage outcomes if your government is to be able to achieve anything in terms of reducing unemployment. Will you be assisting in rejecting Mr Costello's view inside cabinet? How this sit with Mr Howard's core promise about making sure that workers will not be worse off? Surely Mr Costello is arguing for the very reduction in wages that Mr Howard said would not occur. When will the government reject Mr Costello's views and make it clear that no further industrial relations legislation will be introduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht and I had a discussion about this the other night in the estimates committee hearings. You simply cannot attribute something to someone on the basis of what you infer from what is written in the newspaper. Either you are quoting someone or you are not.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand you, you basically want to run a line on something and attribute that to Mr Costello. It is not his view that higher levels of unemployment will force wages down and, therefore, make people more amenable to cuts and to labour market reforms. That is not the approach that this government intends to take. We take quite the opposite view that, if we get your crowd out of the way and allow the workers to look at what is in their best interest—not the scare campaigns that some union officials think might be in their best interest—were much more likely to have people being productive on the work floor, being much more interested in improving the productivity of the firm and, as a result, increasing the levels of employment across the board. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment. Tens of thousands of Australians became involved in Clean Up Australia over the weekend, including a number of parliamentarians. How important is it for the Australian community to be directly involved in environmental matters? What plans does the government have in future for a similar clean‐up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do appreciate the opportunity to congratulate the some 500,000 Australians who participated this last week in Clean Up Australia. It is an amazingly successful community movement, and obviously doing a great job in terms of the quality of the environment. In fact, I understand this time some 13,000 tonnes of rubbish was collected from some 7,500 sites, which is up on previous collections. But I think that is largely because more sites are being exposed to it and more people are collecting.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the heartening things I was told during the day was that on revisiting a number of sites collectors were finding that the amount of rubbish had decreased from previous years. So Australians are getting the message and those who participate in these activities obviously communicate to others how important they are. The end result is a cleaner Australia and that is to the benefit of all Australians.

I take the opportunity to specifically congratulate Ian Kiernan and his organisation, which really started as a clean‐up exercise in Sydney and in the space of just a few years expanded to Australia and now Clean Up The World, led by Australia, is a campaign which is being undertaken in many countries around the globe. It is the community at work to provide a better environmental outcome. Yes, we as a government are pleased to support the community whenever we can in such undertakings.

We have been pleased in recent times to give financial support to the Clean Up Australia organisation. We are pleased, as you know, to have called for applications from the community for grants under our Natural Heritage Trust. We are also pleased to be working with community organisations and with industry to help reduce the level of waste in our community—reduce waste going to landfill, for example. I refer just in passing to the agreements that we are reaching with the packaging industry to reduce packaging waste by increasing recycling targets, reducing unnecessary packaging and advocating lightweight products.

So yes, it is an example of the community working hand in glove with governments towards a better outcome. It is not just in this area that we are engaging the community. I take the opportunity to remind honourable senators that last Friday the government published a discussion paper, Future directions for Australia's greenhouse strategy. That is to develop the new national greenhouse response strategy for the next few years. The point I particularly wanted to make is that now is an opportunity for the community to engage in that debate as well as what should be the most appropriate domestic policies for Australia and Australians, because all the community have to play a part to reduce our greenhouse output which, again, is of benefit to the community as a whole.

That paper looked at a number of different options going through sectors such as the industry sector. It looked at the place of greenhouse sinks. It looked at the issue of clearance of native vegetation, issues of methane sources, resource developments and the like. The discussion paper is available to the community and anyone wishing to contact my department can get a copy of it. I urge Australians who are interested in the greenhouse issue to put their views to the Australian government in order that we might continue to work together towards a better outcome in another vitally important environmental area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to the Prime Minister's concern about the adverse impact of gambling in our community. I ask: doesn't the government have to bear a large portion of the blame for this situation by turning a blind eye to the proliferation of irresponsible and grossly inaccurate gambling advertisements? Given the Prime Minister's concern, which I believe is widely shared in the community, will the minister investigate either drawing up an enforceable code of conduct governing such advertising or banning it all together?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought you are the last ones who ought to be preaching to us on these subjects. The fact is that the primary and constitutional responsibility for gambling matters lies with the state governments. Indeed, as the state premiers have been keen to point out, there are only a limited number of areas in which they do have growth taxes and certainly gambling has been one of them.

ANSWER.PARA: What the Prime Minister was very rightly pointing to was the social implications that flow and the need, I would have thought, in a number of situations to ameliorate any problems that arise. Whether that is the responsibility of the casinos themselves, whether it is the responsibility of welfare organisations in conjunction with government, at the end of the day I think you have to accept that there are some very unhelpful social consequences that flow. But that is not to say that we should be out there banning gambling any more than we should be banning alcohol.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about cigarette advertising?

—I would have thought in this day and age you would understand that cigarettes are inherently dangerous. They are unhealthy per se. I do not think gambling is in that category. The problem with gambling is that some people who cannot control themselves—
—It is your responsibility.

—Look, if it was advertising everyone would be hooked, wouldn't they? It clearly is not advertising that causes these things. The fact is that some people in various forms of desperation or weakness find themselves attracted to gambling and develop problems, but they are a very small proportion of the total. So rather than blaming it all on gambling, blaming it on the state, blaming it on the system, blaming it on the Liberal coalition government, why don't you understand that there is a very significant difference?
—There's a phone call for you from John Howard.
—Wrong number!
—It's the TAB line.

—I would have thought Senator Ray would be keeping fairly quiet today after the ringing non‐endorsement you got from him at the weekend when he said in terms of fixing up the leadership we got it right for the most part. Quite clearly, he has very real concerns about the outcome. I think you would have to say that he knows a lot more about what goes on in the Senate than the House of Representatives. As we know, he has always been a great supporter of Gareth Evans. So clearly, it is pretty obvious who he is pointing the finger at. Make the most of it while you can, son. You may not have all that much longer to run. With friends like that I am surprised you don't just get back to policy because clearly you are not doing terribly well on the politics. I do not think I can add any more than I already have.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer the minister to comments made earlier this year by the South Australian minister for education, Mr Rob Lucas, that South Australia will not allow a completely free market for the establishment of new non-government schools following the federal government's decision to abolish the new schools policy. I also refer the minister to the recent statement by the ACT minister for education, Mr Bill Stefaniak, that the ACT government intends to maintain strong control over the establishment of new non-government schools. I ask the minister: does she share the concerns of the South Australian and ACT governments that the abolition of the new schools policy jeopardises the responsible planning for education services? Does she share Mr Lucas's concern that `millions of dollars of State and Commonwealth funding . . . could be wasted in such a free market'? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Allison, for the question. It gives me the opportunity to repeat to you yet again the arguments that you have asked to have rehearsed in front of you on several occasions, almost to the point that it is now an indulgence on your behalf to waste the Senate's time asking questions that you have asked again and again. You asked them when the bill went through again and again. I think your favourite line was: `I just want to hear you say it.' As I responded to you at the time, `In your dreams.'

ANSWER.PARA: Can I assist you, Senator Allison, with some pronunciations. You got `Lucas' right. Mr Rob Lucas is the Minister for Education in South Australia. I have seen some reports of some comments that he has made. Mr Bill Stefaniak it is, however, in the ACT; I have not seen comments that he has made. But the gist of the comments as related by you is that the states realise that they are responsible for these things and, yes, they are now going to in some instances take a stronger interest and introduce more regulation. We have no problem with that whatsoever.

The new schools policy—the abolished new schools policy—supported by those people over there was a policy that inhibited the choice of parents. We say, unequivocally, that parents should have the choice of the sort of schooling that their children go through. We do not have a preference for government or non-government, but we do want to ensure that all parents have the choice of the sort of school that they want their kids to go to. That is why we abolished the new schools policy. We do not see it as a matter for the Commonwealth to be deciding what schools should be opened where. That is primarily a matter for the states. I am glad you have been concentrating on what Mr Lucas and Mr Stefaniak have been saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. If the states do introduce their de facto new schools policies, will the federal government continue to fund those schools which have set up in the interim and which perhaps will not comply with the new criteria? Minister, is it not clear that the abandonment of the new schools policy should have been negotiated and agreed with the states well in advance of introducing the legislation, instead of being rushed through late last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —If there was one bill that was not rushed through this Senate, it was this particular bill that you are referring to because you went on and on like a stuck record. Thank God we do not have RPM records any more. You reminded me of those days with the same question coming out again and again. This was not rushed through; it got perfectly adequate debate in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the funding for schools set up in the interim, you are asking a hypothetical question. Should the matter arise, undoubtedly I will look at it and I will ask Dr Kemp if he has anything particular to say about it. But here you are setting up a potential problem that does not even yet exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance. I refer to the Mid-year economic and fiscal outlook 1996‐97 and to the corrigendum making 170 corrections to the range of data. On what date were those errors drawn to the attention of the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance? When was the corrigendum printed? Why was there a delay in its distribution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is about the fourth time we have had this question put to us. Senator Sherry is showing great concern. We do not make complaints about that. We have said that there were errors in the midyear review. We have brought those errors to the attention of the public. We have corrected those errors. Senator Sherry, if we had not corrected those errors, you would have been the first up and complaining.

ANSWER.PARA: You have asked a number of other questions—what was the date and so forth. I will bring those questions to the attention of the Minister for Finance and seek a response from him.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get a copy of his briefs; why don't you know?

—Senator Sherry, you were there on Thursday night when you had all the officers from the Department of Finance there. It was so important then—wasn't it, Senator Sherry?—that you did not even bother to raise the question. It was so important. You had officers there from the Department of Finance. You were being so pressed about it, that you never bothered to ask the question.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry, I wish to be helpful to you. You want some dates. You probably want some times, I guess. Do you?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, just the dates are fine.

—In that case, I will put those questions to the Minister for Finance. But it does raise the question why, with all those officers there on Thursday night, you never bothered to ask those questions. I can assume, Senator Sherry, that you did not bother to ask them because you did not think they were important. So you have raised them here. But it is all right, Senator Sherry, I will put them to the Minister for Finance and come back and advise you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Yet again, Senator Kemp, you continue to evade questions and refuse to answer them. Given the delay between the discovery of these errors and the distribution of the corrigendum last Thursday night, when it was tabled in the Senate, how does this square with the Prime Minister's now discredited code of ministerial conduct, which requires ministers to be honest in their public dealings, not to intentionally mislead the parliament or the public, and to correct any inadvertent misconception at the earliest opportunity?

—Senator Sherry, I have not refused to answer your questions. I have said that I will get you the information that you are seeking. That is what I have said. I do not know whether I can explain it any more clearly to you. I am not refusing—
—Why can't you answer the question?
—Why did you not ask the question when we had all the officers there from the Department of Finance? We had them all there at the Senate estimates.
—You covered it up.
—You refused to ask them. You wandered all over the track and made a complete dope of yourself.
—You were too embarrassed by it all. You covered it up.

—Senator Sherry, you had your chance and you blew it, you missed it. So now you are coming back here. I will, as I said, put those questions to the Minister for Finance and seek a response. It is bad luck that you did not raise them last Thursday night when you had a very good chance to.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, the overwhelming success of our film industry has been further consolidated by our recent international achievements at some of the world's most prestigious film festivals, and I include the announcement of nine nominations for this year's Academy Awards. What light does the Gonski report throw on the health of the film industry, and what is the role of government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, the Gonski report gives the film industry a big tick and, as Senator Troeth knows, it is already in a very healthy condition. We have had some magnificent achievements in recent times: Shirley Barrett winning a Camera D'Or at Cannes last year; Geoffrey Rush winning one of the Golden Globes this year; Sundance in Utah in January of this year; and five feature films and two short films all listed for awards. In fact, I think there were more from Australia than any other country. There were nine Academy Award nominations, including seven for Shine , another one for John Seal for the cinematography for The English Patient , and for Romeo and Juliet as well, Katherine Martin. It has been a bumper year, and I am sure it will continue to get better as a result of this government's policy approaches to film.
—Rubbish!
—I am not here to say that every success we have had in films in the last 12 months has been entirely due to this government.
—They were made in our period in office.

—But I think you would find that most film makers would say that the way in which the film industry has been supported over the last 12 months, and the way in which Gonski came in and gave a very critical but constructive analysis of the film industry, demonstrates beyond doubt that the film industry is in very good hands at the present time. The last thing they would want to do is to find themselves put at risk by you lot. You only have to ask them what they thought of Michael Lee—knew nothing about the arts, not interested; could barely recite the names of a few films that he had seen recently. That is not what it is about, Madam President.

ANSWER.PARA: What it is about is maintaining, currently $140 million worth of funding for the arts; coming up with some new innovations as Mr Gonski has recommended in relation to what he calls `flicks' to replace the 10BA system; and restructuring some of the current arrangements in relation to film culture. Overall, he endorses the many doors policy. He makes it very clear that the industry is doing very well at the present time, that it continues to need government assistance and that ought to be in the form of direct funding rather than indirect funding.

Overall, I think one can say that the Gonski report has been very well received by the industry. We are at this time having discussions with them about ways in which they would like to see it implemented. Certainly there have been some concerns about maintaining media resource centres like the Open Channel, but these are at the margin. Overwhelmingly the industry, I think, is very comforted by the fact that Gonski has been so positive in his recommendations and this government is very supportive of the industry. May it go from strength to strength.

Senator Troeth and I will be there. We just hope that some of you will come along to the odd film that is shown in Parliament House on a Wednesday night. I cannot recall too many of your faces being there. Senator Conroy has been there a few times; he has an interest in Australian culture. If you had been there, you would have been able to see Shine when it was first shown in this country. But the fact is that you are all too busy plotting—plotting against one another, no doubt. If you want to raise your sights a bit more, if you want to try to adjust to the long hard years—it took 10 years for Scott Hicks to get Shine off the board; you are looking at least at 10 years—you might as well come along and enjoy yourselves on occasions like Australian showings in Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Did the Minister for Health, Mr Wooldridge, receive a report on private health insurance from the Productivity Commission last Friday? Does the minister agree that the draft of this report that was issued last December was critical of this government's health initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any information from Dr Wooldridge as to what he might have received on Friday. In fact, I think I told you last week that I really am not responsible for everything he does—breathing, eating, sleeping, et cetera. I am very happy to pass your question on to him.

ANSWER.PARA: I have had a very interesting little exercise undertaken in the last few weeks as to the performance of the previous ministry about representational matters. It has been quite fascinating to see just who answered what. I think you might be interested to know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. We know how sensitive Senator Newman is about the issue of her absolute incapacity to answer any question in any portfolio she represents.
—Is this a point of order?
—My point of order is that she has been asked specifically about a question relating to her role as Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services.
—What's your point of order?

—The point of order is that Senator Newman is now embarking on some point of complete irrelevance about the previous government and apparently the number of questions that were taken on notice or given to ministers in that government representing other portfolios. Clearly, that is out of order in answer to the question that has been asked by Senator Neal. Madam President, you are required under the standing orders to call Senator Newman to order and not allow her to abuse the procedures of this place in this way—sit her down and, if she cannot answer the question, shut her up.

—On the point of order: Senator Faulkner is obviously very sensitive to issues of this kind because of his own past record. But I draw your attention to the fact that the comments I was making, when rudely interrupted, went to the answer I gave to Senator Neal and that I was proposing to continue. It is perfectly reasonable that I make it very clear when I am answering on behalf of another minister—and it is only of recent times that this opposition over here was on the front benches on this side—and it is very relevant, as to the comparison between—
—Is this on the point of order?
—Senator Newman is speaking to the point of order for roughly the same length of time as you did.
—For instance, I was asked 100 questions last year; 17 only did I take on notice; 83 were answered in full. Fifty‐eight questions were asked of my portfolio, only two of which I took on notice.
—Very good.
—Forty-two questions were asked of me in my capacity as a minister representing ministers in the other place, and 15 only were taken on notice.
—Senator Newman!
—Let me compare that with the record of this lot over here.
—Order! Senator Newman! Both the original point of order and this discussion in relation to it have gone into debating the issue.
—Do it after question time.

—There is an opportunity to debate the issue after question time. There are still more than three minutes left to deal with the answer to Senator Neal's question. I draw your attention to that aspect of the matter before the Senate.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. At the very commencement of Senator Newman's answer to the question from Senator Neal, she clearly stated that she was not in a position to answer the question and she would refer it to the minister for an answer. On that basis, I do not believe that she has any further right to try to wax lyrical about irrelevant matters. She has indicated that she will take the question on notice and get back to the Senate. That is as far as she should be entitled to go and I would ask you to rule that way.
—The minister has four minutes to deal with the question that Senator Neal put to her. If she has anything further to add, she certainly is able to do so.
—Thank you, Madam President. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to what Senator Cook had to say one day. He said:

BREAK.PARA: I have absolutely no briefing on this question.
Is that not what I just told you?

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam President. My point of order is that surely it is an abuse of question time for this incompetent minister to be answering a question directed to her by Senator Neal in her capacity as minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services and starting to canvass some answer to a question that was given by Senator Cook in the life of the last parliament. Madam President, I put to you very seriously that you ought to rule this incompetent minister out of order and sit her down.

—On the point of order, Madam President: Senator Faulkner's gruff voice and appearance masks an extraordinary sensitivity to personal insult. I put it to you that the arguments he has raised with you are non sequiturs. Senator Newman is entitled to answer the question as she sees fit and she is entitled to use whatever arguments she likes to use to indicate the adequacy of that answer. That is exactly what she is doing. She is indicating the adequacy of the answer by reference to the adequacy of answers given in the past by those who now seek to claim the opposite. I think it is a perfectly respectable argument for Senator Newman to be raising as justification for the answer she has given. She is entitled to do that.

—On the point of order, Madam President: I return to the point I made a moment ago. Senator Newman indicated at the outset that she was not in a position to answer the question. She said she would take it on notice. How is it possible for her to then proceed to try to answer the question when she stated clearly that she cannot answer it? On that basis, she has completed her answer. Her answer is that she cannot answer the question and she will get some advice from the minister. On that basis, I do not think she is entitled to make any further comments.

—The situation is that Senator Newman did indicate that she would refer it to the minister. Whether it shows in the Hansard or not, I do not know, but there were interjections at that time challenging her on not being able to answer it now. On that basis, I can understand her responding, as she has, in wanting to deal with that issue. It has gone on for some considerable time, eating into question time at this stage. There are now two minutes and 59 seconds remaining in which this matter may be dealt with and it really ought to deal with the question asked by Senator Neal without interjections.

—It is also relevant to point out that I not only represent the Minister for Health and Family Services but I also represent the Minister for Family Services, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and, in addition, I am the minister for one of the biggest portfolios in the federal government, which now includes housing as well.
—If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
—Senator Faulkner was an abject failure as a minister so it ill behoves him to make those sorts of allegations. Senator Bolkus, for instance, said:

BREAK.PARA: I have looked through the brief that has been made available to me and, even though a number of questions were anticipated today, one like this was not. I would like to take the question on notice . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down and shut up, you fool.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, will you withdraw that comment?
—I withdraw the fact that I called Senator Newman a fool.

—On a point of order, Madam President: during the course of that delightful little exchange, he also referred to Senator Newman as a dope. I think you ought to make it clear that this sort of sledging should not be allowed to continue. It is about time he decided to reform himself and concentrate on real issues.
—On the point of order, Madam President: in relation to calling Senator Newman a dope, truth is my defence.
—From what has been a very good question time today, in the last few minutes it has degenerated considerably.
—On a point of order, Madam President: the question from Senator Neal related to a Productivity Commission report. I would ask you to ask the minister to remain relevant to that particular issue.
—If there is anything else to be added on the Productivity Commission report, Senator Newman, you may do so.

—As has been a precedent with successive ministers representing ministers in the other place, I am very happy to get the details, such as are available, and bring them to the Senate, as I said at the beginning.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am well aware of the burdens carried by Senator Newman in relation to her ministerial responsibilities, but there is a very easy remedy for that situation. I can understand that there are circumstances where issues may be raised that you may not be aware of, but this particular issue relates to something that was part of your health policy document during the election, was canvassed in December when the draft report was issued—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. This is an interesting little speech but, if it is an attempt at a supplementary question, then it is feeble. I suggest she be invited to ask the question or to sit down.
—Order! Senator Neal.

—I think, in the circumstances, an answer could be given. Given that the legislation dealing with private health insurance incentives is before the Senate at the moment, how can this minister justify not issuing the Productivity Commission report before we have to vote on it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already said that I am not aware of the minister's situation with regard to receiving the report. Therefore, I am not able to answer any further comments that you might like to make by way of editorial.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Thirteen years of Labor governments gave Australia not only the recession that we had to have but also a shockingly high youth unemployment record of 34.6 per cent. What actions has the Howard government taken to reduce youth unemployment and what are the early signs that the coalition government is achieving success in this area by comparison with the appalling Labor record of 34.6 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles for her question directed at one of the most important issues facing this government—that is, the very high unemployment levels left as an ingrained stain on the economy after 13 years of Labor. I have made the point before that this ingrained stain on the economy is not something for which there is a Dynamo fix. You cannot put a little on the stain and the rest in the wash and out it will come. After 13 years of Labor, we had very unacceptably high unemployment and more than unacceptably high youth unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Before getting to the point of Senator Knowles's question, it is worth noting that, despite having been elected by the people on numerous occasions and having had 13 years and got it so comprehensively wrong, the big `s' word can never come out of their mouths. They can never say sorry. They can never say, `Sorry, we got it wrong.' I sit in here day after day and listen to people opposite. The interjections from the other side lead me to conclude that they actually believe that the Australian people did not know what they were doing when they kicked Labor out. They think it has all been a nasty nightmare and that, at the next election, they are going to sweep back to power. They have not connected that after 13 years—which is a fair enough run—they did not get it right. You cannot bring yourselves to say that word, can you? You cannot bring yourselves to say sorry. You could not possibly manage it.

Senator Knowles asked me what this government is doing. We were elected to fix this mess. We came into a shocking mess they wanted to just turn away from. They could not face the mess they had created and we were elected to fix it. And I am asked: what are we doing to fix it?

Of course, since the election of this government, there have been three reductions in interest rates. That has to be in the top league of changes that will introduce confidence into the business community and likely lead to better employment levels. That partly comes about through being a responsible government and having a balanced budget and low inflation. We have made the workplace arrangements more flexible with the assistance of the Democrats. Anybody who wants to look at low unemployment levels will see a very flexible labour market. We were prepared to tackle that with the assistance of the Democrats. These people never did. They left us with a straitjacket industrial relations system. We are revitalising the apprenticeships and traineeships that were left waning under Labor.

Do you know, Madam President, that when we came to power, the number of apprenticeships was roughly the same as it was 10 years before? When we all know that apprenticeships are one of the key ways to ensure that someone will get a job, that is a disgrace. One of the key ways to get a job, if you are not going to university, is to get an apprenticeship, and you did not provide enough of them. We are providing individually tailored labour market assistance to unemployed Australians. Twenty‐eight thousand five hundred apprentices and trainees have commenced so far this year. That is nearly double the number for the same period last year and we will substantially exceed last year's total of 36,000. That increase is directly related to this government's having the guts to cut Labor's wasteful Working Nation programs and put that money more towards apprenticeships and traineeships. We all know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense—that's nonsense. You know that's not true.
—Look at the numbers, Senator. We have increased apprenticeships; you just left them waning in the never‐never. Yes, we had to find savings—(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the minister to detail further some of the other measures she has not been able to detail thus far due to the restriction of time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very kind of you, Senator Knowles.

—I raise a point of order. I think Senator Knowles raises a good point there. In the interest of completeness, maybe the minister should also address the fact that youth unemployment has gone up by 14 per cent while she has been minister.
—There is no point of order, Senator Bolkus.

—It is worth just fixing in Labor's mind just how poorly they did in this area. Yes, it is true that we had to make substantial savings because of Beazley's black hole, but it is also true that, in order to protect and enhance the important programs—apprenticeships and traineeships—substantial cuts were made to Labor's very, very wasteful Working Nation programs. I make no bones about that. They were wasteful programs.

ANSWER.PARA: The key point is: under this government more kids are getting apprenticeships and traineeships. What does that mean? More young Australians are in a better position to get a job. You opposite all know that if they do not have appropriate training and appropriate apprenticeships, then they are not likely to get jobs. You understand that very well. In the time available—sadly wasted today—we could have a dorothy dixer a day on what this government is doing and it would exceed anything they ever did. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bolkus today, relating to comments made by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Fischer) concerning the High Court of Australia.

On 3 January this year, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia wrote to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). It was not a normal letter; it was not a run of the mill letter. It was a letter of major constitutional impact. One has only to check through the records to find that this sort of correspondence is without precedent. It is a letter that raised legitimate concerns. It raised concerns that should be of concern not just to constitutional lawyers of this country but very much to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and this government.

It raised concerns that the Deputy Prime Minister had got it wrong when he complained about the time it had taken for the Wik case judgment to come down. It also raised concerns that the Deputy Prime Minister had undermined deliberately the constitutional system of this country and had undermined the High Court. It is worth placing on record some specific quotations from that letter. The Chief Justice says:
to say that there was any unwarranted delay in the delivery of the Wik judgment is quite unjustified.
One has only to read the preceding page and a half of documentation to show that the Deputy Prime Minister had got it woefully wrong.

The other aspect of the correspondence goes to the campaign—the lynch squad—that has been out to destabilise and undermine the High Court. In that respect, Chief Justice Gerard Brennan makes a number of points, which are also important and should be placed on the record. Towards the end of his letter, he says:

You will the more readily appreciate that attacks of the kind that you have made, emanating from a Deputy Prime Minister, are damaging to this Court. You will appreciate that public confidence in the constitutional institutions of Government is critical to the stability of our society.
He goes on to say:
members of the particular branches of government do not (and certainly should not) attack the judges except on a substantive motion in the Parliament.
I think his last sentence is quite telling. He asks the Deputy Prime Minister—in fact he admonishes him to bear this in mind:

BREAK.PARA: to consider whether the making of attacks on the performance by this court of its constitutional functions is conducive to good government, even if an attack can gain some temporary political advantage.

As I say, it is an unprecedented letter from the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, a letter which reflected obviously the concern of the High Court but also reflected the concern of many Australians at the way that Tim Fischer had gone over the top. It was not just a concern at the time. The concern is being expressed even to this day, with a letter in the Australian by Mr Chris Pullin QC, the President of the Australian Bar Association. In his letter, he says:
Another unfortunate aspect of the recent criticism of the court has been the personal attacks made on individual judges. This is quite unacceptable.
He is spot on in that respect. He goes on to say:
In the ultimate analysis, such personal attacks should be seen as an attempt by the executive to secure more power for the executive and the legislature.

Mr Pullin is concerned about personal attacks. He is concerned that those attacks reflect a grab for power by the executive and he is concerned that the concept of separation of powers—something quite alien to, especially, Queensland conservatives—is being blurred by the attacks by the Deputy Prime Minister.

What has been the government's response to Chief Justice Brennan's letter? It has been one monumental snub. Since that date of the correspondence, 3 January, Tim Fischer has maintained and continued his attacks, on 11 January and thereafter. Queensland's Premier Borbidge has continued the attacks and they have become more shrill, more violent and more strident. He calls the High Court justices `dills'. He talks about their being increasingly held in absolute and utter contempt. That sort of language is something that does not engender confidence in our constitutional system.

The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), whom one would expect to give solid support to the court, is quite equivocal when he talks about the role of the High Court and the fact that the High Court should basically come back from the sort of role it is playing. They are joined by Victorian Premier Kennett.

But one person who would love to put himself on the court—he is just about everywhere else—and who has abdicated his responsibility is the Prime Minister. He should have taken action to restrain the Deputy Prime Minister. He should have taken that some time ago. If respect for the constitution and its institutions means anything, he should have acted quickly. But, instead of defending the High Court and defending the institutions, he has actually joined in the chorus. As usual, from the sidelines, he has indulged in a debate on the High Court, claiming that the High Court has only one job and that is to interpret statute law. Yet any first year law student knows that the High Court, in its recent cases, has done what the High Court has always done, and what courts in the British system have always done: to interpret and define the common law. The Prime Minister is involved in trumped up charges—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to support the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). He has not made any personal attacks. He has certainly criticised the judgment of the High Court, as many others would have done. You can understand where the Leader of the National Party is coming from when, under the Native Title Act, which the Wik decision should have been based on or held in consideration for, the High Court held that native title is extinguished by valid government acts that are inconsistent with the continued existence of native title rights and interests, such as the grant of leasehold in the states. It went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The needs of the broader Australian community require certainty and the enforceability of the acts potentially make invalid because of the existence of native title. It is important to provide for the validation of those acts.

No direction could have been clearer to the High Court and yet the High Court ignored what this parliament voted on. Every one of us in this parliament believed that native title was extinguished by pastoral leases and mining leases. We all voted on it. We took the word of the previous Prime Minister, the previous Attorney‐General, Gareth Evans, and all the other members of the Labor Party who spoke and convinced us that native title would be extinguished. So, if Chief Justice Brennan believes that he is going to get any accolades from people who represent rural Australia for his decision that plunged Australia into an abyss, certainly the people out there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—Senator Reynolds, you are an utter joke. Senator Reynolds, please do not distract me. If Chief Justice Brennan believes that he is going to get accolades from this side of parliament, when his decision has plunged rural and mining Australia into an abyss of uncertainty, then he can forget it. I will quote one of Chief Justice Brennan's judgments. Those on the other side should listen to this and they might understand it. In the Theophanous case, Chief Justice Brennan said that the constitution implies freedom of speech, including a right for public figures to criticise politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: So that was his decision on the Theophanous case. Anyone can criticise us—we are fair game—but he is up there on some sort of a platform, where he is beyond criticism. I am sorry, Chief Justice Brennan, but you are not beyond criticism. The High Court is not beyond criticism. This country still has freedom of speech.

My leader, Mr Fischer, did not personally attack Chief Justice Brennan. He criticised the judgment, as every right‐thinking Australian criticised the judgment. It is an absolutely appalling judgment. I want to tell the Senate that at our meeting on Saturday there was a resolution carried unanimously, 100 per cent, supporting Tim Fischer's criticism of the High Court.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FORSHAW

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 193(3), which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Senator shall not use offensive words against either House of Parliament or of a House of a State or Territory Parliament, or any member of such House, or against a judicial officer . . .

I would ask you to rule as to whether or not Senator Boswell's comments, with respect to the chief justice and to members of the High Court, are in order. I would suggest that they are, quite clearly, out of order. They are offensive words being used against senior judicial officers of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I would ask Senator Forshaw to nominate the offensive word that I have used. I have not been offensive in the least to anyone on the High Court. I have criticised their judgment; I have not criticised any person in particular.
—You've attacked them personally.

—I have not attacked anyone personally. I have criticised the judgment and I have merely drawn attention to the chief justice's ruling on the Theophanous case, when he said that Australia has freedom of speech and people can be criticised. That is my explanation.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on the point of order in response to Senator Boswell's request. Firstly, there was a clear imputation and, secondly, a clear message within the comments made by Senator Boswell. I think he used the words, `Well, Sir Gerard, you are not out there on some ivory tower,' or words to that effect. The clear statement was that Chief Justice Brennan, as a member of the High Court, and other High Court justices presumably believe that they are on some pedestal upon which they would not be subject to criticism in terms of their judgments. I would suggest to you that that is an offensive assertion to put in the Senate in the manner in which Senator Boswell did.

—I believe it is very difficult for Senator Boswell to debate this particular issue without making some reference to the High Court. I do believe at this stage that Senator Boswell has been debating points which have not carried an imputation, but I will listen carefully hereon.

—I merely want to raise the point that Mr Fischer, at our party conference on Saturday, received unanimous support in his decision to point out what the Wik decision has done to rural Australia, particularly the fact that the Mabo legislation had a very clear-cut preamble. Everyone in this party and everyone in this parliament understood that native title was extinguished by pastoral or mining leases. It said so very clearly. I believe 99 per cent of Australians would believe that the highest court in the land is this parliament. This parliament makes the laws because the people elect this parliament. They expect this parliament to make the laws, and they expect the High Court to interpret those laws. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the same matter. Senator Boswell is so completely out of his depth in considering this issue that I feel rather sorry for him. I also feel sorry for a number of members of the National Party, because they are not prepared to listen rationally to what the High Court decision is.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely irresponsible of Premier Rob Borbidge to claim that the High Court is out of step and to attack the High Court because, in actual fact, the High Court has simply considered the legal issues in an international context. Australia cannot live in a vacuum when it comes to consideration of native title issues. It will have a devastating impact on our national image. It will impact on our trade reputation. It will certainly impact on our reputation as a country committed to human rights if we are not prepared to accept a very simple judgment—Senator Boswell, if you were prepared to listen—that Aboriginal people and pastoral interests may coexist. Coexistence is the issue that the High Court has ruled on.

Senator Boswell said that we understood this in the native title debate. In the native title debate, we agreed to leave this issue to the court to determine; that is, whether or not native title did in fact remain on pastoral leases and if, in fact, it could coexist. We did not know; it was left to the court.

What really concerns me is that a premier of a state of this country does not understand, or chooses to ignore—I am giving him the benefit of the doubt perhaps—the separation of powers. He seems to think that as an elected representative he has the right to be absolutely dismissive of the High Court. He clearly chooses, in a very irresponsible way, to attack the High Court when in actual fact he should be following the leadership of someone like Jeff Kennett or the Tasmanian government. They have actually sat down and talked with indigenous people. I know that Senator Herron agrees with me, because he has made sensible comments along these lines. I acknowledge that Senator Herron and indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have spoken of the need to negotiate, to work this decision through in the interests of both pastoralists and indigenous peoples.

Anyway, the rights of pastoralists prevail. In all the damaging rhetoric Premier Borbidge has been spouting for some weeks now, he seems to choose to ignore that the High Court has said absolutely clearly that where there is a dispute that cannot be resolved the interests of the pastoralists will prevail. So much of what we are hearing is mere political rhetoric, but the damaging feature of political rhetoric is that it impacts very severely on, particularly, indigenous peoples. It unnecessarily worries pastoralists, who should be being told, `We can sort this out if we all learn to live and listen together. We can resolve these issues, just as they have been resolved on Cape York.'

Instead, the Premier of Queensland is more interested in political opportunism, in grandstanding and in attacking the High Court in an absolutely disgraceful way. He has no right to abuse the High Court. All the High Court has done has been to consider the evidence and look at the international precedents—precedents that have existed in countries like the United States, Canada and Scandinavia for much of this century. Rob Borbidge, a real estate agent from the Gold Coast, thinks he knows better than those who have been involved in these issues for nearly 100 years. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing new about scrutiny of the judiciary. In fact, senators opposite will recall the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee inquiry into alleged gender bias of the judiciary. That inquiry looked at various directions to juries by judges in trials which involved sexual offences. Indeed, I think Senator Reynolds expressed great concern at one of the judges who had purportedly said that when a woman says no it does not really mean that. Senator Cooney, I think, chaired that inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: What that committee properly looked at was the question of gender bias in the judiciary and what could be done to remedy the perception in the community that existed at that time. That related to a number of notorious cases involving sexual offences. So there is nothing unusual about scrutiny of the judiciary by the parliament, more particularly by the Senate.

What we have here is a simple situation where the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) inquired as to lack of progress in the Wik decision. The chief justice replied that such inquiry or criticism was unwarranted and he defended the court's position, saying that they had a heavy workload. That is as far as it has gone. There has been no personal attack on the judiciary or any member of it. In fact, the whole situation is being blown out of proportion. The opposition is trying to distort the situation, saying that there is indeed a personal, malicious attack on the judiciary when none exists.

The Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has made comment in the past that attorneys‐general can no longer be expected to perform their traditional role of defending the courts in public. In the West Australian of 1 March he was reported as saying that the Australian Judicial Conference, which recently met, could well be an instrument to fulfil this function. For my part, I would see that as being a possibility. In the Age of the same date, the Attorney-General pleaded for some peace in relation to this row.

When Senator Bolkus says that the Attorney-General is not doing his job, he ought to refer to these two particular articles and think again. I look at the Attorney-General's role in this as being completely appropriate. His actions have been entirely in order. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who has been attacked by the opposition, put things quite simply when he said:

BREAK.PARA: The perception has developed that some judges believe that it is their role to give parliament a hurry on and do things that they think parliament should have done. I can understand why some people have developed that perception.

Indeed, it was the former chief justice who said that there should be some judicial activism and, in fact, as some people would see it, some judicial legislation. When you have a former chief justice saying that, and when you have members of the judiciary who believe there should be some judicial activism, you cannot deny that the perception can reasonably grow from that that judges are hell-bent on some sort of judicial legislation.

What I am saying is that there should always be scrutiny of the judiciary. That is a matter of fact. It is a part of the parliamentary process, part of the parliamentary role of this chamber. That was evidenced by the inquiry of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee into alleged gender bias in the judiciary. That is a matter of record and history.

What we have is a situation where people have been critical of various judgments of the High Court. That is entirely appropriate. Indeed, Senator Bolkus, in his former role as minister for immigration, brought in legislation which was to overturn various judicial decisions relating to his portfolio. Previous governments have been no strangers to overturning various decisions of the judiciary. In fact, members of the opposition have a cheek when they say that we are trying to overturn the Wik decision. They ought to look at what they did in their last term of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to address Senator Ellison as the parliamentary secretary—because this is the first time I have been on my feet since his appointment—and I congratulate him on obtaining what was properly his due. What has been spoken about on this side is not the sort of thing that Senator Ellison was speaking about. Of course judges are not above scrutiny. Section 72 of the constitution says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Justices of the High Court . . . :

(ii) shall not be removed except by the Governor-General in Council, on an address from both Houses of the Parliament in the same session, praying for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity . . .
So the constitution gives the parliament a duty to scrutinise the High Court. That is not the issue. The issue is the process, the style, the language, the mentality—

TALK.START.PARA: —The abuse.

—And, if I can accept what Senator Sherry says, the abuse that is aimed at the High Court. That is the problem, and it has obviously troubled many people—the media and the chief justice himself. Senator Ellison would agree that the present Chief Justice of the High Court is a man of great reputation and great skill in this area and one of our great judges.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ellison talked about judicial activism. Of course there needs to be some judicial activism. That is part of the process that has developed over the history of courts here, in England and in America—that each case presents a challenge and a task for the High Court to deal with. In dealing with it, they sometimes develop the law. That is to be praised.

But Senator Boswell talked about what the people in the country thought about how the parliament would vote on these things. In doing that, he was treating the judges as if they were parliamentarians, as if they were members of that branch of government that deals with legislation. They are clearly not.

The need to protect judges is not a need that is dictated by trying to give them a dignity they do not deserve or to give them an aura that would be pleasing to them. The point about having the judiciary independent is that it goes to the very issue of our civil rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—And Senator Carr agrees with me. The Act of Settlement, made at the beginning of the 18th century, is basic to the civil liberties of people in the United Kingdom, has had a great influence on constitutional theories since then and is fundamentally important to the quality of Australia's human rights.

BREAK.PARA: The seventh clause of the Act of Settlement gives tenure to judges and says that they are not to be removed except, as I said before, on the actions of both houses of parliament. The whole purpose of that is to guarantee that judges will not be placed under undue or improper pressure from parliament or from the executive. It is to keep them clear of that so that they can then decide the law in a way that is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Free of intimidation.

—Yes, Senator Carr, free of intimidation so that they can do justice to everybody without party politics coming into the affair. They are to stand above that. They are to apply a rule of law and they are to be consistent with the rule of law that must be applied. Unless we have a rule of law that stands above parliament, the executive and the courts themselves, we are all in trouble. It is our civil liberties that we have to protect. We do that by protecting the judges from undue criticism. Unfortunately, that is what has happened in recent times. The criticism of the judges has been undue, has been very poorly presented and has been quite wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —A major concern I have on this issue is that this is really another illustration of the adage that all that is necessary for evil to triumph is that good men do nothing—and I use the term `men' to mean both men and women. The situation here is that, once again, when a member of the community has stepped outside the boundaries of what is reasonable in a democratic process, this government, and in particular the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has not seen fit to make a statement which would indicate what the clear boundaries are.

SPEECH.PARA: This has happened once before; it is not a new matter. It happened before when that woman in the other place—and `that woman in the other place' is all I would like to refer to her as—made statements which, in my opinion, were completely beyond what is acceptable in a democratic community. I think this is another example of that occurring.

Some of the comments that have been made by both Mr Borbidge and Mr Fischer clearly go beyond the boundaries of what is reason able in terms of debate and criticism of a particular issue and go to fundamentally undermining the respect and regard that members of the community have for the High Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly the National Party.

—That is quite correct. In fact, Mr Borbidge said, `The current High Court, across large parts of Australia, is increasingly being held in absolute and utter contempt.' I do not see that as some sort of reasoned criticism or some sort of reasoned debate about the issue at hand—whether or not native title is extinguished by pastoral leases. I think it indicates that Mr Borbidge and other members of the National Party have no clear understanding of the fundamental division between the judiciary, parliament and the government. They seem to be unable to understand that, in order for the rights of Australians to be protected, the judiciary has one role in interpreting legislation and the parliament has another role in creating that legislation. It is not the proper role of members of parliament to criticise that interpretation, but there is a proper avenue for redress if they believe that the interpretation of the legislation put forward by the High Court is not in the best interests of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Brennan, in his letter, very clearly pointed out—this matter should be taken note of—that, if members are unsatisfied with the interpretation of legislation, they can properly bring another bill before the parliament and change the law, as is well within their democratic right. So Mr Fischer and other members of the National Party who do not agree with the interpretation of the High Court should not be undermining, criticising and trying to bring into contempt the High Court. They should be putting to their party members a proposal for legislation to be introduced into the parliament. That is their proper course.

But the problem is that members of the coalition government currently do not seem to have a great deal of respect for our constitution. Criticism of the High Court is not the only issue that people like Mr Borbidge have been dabbling in. In fact, Mr Borbidge seems to have indicated that he has no respect for the constitution in terms of the appointment of senators after others have resigned. In fact, as indicated, he may well, if the situation arises, not appoint a senator who is of the same party as a senator who has resigned or vacated their position. I think this is again illustrates that Mr Borbidge and members of the National Party have no regard whatsoever for the constitution and the High Court.
I suppose, fundamentally, this comes down to leadership. If members of the coalition—(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate I referred to a High Court judgment in the Theophanous case and made some reference to Mr Justice Brennan making a statement that politicians were fair game and not beyond criticism and that it was a free country. I have checked with my office and found out that the High Court actually made that decision but Mr Brennan was a minority. I wish to note that. I thank the Senate.
