SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that I am in continuation. Just to recap, when I spoke on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 last Tuesday, it was clear that this particular bill had four aspects to it. My understanding is that just a moment ago the government withdrew its intention to charge massive fees for newly arrived migrants to learn English. That measure would have seen more than a doubling of the cost to migrants to learn English. We approve the discharge of that particular provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week—I believe it was on Tuesday—I made note of the Australian Democrats' policy platform and the fact that with our population and immigration policy, we seek to balance the competing objectives of and responsibility for environmental sustainability, social justice and a sustainable sovereign economy. In this regard we distinguish ourselves from all other parties in this place and perhaps all other senators in this chamber, but particularly the coalition government in both policy and substance. It is a position which I am particularly proud to represent today.

The Australian Democrats' position has been clear and consistent in regard to the family reunion categories. Unlike the government, we believe that spouse, children and even aged parents, with all the fees and charges they have to pay to come to Australia, add value to our society. We do not believe in some kind of socially engineered immigration program or some kind of economically rationalised intake of immigrants. We believe that individuals should be valued on their merits and that being wealthy in itself is neither meritorious nor a particularly sophisticated social view. That said, this schedule seeks to give the government an other dimension of power that I believe it already has.

I mentioned the Democrat position in regard to the capping powers, which the government asserts are necessary to enable it to manage all parts of its migration program. I can assure the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) and the department today that should your government choose a path in regard to capping that is harsh, oppressive or discriminatory, we will be watching closely and will certainly bring you up to speed and scrutinise that particular path if that is chosen.

Since the quite shaky start we have had to this debate, the government has indicated that their sole objective in enacting schedule 2 is to usher in a more flexible and compassionate administrative regime—capping and cuing instead of capping and killing, which is considered more compassionate. Indeed, it is.

A closer scrutiny of the effects of this bill, as well as the minister's assertions, have persuaded us that, on balance, the government of the day should possess such flexibility in determining the immigration program in this country. The question is not whether the government is going to cap but how they will do it. I have made that very clear in all the migration or immigration debates we have had in this place—not so much the numbers that have been brought in but how we are treating people before they get here and once they come into this country. The Australian Democrats will be supporting a more humane way of managing the migration program.

What seems to have been left out of this entire debate is the total population picture, the whole policy issue of population. It is clear the Australian Democrats' policies speak very clearly of sustainable population levels. The population debate, as opposed to the immigration debate, is a discussion we are yet to have in this country. I am glad to see that in recent months the Australian Labor Party have begun discussing the issue of population policy. I would wish to acknowledge that the Democrats have had such a policy almost since our inception and I look forward to the government coming forward with a compre hensive and sophisticated discussion of population issues in this country.

If we are to speak about population in this country, we must also speak about the rural decline that is occurring in Australia. We need to speak about the people already here in Australia who are increasingly moving to our already overburdened eastern seaboard. And—Senator Harradine should be here for this—we should begin to talk about birthrates as well. This underlines our commitment to environmental sustainability, so any population discussion must have regard to the impact on our natural heritage.

Schedule 3 of the bill proposes to implement an exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in relation to the making of certain regulations which will discriminate between de facto and de jure couples. It is a provision which seeks to socially engineer the types of relationships that are important in Australia. This amendment was initially aimed at implementing a two‐year cohabitation period for de facto couples before they could apply for Australian citizenship. Although I understand that the proposal will now be for a one‐year period, this does not necessarily change the original policy concerns we had regarding this proposal.

The government are attempting to develop regulations which discriminate on the ground of marital status. Thus, it is necessary for them to amend the Migration Act to allows its regulation making powers to override the Sex Discrimination Act. The government recently introduced the Sex Discrimination Amendment Bill 1996, which aims to limit the number of exemptions for legislation in relation to the SDA. At the time, the government stated that the bill `reflects the government's commitment to equal opportunity and the prevention of discrimination'.

Both the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats noted, during debate on this bill, the inconsistency of this ostensible policy position with the proposed exemption from migration regulations, in certain circumstances, from the SDA. The fact that the proposed exemption is placed in the Migration Act makes any understanding of the anti‐discrimination regime extremely confusing for anyone in the Australian public. It could be said that, if the government wishes to introduce discriminatory legislation, it should do so by explicitly amending the Sex Discrimination Act, not via a backdoor attempt.

The underlying policy objective of the proposed amendment is that de facto marriages are more likely to be unstable or less likely to be as strong and long as perhaps other types of marriages. It is strongly arguable that this view is antiquated and out of step with current Australian society. In fact, nearly all submissions to the Senate committee's inquiry into this bill put this view. Several noted that it reflected the views voiced in 1960 by the then minister for immigration, the Hon. A.R. Downer, who said:

An immigration policy that smiles on illicit unions would not be in the interests of the Good Life of the Australian community. Those who wish to live in such a way should not expect an easy entry into this country.

A rather outdated view, I should think. The proposed cohabitation rules are almost impossible to fulfil if one's partner is not an Australian citizen and the non‐citizen partner cannot easily get temporary visas either in or out of Australia.

Besides explicitly discriminating on the ground of marital status, the proposals also significantly discriminate against women. Firstly, in many countries, divorces are either extremely difficult to obtain for women or impossible for women to initiate. Therefore, a de facto relationship is the only option a woman will have for forming a new relationship if the old marriage has failed.

The National Council of Churches in Australia made a similar point in their submission to the Senate inquiry when they stated that, in many communities, a two‐year cohabitation period prior to marriage was impossible. Therefore, it would be impossible for those people who exercised their right to live in de facto marriages to enter Australia. In the council's view, `The government should be primarily concerned with the couple rather than the couple's community,' which prohibited de facto marriages.

BREAK.PARA: Even more seriously, there has been significant research recently that there is a disproportionate amount of violence against migrant women in Australia. Examples are research by Dr Patricia Esteal of the Australian National University and by the Australian Law Reform Commission in their report Equality before the law. Women without independent residential status in Australia are particularly vulnerable to such violence. The threat of a de facto relationship being broken can always be used to force them not to seek the intervention of the law in an abusive relationship. I note that the coalition law and justice policy stated:
The prevalence of violence against women and family violence in our community is of deep concern and will not be tolerated by a Liberal and National government.

Finally, the migration regulations currently contain extremely detailed definitions of what constitutes a `spouse' for the purposes of the Migration Act. The focus of this definition is on ensuring that the relationship is bona fide via a series of well‐established tests, including joint bank accounts, letters, phone bills and other well‐established indicators. We consider that there are already appropriate mechanisms and definitions within this bill and, for that reason, are greatly concerned about the attempts to seek exemption from the SDA in this case.
In regard to the issue of capping and queuing, the Democrats will be supporting the government's measure. Our main concerns now relate to the exemption from the SDA.

Finally, I think the issue of the population debate—as opposed to the immigration debate—is a debate that we have to have in this country. We are yet to have it. I commend the ALP on their efforts recently in regard to establishing a policy in this area. I look forward to seeing similar objectives and work undertaken by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of background to this debate on migration legislation, I am sure senators will know that when this bill was last before the Senate the opposition opposed it strongly. It is worth reflecting now that when the debate came on last week, indication was given by the government that there had been some significant discussions between the government and the opposition spokesperson, Duncan Kerr. Those discussions have led to significant and welcome concessions from the government. Of course, there do remain some fundamental differences between both sides of parliament. Although a number of issues have been addressed in this legislation and we have sought to find some suitable middle ground in respect of most of them, there are still some areas in dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to recognise that discussions have led to an accommodation of different points of view in respect of most parts of the government's proposals in this area. For instance, as was noted just before this legislation was called on, the government has agreed to separate the English education charge from the bill in order that the remainder of the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill may proceed, and as a consequence we find our way through to overcoming some of the problems in that area. I also should note at this particular stage that the government undertakes that the regulations which need to follow the passage of the bill will set the English education charge at the current rate, including the concession rate, and that the ceiling will also be set at its current level.

I think what this bill does and what the recent history on this bill does is show the difference in attitudes on this side of the parliament as opposed to the other side. We have seen the measures that were rejected by the Senate at the last debate bandied around by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock). In a sense, we have seen them using the immigration stick to try to belt the Senate around. And they have done so in a way which I think has been ill informed and dishonest in terms of the debate and quite inappropriate in terms of the way immigration really needs to be discussed, especially in Australia.

On our side of parliament we believe that the best way to discuss immigration is not to use it as a political tool in the way that it has been used but to use it as the basis of and as a result of informed debate. We should recognise, for instance, that family migration has been and continues to be important; that a lot of people with skills come into Australia as part of the family migration program; and that, though English is desirable, people who do not speak English have made and continue to make a massive contribution to this country. I think those sorts of recognitions and a recognition of the continued importance of migration to Australia, particularly in the global environment, are something that need to be stressed, not just by one in five speeches by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs or not just under his breath by the Prime Minister. They need to be stressed consistently and continually so that there is informed debate in the community.

We do not have that. To the contrary, we have claims that the skilled component of the migration program is at an all‐time low. If one were to look at the overall migration program and look at the levels of skills that people who come in under the family reunion part of the migration program bring with them, one would find, as I was advised consistently by officials, that we have at the moment levels of skills which are at an all‐time high. That is something that needs to be stressed by this government and something that needs to be picked up, I think, by commentators who look at this issue with blinkers on. I think the responsibility is on government to stress the reality, the facts, the fundamental characteristics of a program which delivers, not just in the skilled part of the program but also in the family reunion part, high levels of skill concentration.

The other point that needs to be made is that this bill is not about levels of migration. We have made it very clear from this side of the parliament—Duncan Kerr has stated it often—that the opposition does not take issue with the government on the size of the program it announced for 1996‐97. In fact, when he announced the program, Minister Ruddock took the trouble to say in his media release that the size of the program was about the average of the previous four years of Labor government. You cannot say that and then say that Labor allowed the program to get out of control, as the minister says. If it is out of control, where are the massive cutbacks? If it is out of control, why are we still talking about levels the average of those of the previous four years of Labor government? The reality is that the minister has been talking in code in this area and wants to give the impression to people in the community that he is going to wind back enormously on migration when, as I said, he says that the program is about the average of the previous four years of Labor government.

So the language is language which is designed to tap into a reactionary vein in the community and I think it is something which is quite unfortunate in this debate. If the program was out of control, why didn't the coalition say so explicitly before the election? If it was out of control in the family reunion part, why before the election did the coalition commit itself to specifically providing priority to family reunion within a program of similar size to the one that we had managed? Those who have taken an interest in this debate know that there were some direct effects of the 1 November decision of just a few years ago and those effects were always going to be felt for a short term in the program. To the extent that there is a blip in the program, we ought to recognise that that has been the case.

As I say, we on this side of parliament would rather get into the reality of the benefits of migration and not indulge in what one public commentator on the broader racism debate put quite aptly as dog whistling. Dog whistling is a technique where the message is coded and is pitched at a certain frequency—a frequency at which a certain audience is expected to be tuned in; a frequency that is directed to that audience but can be denied whenever necessary.

It is regrettable that any member of this parliament should indulge in such practice; it is despicable that some government members have done so. But let me say two things. Whilst some are doing it, many, I think, however silently, would join us in rejecting some of these measures, as well as the concept of dog whistling. I think it is really unfortunate that those involved in dog whistling include the Prime Minister. It is all about playing to racist sentiments with sugar‐coated language, and it really does this country no service in the short term or the long term for that to continue.

So I say that this legislation does reflect a different attitude to migration. On our side we would rather recognise the contribution of migration; we would rather recognise all those things I mentioned earlier. We do not think there is value in the technique of dog whistling.

A key issue in this bill is the measure that would allow the minister to limit or cap the number of spouse, aged parent and dependent children visas that can be granted in any one year. We on this side of parliament are concerned about a minister having introduced that sort of measure. They could have looked at alternative ways if they were concerned about the numbers coming in, but they have not chosen to do so. The approach taken by the government is one that is objectionable in that it has the direct impact of breaking up families.

Let there be no mistake about the issue of capping the spouse visa. It is not one of immigration alone. It is all to do with the violation of the rights of every Australian. Whether the Australian has been a citizen for one day or for six generations, whether that Australian is of Chinese, Greek, Vietnamese, Lebanese, African or English descent, it is all about violating that person's right to have a family and to be with that family.

This legislation makes a mockery of the Prime Minister's commitment to families. It undermines any capacity that people in these circumstances have to be together. In essence, it produces two sorts of families. You can have two sorts of families living in the same street: those who have a right to be together and those who, under this legislation, would be separated because of the government taking a deliberate measure to either cap and kill or cap and queue.

If this legislation were to be passed by the parliament, it would mean that any such Australian would have his/her right to choose to marry restricted. The government has already made it clear that it intends to set a limit on the number of spouse visas that can be issued in each year. This will mean that, if you are a long-term resident and citizen of Australia and are travelling or working overseas—as it is increasingly more common for people to do so; I think we find tens of thousands of Australians doing it every year these days—and you meet a person whom you decide to marry and to bring back with you to start a family, you can be lucky if you make the decision early enough in the life of the program when there are still some visas to be granted. But too bad if you meet that person towards the end of the program. In those circumstances, `try again and good luck for next year' is the attitude that the government is taking.

It is objectionable enough in respect of spouses. It is equally unthinkable in the case of dependent children. There are many scenarios that will arise and do arise. The parent may be in Australia and their children are overseas, or the relationships are born overseas, as are the kids. What we are going to have here is the situation where we will have parents in Australia who, year after year, will be unable to have their dependent children in their care. There are cases, for instance, involving broken marriages. There are cases where the child may be the subject of abuse. There may be one parent overseas and the parent in Australia is unable to bring that child to Australia simply because this government is setting the maximum number of dependent children that can be sponsored. You are simply playing lottery with the lives of families in this respect, and that magic number may have been reached.

These scenarios are not hypothetical. There are already cases where people need to bring their dependants and their spouses here quickly. The sorts of barriers that the minister is putting in place are barriers that will call the immigration policy into public disrepute. When the minister says, `These measures are crucial to restoring public confidence in immigration,' I think he may have that objective, but there is no doubt that the sorts of measures he is continuing to propose will have a directly contradictory effect.

We do not need to forever quote what the current minister said about policies that keep families separated. We do not need to go back to the statements he made in 1989, where he said that it was unconscionable for a government to say halfway through the year, `We've had spouses now. We're going to close off that category. No more people in that category can come to Australia.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And who was in government at that time?

—He was talking then of a proposal that the previous government did not proceed with. He said at the time that he was pleased to see that the government had not chosen that course. Senator Harradine, we were in government at that time, and I am pleased to say that I did not resort to measures like this over the last three or four years when I was responsible for immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: So if you look at the migration program—look at the minister's claim that it is out of control, look at the figures over recent years, look at planning levels, look at outcomes and look at the points that people need to obtain to migrate—you can very quickly come to a conclusion that there are other alternatives that this government could have taken. But the government wanted to play politics with this issue, and that is what they have done.

In the interim period, since this legislation was last debated in this place, Duncan Kerr has had discussions with the government in an endeavour to find a reasonable way to remove the heat from this debate. I think it is fair to say that Mr Kerr thought that we had reached agreement whereby the government would be able to cap and queue the aged parent category but not proceed with the other capping arrangements in terms of spouses and children. We do have a responsibility for caring for our elderly parents. That is one we should respect. The opposition has, in discussions between the minister and Mr Kerr, come to what we think is an arrangement whereby the government would proceed with one, but we will oppose the introduction of capping and killing, particularly killing, when it comes to the rest of the family, spouses and children.

I could go on at length in respect of these issues, but I think I should address the issue of the Sex Discrimination Act and the arrangement that was reached there. Senator Stott Despoja talked about that, both today and last week. I think one of the clear objectives of the discussions between the shadow minister and the minister has been to recognise that we really cannot dictate an outcome from our side. We would like to have some influence in terms of the policy that finally gets through this parliament.

Although we have had in principle objection to amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act, the arrangement that was finally reached is one where, at the end of the day, the impact of the government's measures is much less than it would have been had they got what they set out to get, and had what they set out to get went through this parliament. The impact is minimised by the fact that we are not talking here about discrimination as against one sex in terms of the letter of the law, but I do take the point that we need to monitor closely the operation of this law to ensure that, in practice, women are not affected and disadvantaged in the way that some people have feared.

Once again, I think the full impact of the overall operation of this exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act that the government is seeking needs to be closely monitored—and I am sure it will be—to ensure that people are not disadvantaged in the way that many witnesses before the Senate committee process fear they might be.

We are talking here of a proposal which the government has agreed to tone down—to radically reduce the cohabitation period from two years to one year. As a consequence of that government undertaking to reduce the cohabitation period from two years to one year, the opposition has felt able to support the amendment to the Sex Discrimination Act in the belief that the legislation would not in practice have the negative effect that has been feared.

I turn finally to the question of citizenship. In this particular area we have been on the record as saying that the opposition could give in principle support for the measure but that we did have concerns about its open‐endedness in respect of the proposed citizenship provisions and about the capacity to make some people, particularly children, stateless as a consequence.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition welcomes the supplementary explanatory memorandum, which Minister Ruddock has tabled in the House. It is one that was brought forward at the opposition's request. It clarifies what the government means by its action. The government intends to act in cases where there is an intention to defraud. That being the trigger point in terms of implementation of the amendments to the citizenship provisions, it is clear that the opposition can support the government with respect to amendments that cover citizenship.

We have concerns about the question of statelessness. A person, by accepting Australian citizenship, may have found themself to be without citizenship of their former country. There is a capacity under these provisions that, maybe 20 or 30 years later, they might even lose Australian citizenship. This question needs to be addressed. There are international conventions in place to avoid persons becoming stateless. Minister Ruddock was asked in the House to come back to parliament on this issue when the bill came before the Senate. We would like to hear something of the government's position in respect of this before we take a vote on this particular proposal.

There have been extensive discussions in the last few weeks in respect of this legislation. The government has amended the legislation quite substantially. As a consequence of this, I think we will find much more of it getting through the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —While this legislation merges fees so that there is a single application fee for immigrants to Australia, it has the massive impact of limiting the number of spouse, aged parent and dependent children visas by ministerial discretion. This is what the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) himself calls `cap and kill' when referring to the queues of people waiting to come into Australia. The term could also adequately refer to the aspirations of people wanting to join their families under sometimes very emotive and distressing circumstances. This legislation also enables the minister to prescribe a two‐year cohabitation period in respect of applicants who apply offshore for migration on the basis of a de facto or inter dependency relationship with an Australian citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this legislation is that it is really scapegoating immigrants to this country on the altar of a change in direction by the government with regard to immigration policy. This is in response to well‐versed concerns about multicultural Australia, about the make‐up of this country and about unemployment in the country. The problem with the response the government is making is that the rich and powerful, and their families, will be able to get to the front of the queue. Those who are not in that position and who are wanting to be united with their families will stay out, in many cases, under this new legislation.

By keeping migrants from accessing benefits in times of hardship—we have seen that legislation recently in this place—the government began a process of divisiveness in the community, I believe. This legislation accentuates that process. It is a divisiveness which says that it is going to be more difficult than it was in the past, under a policy that most Australians were relaxed about, for people to come to this country, not least those with aspirations for family reunion. When they do get here, it is going to be more difficult for them to survive. The hardship is put before the barrier and after the barrier.

When you look into the reasons behind this legislation, you will find that there is a favouritism emerging towards the rich, particularly business migrants. For $12,500, a rich person can enter into the race to come into Australia, while family reunions are being so-called capped and killed. There is no doubt, whatever figure is put on the amount required for business immigrants, that in relation to whether or not you can get into this country we are going more towards a policy of `it depends on what you've got, not what your relationships are or what your need is'. The proposed amendments are going to make coming to Australia more difficult for the spouses, children and aged parents of people already here.

There is also the real effort here to make it more difficult for people who are not married to come into the country. There is an inevi table effort to separate those who have undertaken the marriage process to come into the country from those who have equally legitimate relationships—so-called de facto or interdependent relationships. There is a separation of the requirements instead of a convergence, as we have seen in recent years.

Interdependent relationships can be seen as a grab bag, but they do include people who have a great reliance upon each other for one reason or another. I am told that a majority of these people are in same sex relationships. The question that immediately arises is: why do those people find that there are more onerous conditions placed on them to come into the country? I would have thought we were past the age of discriminating on those grounds. Yet this legislation has a very strong tenor of increased discrimination on those grounds.

It is remarkable that the government, in tightening the rules in respect of people in heterosexual de facto relationships, is chipping away at the sex discrimination legislation. It is certainly recreating some of the difficulties that partners in a heterosexual de facto relationship have experienced in the past. The barrier is going to be higher for them than it is for people who have married.

So, for those reasons, the bill is not one that I find acceptable. It is going to save the government some money—$5 million this year and $19 million next year. But that, of itself, is neither here nor there. I think the government itself would say that—although any measure that saves it money and cuts down on the public welfare bill seems to it to be a welcome measure, whatever the consequences.

There are very strong arguments as to why this legislation should not be accepted as it is. There will be amendments seeking to improve it. But, ultimately, I have to say that we would be better staying with the legislation we have. We would be better trying to maintain the current level of immigration. The temporary increase in applications on the basis of family reunion have resulted because of the extra people, particularly young people, who stayed in this country as a result of the Tiananmen Square massacre and because of the fears that 10,000 Australians had about returning to China at that time.

The arguments for this legislation are weak. They echo arguments of the past. The arguments against it are strong and humanitarian. They are under the banner of `a fair go for all' and across the doormat of `welcome' to this country, particularly for those who have a humanitarian need or are in distressing circumstances. The government is taking the wrong direction with this legislation. It can be patched up, it can be ameliorated, but it would be better if it were not here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Had the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 come on for debate at the end of last year, I suspect the second reading debate the chamber is taking part in now would have been completely and utterly different. I make that point—and make it very strongly—not to score any political points but merely to put on the record the fact that the major players in the parliament on matters to do with immigration have actually had the opportunity to sit down and talk and reach some understanding and agreement about where we go.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to put a bit history of the bill on the record and, in doing so, to make a point about the workload that is from time to time imposed upon committees of the parliament. It has been mentioned by previous speakers in this second reading debate that this bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report in the latter part of last year. That committee, under the then chairmanship of Senator Ellison, undertook that inquiry and reported only a matter of days after its original reporting date.

That happened at a time when the Senate was sitting for four weeks continuously. Prior to that we had what was supposed to be, and what people outside see as, a one-week break from the parliament when parliamentarians do not do anything. Before that we had two weeks of sitting. So, out of seven weeks, the parliament sat for six weeks. In the seventh week, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee had to address itself to matters contained in this bill.

BREAK.PARA: That happened way back in November last year. Definitely there was a sense of urgency about the matter, but here we are in March 1997 actually debating it. As one of the players in the committee at that time, I sometimes wonder about the schedules and time frames that we are asked to work under from time to time. That was brought to mind in a different reference that is before the same committee. We discussed that issue at length this morning after quite elaborate inquiry and consultation with the community. But that is something for a different debate. I put on the record the sorts of time frames under which Senate committees are required to report and present their deliberations.

It is also worth noting that, when the committee's report was presented to the parliament, the bill that was before the committee did not receive unanimous support of committee members and indeed the participating members of the committee. Despite the attractiveness of it, I will not try to score cheap political points about my colleagues on the committee, some of whom who signed the minority report now find themselves, as a result of the negotiations that have taken place between the government, the opposition and indeed the Democrats—I understand they, too, were involved in them—agreeing to some changes. Some changes have satisfied some of the concerns some members who signed the minority report have, including one of the previous speakers, Senator Stott Despoja.

It is on the record that we can—I think this is a welcome approach—with maturity, sit down and talk about these things. The government and the opposition certainly sat down and talked about them after an extensive debate in the House of Representatives just before parliament rose for the Christmas break. In preparing for this contribution this afternoon it had been my intention to refer to some government members' comments in that debate. However, to do that now might bring further division into this debate, and I do not believe that anybody in the Australian community needs further divisive debate on immigration in this country. There are too many players out there seeking and playing a spoiling role in the affairs of this country and unfortunately using the immigration debate and migrants to fuel their own points of view. I do not believe they are operating for the benefit of Australia in offering those views to the community.

We are debating Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and not indeed, as Senator Stott Despoja mentioned, population or population issues per se. Certainly this bill relates to populations, and she acknowledged that my party, the Australian Labor Party, embarked on a debate about population issues. It is not all that recently that we did embark on that debate. It has been the subject of debate within the parliamentary party ever since I became a member of this parliament and it is a debate which I wholeheartedly welcome and have participated in. I welcome the enhanced measures that the current spokesperson for my party has introduced to it in recent months.

This debate is ongoing, and I hope that it can be much more constructive than some of the debates we have had surrounding immigration. I think that, as the debate progresses, people in our community and indeed our parliament will seek to play a spoiling role on the issue of population just as they have on the issue of migration. It is very unfortunate that many of the people who have played that spoiling role are indeed migrants who have forgotten that they have been blessed with the opportunity of coming here. Maybe it was not their decision; it may have been a parental decision. Nevertheless, they are the ones taking advantage of the fact that Australia is an open society that does allow and indeed invites migrants into its community.

Being able to migrate to a country such as Australia is a very great privilege. I am one of the beneficiaries and one of the people who have taken a very strong line on immigration. I have done so in the time I have been in this parliament and certainly before I entered parliament. I, like many others in this chamber and the parliament, support a migration program. In doing so, we are supporting—I acknowledge this—in part a population issue, although migration and migration legislation are not the exact place to start with it.

I have been active in the area of migration legislation since I entered parliament. Because of that, and because of particularly my enhanced activity in immigration debates in recent years, I was very surprised when the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) made the comment in his second reading speech to this bill that `Labor had allowed immigration to get seriously out of control'. When we look objectively at the facts, we see they do not stand up to that statement the minister made in his second reading speech. The facts just do not stand up at all when we analyse them. Indeed, the minister, by his own words, contradicted himself. When he offered the statistics he drew attention to the fact that what was being proposed for this current financial year in the intake of migrants matched pretty neatly and closely what had happened in the latter years of the Labor Party administration.

So I think comments such as `Labor has allowed immigration to get seriously out of control' should not be made by any minister who claims to be a responsible minister for immigration. I hope that the minister notes the fact that he has not sought to substantiate those claims and that he should take the opportunity to refute and back away from remarks like that. In the current climate in this country, where some people are trying to whip up a racist debate, comments such as the one the minister made do not help the situation at all. He should be adopting a much more constructive and responsible role in parliamentary utterances rather than making comments such as the one he made.

I want to make a few points on the matters currently under issue in the bill and the arrangements and understandings that have been reached between the government and other parties in the Senate. My colleague Senator Bolkus in his contribution canvassed the issues very thoroughly. I am not going to use all of the time allocated to me in this debate this afternoon to further those comments. I think the comments stand on the record to speak for themselves. However, I am disappointed with the position the Austral ian Democrats have taken on the issue of `cap and kill'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they are working—don't go too heavy.

—I will not go too heavy. I was very pleased to have an understanding prior to this debate and indeed last week of what the Democrats' position was on that issue, because it certainly was one of the matters that were the subject of intense negotiations between the parties in recent weeks. When I heard Senator Stott Despoja on her feet making her comments that the Democrats' support would go to the government when it came to a vote on the matters, I was disappointed. But, if there are further issues being debated, I think the safest thing for me to do would be to pass over this issue and perhaps come back to it if necessary during the committee stage of the bill.

BREAK.PARA: One final point I want to make with regard to the bill, and drawing attention to the committee's report of December last year in the—
Senator Cooney interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, indeed it is No. 3, Senator Cooney. The minority report by a number of senators, including me, drew attention to the exemption of the Migration Act from the Sex Discrimination Act. We had some real concerns about that which we itemised on the third page of the minority report. We did draw attention to that.

BREAK.PARA: The other objection we have is that it would discriminate against nationals from countries where it is not possible to obtain a divorce, such as Irish nationals. I am very pleased to record that the passage of time has caught up with that issue. Only last week it became lawful in the Republic of Ireland for Irish nationals to get a divorce. So if you wait long enough it will happen. I hope, in the passage of this bill through the second reading stage and the committee stage, we will record progress such as I have just drawn attention to in Ireland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 3 of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996, if enacted, would provide subordinate law makers with the ability to set criteria—different from those they set for a married person—for a de facto spouse to meet before he or she obtains a visa. That people have a genuine personal and persisting commitment to each other can often be more readily demonstrated when they are married than when they are in a de facto relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidentiary issues involved in proving the two relationships are distinct, and accordingly there is a good reason for having discrete tests for each of them. But it is not good enough to justify the passing into law of proposed section 507 of the Migration Act 1958 as set out in schedule 3, because to do so would empower the makers of subordinate legislation to override the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. Were this to happen, it would place too great a strain on the meagre mechanisms that presently exist to protect human rights in Australia.

The certainty that fairness permeates its social institutions, that everyone is equal before the law and that fundamental rights are held inviolable is essential to a decent society. To ensure this certainty some countries—for example, the United States of America and Canada—have a bill of rights. Australia does not. Many of its people consider it should have one. Others hold the contrary view and maintain that the common law, appropriate conventions and discrete statutory provisions are the best safeguards for the liberties and entitlements of its citizens. In any event, most Australians believe that there must be effective mechanisms in place to enable them to vindicate their civil rights.

The Commonwealth parliament has responded to this belief by enacting a limited but vital body of legislation. Included in this are the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992. So essential are these to the wellbeing of the community that their operation should be suspended, if ever, in only the most exceptional circumstances. No such circumstances exist to justify the passing of schedule 3 of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996.

If we as federal parliamentarians pass proposed section 507 as set out in schedule 3, we demonstrate not only our readiness to interdict the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act ourselves but also our willingness to delegate that power to the makers of subordinate legislation. This bodes ill for the strength and standing of Australia's human rights law. There is much to be worried about where the Commonwealth parliament is prepared to see the operation of one of its own civil liberty statutes suspended to make it easier for government to administer applications for visas.

What vice does schedule 3 seek to remedy? How many migrants are coming to Australia under the guise of being de facto spouses when in fact they are not? Indeed, how many people come here under that description in any event? How difficult is it for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to establish whether a relevant person is or is not a de facto spouse? Whatever the answers to these questions, they are most unlikely to justify what is, in effect, either the rescission of human rights legislation or the delegation of the power to do so to subordinate law makers.

A seemingly good reason is often advanced to legitimise the setting aside of civil liberties. But each time that happens the quality of Australia's regime for protecting human rights is put at risk. This is the case in the present instance where, no doubt with the best of intentions, the government seeks to prevent the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act in certain circumstances. It wants to render ineffective legislation the purpose of which is to further people's rights and liberties. This is hardly a good thing.

Although proposed section 507 may make good administrative sense, the legislature should not embrace it. Over a period parliament can, for a succession of reasons, each of which appears compelling at the time it arises, whittle away the regime of civil rights in Australia. The problem with this legislation is that it tries to do something that seems eminently sensible: that is, provide for a position where a stable relationship can be proved, but in different ways. In one case it can be proved by producing a marriage certificate, and in another case by introducing other evidence. People say, `Look, that is a fairly sensible thing to do,' and so it would seem. But the consequences of doing that, as proposed section 507 says, is that provision has to be made to set aside the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 in so far as it would interfere with the making of these regulations.

I think there are some real problems that we as a parliament face at the moment. We had a debate earlier in the day about the position of the High Court and where it enters into the field that people allege is a legislative field. They say it should not do that: that it should keep out of that field; that we as parliamentarians should be the only ones to legislate. Our position in saying that would be much better if we were to be more jealous, I think, of issues of human rights. In this case it is not a dramatic attempt to suborn the human liberties that we enjoy. But it is, nevertheless, an instance where for what is, no doubt, seen as a good reason, but is an insufficient reason, this act is set aside.

The message that goes out is that we would suspend the Sex Discrimination Act fairly readily if we thought there was a need. If we are ready to do that, then why have the act at all? Perhaps we ought to leave our civil rights to the attention of the common law—in other words, the common law‐maker; the court system, at the pinnacle of which is the High Court. Perhaps the High Court has got a greater sense of justice—a `feel' for those rights that we all consider are the rights any decent society should enjoy. I think that this particular provision is an occasion when we should pause and work out what we are doing. I also would like to comment on schedule 4. There are some concerns with that, but I think I will leave that to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to contribute briefly to this debate. I feel my colleague, Senator Cooney, has raised the area of concern that I have with this bill. I first of all would like to put on the public record that it concerns me that the government has given a number of indications, in respect of some of the elements that are contained in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996, that it is responding to some of the myths and prejudices that have come out in the past year's race debate. While I acknowledge that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) and the shadow minister for immigration, Mr Duncan Kerr, have negotiated and that some of the impacts are less—of course, compromise is always welcome—nevertheless, I have grave concerns about meddling with the Sex Discrimination Act. If it is good enough to tinker with the Sex Discrimination Act in this instance, it sets a precedent. This government can ill afford a precedent in this area. Over the last 12 months there have been too many occasions when the government has not maintained its commitment in regard to equal opportunity and gender issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to put on the record the view of the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Chris Sidoti, who said the commission has major concerns with the amendments proposed in schedule 3. Schedule 3 represents a significant withdrawal from the lawful commitment made by Australia in the ratification of the convention on the elimination of all forms of sex discrimination, as implemented through the Sex Discrimination Act. The first part of schedule 3 proposes the insertion of a section in the Migration Act. The insertion of this section would permit differentiation between applicants for immigration on the basis of de facto or de jure relationships, according to the law's status. The commission is most concerned that the introduction of this kind of discrimination represents a significant retreat from the commitment made in the enactment of the Sex Discrimination Act that there should be no discrimination on the basis of marital status.

Australian law has dealt for some time with the criteria for the acceptance of the existence of a genuine de facto relationship. Those criteria have been spelt out most particularly in social security law. They have also been enacted in the past and developed in relation to immigration law. As a non‐lawyer, I do not know whether this criteria will be challenged at some stage. The immigration department has had to contend with a number of challenges over the years. Whether or not this could be challenged is something that we will have to wait and see, I suppose.

It is not just the Human Rights Commissioner. The Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists also commented saying that the Sex Discrimination Act is a piece of fundamental human rights legislation. By admitting the need for a piece of legislation to be exempted from the operation of a law, such as the Sex Discrimination Act, the government is admitting the legislation it proposes is discriminatory and breaches Australia's international undertakings. The Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists sees no reason why this should be done.

If, indeed, it is the policy of the government to resile generally from the principles contained in the Sex Discrimination Act, then it should openly announce such a policy and seek to amend the act generally. I do not even want to suggest that option. I am too concerned that it could in fact be somewhere on the government's agenda. Senator Cooney, in his usual way, was very generous in his comments and said that probably the government had the best of intentions in setting this requirement for two years. Of course it has been renegotiated to a one‐year cohabitation period.

Having worked as minister assisting in the areas of both the status of women and immigration, I would concede that the department of immigration has always tried to assist women in relationships to ensure that those relationships are genuine, that those relationships will be particularly in the woman's best interest. I am looking at a number of fairly controversial discussions that have been taking place over a number of years now in relation to Filipino relationships.

The goal of the immigration department was to give women every opportunity to ensure that the relationship was as it seemed and was not going to result in the woman regretting that she had made such a choice. So there are some reasons for setting a period. It used to be six months. I understand it was not legally binding. It was simply that the department set that as a period to be demonstrated as the cohabitation period. Senator Stott Despoja said that she was concerned about violent relationships. There can be a need for certain protective measures in this regard. So I can accept some of Senator Cooney's comments about best intentions.

But if we have been operating for a number of years with a six-month period seen as mandatory, why change? Why do we have to enshrine it in legislation, particularly when it means going against the provisions of the sex discrimination legislation? I know that we have an indication from the minister that it will be closely monitored. There will be exemptions but it is the principle of changing the compliance of the migration legislation with the sex discrimination legislation that sets a precedent. I think that is a very risky precedent.

On perhaps a lighter note, it interesting to note the double standards that apply when we talk about family reunion as distinct from business migration. We seem to be at pains to set a period of time in which the spouse can indicate a stable relationship but we do not do that for business, do we? We do not have any period of time in which business has to indicate that it is in fact a stable reputable business. We do not have a two‐year period. I see an officer is nodding. I would be interested at a later stage in this debate to compare how we treat family reunions with how we treat business. It seems to me that some pretty creative business practices can get past and those practices will continue in this country.

We do not adopt the same standards of ensuring stability in the business community as we are insisting on in terms of establishing appropriate relationships. Also the obvious double standard is that if we did that domestically, if one had to prove stability in a relationship to proceed in any number of areas domestically, would it not be interesting? I did want to put on the record my concern.

I note that Senator Newman now has a parliamentary advisory committee looking at how Australian women get their message through. I would like to recommend to Senator Newman that she take a close look at the processes of this government in terms of how the Office of the Status of Women is able to report on the impact of government decision making on women. The Office of the Status of Women is very poorly resourced at the moment. It is understaffed and has recently lost its senior officer.

It is quite clear that this particular amendment bill, and I am speaking specifically of schedule 3, seems to have got past. It certainly cannot have had any input from the Office of the Status of Women. I cannot believe that the Office of the Status of Women would have recommended setting aside the fundamental principles of the Sex Discrimination Act. If that is the case, I would certainly like to see the evidence.

Whatever agreements have been negotiated—and when you are in opposition you do have to negotiate and get the best of a bad situation—I think the fundamental principle of tinkering with the Sex Discrimination Act, setting aside the Sex Discrimination Act, is like what is being recommended in relation to race discrimination in the government's response to the Wik decision. It sets a very bad precedent.

In considering this bill, we should keep that very much to the fore. Whatever inevitably goes through this chamber, we must insist that community, government and the opposition monitor the impact to ensure that there is not the kind of discrimination that the Sex Discrimination Act is there to protect us from.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks in relation to some of the comments that have been made, particularly in the area of schedule 2 and in relation to the mechanisms by which it is proposed in these migration bills that the government could deal with migrants in certain categories, most particularly aged parents and spouses. These bills set out to create a more flexible regime for dealing with applications than is currently available.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a mechanism—there has been for a long time—by which it is possible to cap the number of migrants in particular categories. That is known as the cap and terminate mechanism. For the benefit of honourable senators, let me explain how that works. Where a cap has been set in a particular category, when that cap is reached all applica tions are terminated. That means that those applications have to be made again.

It is within the discretion of the minister under the cap and terminate procedure to choose to refund the application money, but the minister is not obliged to refund the application money. I think it would be very peculiar if a minister chose not to refund the application money, but there may be particular circumstances where that would be the case.

The essence of the cap and terminate mechanism is that the application is dead. What we are seeking to do in this bill is to introduce cap and queue mechanisms. The difference between cap and queue and cap and terminate is simply this: under cap and queue, applications which are not accepted because the cap has been reached get carried over into the following year and they get dealt with at the top of the queue in the following year. That means that a person who meets the criteria but fails to get accepted or fails to get the visa issued because the cap has already been reached keeps their place in the queue relative to people who apply in the following year. That is very important.

Under the cap and terminate mechanism, there is no guarantee that somebody who meets the criteria but fails because the cap has already been reached will be dealt with at the top of the queue in the next year. It may well be that there is a flood of people at the beginning of the next financial year and that flood of people ensures that the bona fide applicant who failed to get accepted because of the cap the previous year does not get accepted in the second year. That is the danger of the cap and terminate mechanism.

What the government is seeking to do in schedule 2 is quite simply say, `We want a mechanism that is simpler and we want a mechanism that is fairer to the applicant.' There is the possibility that schedule 2 may be deleted by amendment during the committee stage. I am merely rising at this point in time to say to honourable senators who have some concerns about capping generally that this is not the place to address those concerns. The cap and terminate mechanism is already in place. It was in place during the life of the previous government. So I say to those who have an argument about capping: this is not the place to have the argument.

Those who want to ensure fairness for applicants and want to ensure a system that recognises that people who fail to get in simply because of the cap in one year should be given some priority of assessment the following year must support schedule 2 as it exists in this bill. A failure to support schedule 2 will mean that the government will be forced very reluctantly to utilise the cap and terminate mechanism if applications in certain categories exceed the target. The government does not want to do that.

This bill is not, in so far as schedule 2 is concerned, a sign of an authoritarian, dictatorial or harsh government. Schedule 2 is part of a commitment by this government to make the mechanisms for dealing with migration applications fairer, simpler and more reasonable. It would be an enormous shame if the Senate, to make some sort of other ideological point, were to knock back a more reasonable, flexible and fairer system as is proposed in schedule 2 of this bill.

I know as I speak that there are honourable senators from a number of parties who are undecided as to how schedule 2 should be dealt with. It has been suggested by the opposition that schedule 2 should be deleted in its entirety. I am rising at this late point in the debate to argue as forcefully as I can that honourable senators wanting to see a fair processing of applications should support schedule 2 as it stands or at least support schedule 2 in part if they believe that parts of it should be dealt with.

I firmly believe that, if any honourable senator believes that the cap and queue mechanism should apply to, for example, aged parents, then that logic also flows through that it should also apply to spouses. It would be wrong to suggest that a fair mechanism should apply in one category and not in another. Acceptance of it in one category means that you should accept the principle in the other categories for which schedule 2 seeks application.

In conclusion, I beg honourable senators who are undecided as to how they will vote on schedule 2 to consider, between now and the vote in the committee stage, the fact that voting against schedule 2 makes the system more harsh, and that this bill is part of a package of reform aimed at making the system less harsh and more flexible. For that reason, I beg honourable senators to support the bill and schedule 2 as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their consideration of this package of legislation. In particular, I thank Senators Stott Despoja, Bolkus, Brown, Cooney, McKiernan, Reynolds and O'Chee for their contributions to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The package of bills now before the chamber is designed to achieve several important policy initiatives which were outlined in the second reading speeches. Senator Kemp, in a statement to the Senate on behalf of the government, announced how we intend to pursue regulations relating to the cohabitation requirement for de factos, and the English education charge. There is no need to repeat those statements here, other than to note Senator Bolkus's advice that the opposition will support schedules 1, vis-a-vis visa charges, and 3, vis-a-vis the cohabitation requirement, of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) on the basis of those understandings and explanations.

I am also advised that the opposition will be supporting schedule 4, vis-a-vis deprivation of citizenship, subject to clarification about the issue of statelessness. I will come to that issue later, and I certainly can reassure Senator Bolkus on that matter.

I would make particular reference to the measures contained in the No. 3 bill relating to placing limits on visas. The government is determined to restore balance in the migration program in 1996-97 and future years. We are doing this through an integrated, sensible and reasonable range of measures which include placing limits on the number of visas which may be issued in some categories.

The purpose of the capping amendments which are before the Senate is to enable government to manage all parts of the migration program in a manner that would minimise inconvenience to applicants and reduce costs and inefficiencies. I note that Senator Stott Despoja has indicated that the Democrats will be supporting all these measures, which are contained in schedule 2 of the bill. I welcome that support and trust it will be forthcoming, particularly given the policy commitments of the Democrats to lower migration levels.

The government obviously will be opposing the opposition's amendment which would omit schedule 2. As senators would be aware, the bill itself does not seek to specify the actual limits on the number of visas issued to spouses, dependent children or aged parents in any one year. In fact, the government can already use the existing cap and terminate provisions of the act in respect of spouses, dependent children and aged parents.

However, use of these powers means that, once a cap is reached, all outstanding applications are taken not to have been made. This means that affected applicants must be contacted, advised of the impact of the decision and refunded their fees. If those applicants still wish to continue to seek to migrate to Australia, they will have to reapply in the new year with a new form and a new application fee. Consideration of their applications would then start afresh.

The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, has made it plain that in future if he must use the existing cap and terminate powers to deliver a balanced migration program he will do so. What this bill seeks to do is to ensure that, if there are insufficient places compared to demand, the length of time applicants have to wait for a visa and any inconvenience associated with the process are minimised. The amendments would enable the government to establish an orderly queue for migration to Australia in all migration classes such that inconvenience to applicants would be minimised.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fairer system.

—As Senator O'Chee says, it is a fairer system. Under the arrangements we propose, once a cap is reached, processing would continue, and those applicants who reach visa grant stage would be queued for visa grant in the next program year when places become available. The length of time that applicants wait may be only a few weeks, depending on demand and the number of places that become available.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the provisions in schedule 4 of the bill relating to Australian citizenship, I note that some concerns have been raised regarding statelessness. I wish to emphasise to honourable senators that the power to deprive a person of Australian citizenship is a discretionary power which may only be exercised if it would be contrary to the public interest for the person to remain a citizen. Honourable senators are assured that statelessness is one factor that will continue to be taken into account in exercising the discretion of whether or not to deprive a person of Australian citizenship. The power is therefore exercised sparingly and only in appropriate cases.

I can also inform the Senate that the government has been advised that the provisions of schedule 4 are not contrary to Australia's obligations at international law. Indeed, the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness provides that a person may be deprived of a nationality which was obtained by misrepresentation or fraud. I thank all senators for their contributions to this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1996
The bill.

—I see the schedule as well. The schedule has listed on top of the agenda `government schedule 1'. —Minister, I think you will find that I was looking at the schedule. If we move to government amendments 1 and 2, they do relate to the Immigration (Education) Charge Act.
