SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Title, page 1, (line 3), after " 1971 , ", insert "the Immigration (Education) Charge Act 1992 ,".
(2) Schedule 1, page 4 (after line 28), after clause 17, insert:
After "1993", insert "and before the commencement of the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Act 1996 ".
Insert:

PARA.TAB: (aa) any visa application fee payable in relation to the application has been paid before the commencement of the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Act 1996 ; and

SPEECH.PARA: There are quite a few points that I want to make with respect to these amendments. I think I had better put these on the record quickly. As I have said, the package of bills was designed to achieve several important policy initiatives. They have already been outlined. The government has decided not to proceed at this time with its planned changes to the existing English education charge. The government has also decided to address concerns raised by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in relation to aspects of the proposed exemption of the Sex Discrimination Act. As a result of these decisions, the government is now moving three amendments, of which we are dealing with the first two. We will not be proceeding with the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill.

I would like to bring to the attention of honourable senators my only discrepancy between the order of the amendments and the order in which they appear in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. This discrepancy only became apparent after the explanatory memorandum had been printed and lodged with the Table Office. The first amendment—that is, item 3 in the explanatory memorandum—changes the long title of this bill. This is consequential to the second amendment and is purely technical in nature.

The second amendment—that is, item 1 in the explanatory memorandum—concerns the mechanism for introducing the proposed visa application charge. The Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill 1996 introduces a single visa application charge to replace the existing complicated system of visa application fees, the health services charge and the English education charge. This new charge will include a component equivalent to the current English education charge, a charge which is only paid by some migrants who do not have functional English. Payment of this charge entitles a person to up to 510 hours of English language tuition.

Under existing legislation and subject to an indexation formula, the maximum amount of English education charge is $4,405, a figure which is well short of the current full cost recovery figure of $5,500. The government announced in the 1996-97 budget that it would move to amend the Immigration (Education) Charge Act 1992 to increase the ceiling for the maximum of the charge payable under the regulations to $5,500. At the same time the government moved to amend the regulations to remove concessional rates of charge that were payable by some migrants. Those regulations were disallowed by the Senate on 7 November 1996. It is apparent therefore that a majority of senators do not currently support increased charges for English language tuition or the removal of concessional rates. Accordingly, the government has decided at this time not to pursue the proposed increases in English education charge, even though this creates a greater burden on the Australian taxpayer.

With the action now proposed by the government, the amount of the English education charge will remain at the same level as at 1 January this year, subject to any changes flowing from the indexation procedure that has been in place for some years. In view of this, the government will not now be proceeding with the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill. This means that visa applications that are made before the commencement of the Migration (Visa Application) Charge Bill will be subject to the existing legislative provisions for calculation of the English education charge. Visa applications that are made after commencement of the visa application charge will, of course, be subject to a new charge instead of the existing charges. The new charge will contain a component that is based on lack of English language proficiency.

Consistent with the government's decision not to increase the English education charge above current levels at this stage, the component of the visa application charge that corresponds to the English education charge will be set by regulation at the same level as applied at 1 January this year. That will also include maintaining the concessions that applied on that date. The amendments proposed by the government ensure that people who apply for permanent visas after the introduction of the visa application charge will only pay the new charge and that people who are already liable to pay the existing English education charge will not have to pay the visa application charge.

The two items in the second amendment are identical to items 1 and 2 of the schedule to the Immigration (Education) Charge Amendment Bill, the bill we are not now proceeding with. These items are largely technical in nature and are designed to prevent the possibility of double liability for both the English education charge and the visa application charge. No-one who has made a valid visa application within the meaning of the Migration Act before the commencement of the visa application charge will have to pay a visa application charge and no-one who makes a valid visa application after that date will be liable for the English education charge.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, item 19, page 5 (line 11), omit "A non‐citizen", substitute "Subject to section 45AA, a non‐citizen".
(2) Schedule 1, item 19, page 5 (after line 13), after section 45A, insert:
(1) A non‐citizen who makes an application for a refugee and humanitarian class of visa is exempt from liability to pay visa application charge in respect of that application.

(2) A person who makes an application for a visa and who is an immediate family member of a person who is the holder of a refugee and humanitarian class of visa is exempt from liability to pay visa application charges in respect of that application

PARA.TAB: In this section:
immediate family member of a person includes:
(a) a spouse of the person; and
(b) a dependent child, adult child, parent, grandparent, grandchild or sibling of the person or of a spouse of the person;
spouse includes a defacto spouse or an interdependent partner.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, item 19 page 6 (line 13), after "make", insert "further".
I draw the committee's attention to the fact that the amendments circulated in the chamber said `Schedule 1, item 18,' when they should read `Schedule 1, item 19'.

The aim of these amendments is to take from the regulations and place into the legislation the government's proposal that people who are in the refugee and humanitarian categories will not be faced with the visa fees. It is an amendment to simply put that into the legislation while we are here in committee. I would also draw the committee's attention to the definition of `spouse' at the end of the amendment which states:
. . . spouse includes a defacto spouse or an interdependent partner.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are quite happy to support these amendments. It is in line with our policy which gives priority to refugee and humanitarian cases. But I ask the minister: are these groups not already exempt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In comment on that, I could say that the bill is seeking to provide enabling legislation and not dealing with particular categories. That is the bill we are dealing with. As a general principle, fees are not payable, as Senator Stott Despoja says, by applicants in the refugee and humanitarian categories. This bill does not affect that. However, for reasons of integrity and simplicity of the overall scheme, we oppose the program. The bottom line is that Senator Stott Despoja is right: as a general principle, people do not pay fees. For that reason we oppose this. It is simply going to complicate matters.

—The opposition has just been given Senator Brown's amendments and we are looking very closely at them. One aspect we are looking at is that, obviously, they embody in legislation what otherwise the parliament has the capacity to protect in being able to deny regulations. It has been suggested to me that maybe the definition of `immediate family member' in this amendment is a bit broader than what is currently used in other parts of the act. I wonder if the minister or her advisers can help us on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I am advised that the term `immediate family member' generally means spouse or dependent child. You can see that this definition quite markedly extends that meaning quite dramatically from spouse and dependent children to include an adult child, parent, grandparent, grandchild, sibling and so on. So you are quite right. This definition is at odds with the general definitions in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The principle is one that the opposition has always supported in order to exclude refugees and humanitarian entrants from some of these changes that the government has proposed. Given that the amendments are at a late stage and there are those questions of definition of `family member' and so on, we would rather continue with the situation where the parliament has capacity to reject any such fees, if and when the government chooses to bowl them up, rather than to be prescriptive at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably something we can look at in terms of future legislation. It is something we need to have a close look at because the issue of the definition of `immediate family members' is not an easy one. It does change from background to background, culture to culture. It is important for us to ensure that we do not create a precedent here that we have not foreseen the consequences of. We are attracted to the principle, but not attracted to the legislation at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the consequences are foreseeable in that they are wholly good as far as we are concerned. Senator Bolkus has said that we can deal with this maybe by looking at government regulations further down the line. The problem there is that we cannot regulate. I can amend the legislation here and now, but I cannot regulate later down the line to add to or change the import of the legislation. So this is the one chance the Greens have of giving the definition we have, to include within the ambit of `immediate family members' those persons who have been outlined, including grandparents and siblings, for goodness' sake.

SPEECH.PARA: If they are not immediate family, who is? If that is not in the definition of immediate family, the words `immediate family' need changing or the definition needs changing. It seems that it is so proscriptive that it belies the term `immediate family' if these people are not included. One should stick to the term `spouse or child' if that is all that one means by immediate family, because grandparent, grandchild and siblings are commonly thought of as immediate family. They are immediate in every sense of the word of relationship as far as the public is concerned. However, that being the case, I can see that we are not going to get support from the major parties on this matter. I am glad that I brought it up because it was an effort to weight things a little bit in the opposite direction from the one which the government is taking overall with immigration policy.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing now with the opposition's proposal that schedule 2 be opposed. The opposition has some very strong views about this particular proposal put by the government. These views relate to what could probably best be described as two particular points. First of all, the overall impact of schedule 2 will be to enable the minister—not by regulation and in no way accountable to the parliament but by a notice in the Gazette —to have the unfettered power to cap and kill off applications in those areas of close family.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking here of spouse, dependent child and aged parent visas. It is important for us that any power that is exercised in this area is one that is exercised under the scrutiny of the parliament and with accountability to it. It is also important for us to ensure that families are not kept separate because of an arbitrary unaccountable exercise of power by way of gazette by government ministers.

As I said earlier, the opposition was prepared to enter into an arrangement with the government to allow the government to be able to cap and queue in respect of aged parents. We had introduced a number of measures in government to try to get the balance right in respect of aged parents. We could see that the government was insistent on trying to reduce the number of entrants in the family program and we were prepared to contemplate capping and queuing in respect of aged parents.

The government, I am informed, was prepared to contemplate dropping off their proposals in this area as they affected spouses and dependent children. I think that would have been a fair outcome in the circumstances, although one in principle that would have still caused problems in respect of aged parents. That was the proposal that was around the place, one that in a sense was agreeable to the government. But I am told that the government is not agreeing to that and now it wants to test this particular proposal over schedule 2 on the floor of the Senate. I am further advised that, if in fact schedule 2 does not survive in this place, the government will look at further proposals in the House of Representatives which would, in effect, reflect the spirit of the discussions that have been taking place between the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, and the opposition spokesperson, Duncan Kerr.

The government is indulging in a bit of a try‐on here. For the government to ask for a power to actually act in this area in a way that involves no accountability at all to the Senate and in a way that would allow the minister to make a decision here to cap and kill by an announcement by notice in the Gazette is something that we should not be in the business of agreeing to. That would be the impact of the amendments in respect of the proposed section 39.

We also, of course, have problems in respect of keeping families separate. The proposals here would give a minister a capacity to keep children from parents and to keep one spouse away from another. Those sorts of interventions by government are totally unsavoury and unhelpful and should not be supported by the parliament. If anything is going to bring the migration program into disrepute, it will be a continuation of the flow of cases—day after day and week after week in the media—of kids who cannot join their parents, or of spouses who cannot join the other spouse. That sort of procession will drag the law into disrepute because that sort of procession is indefensible.

You cannot defend keeping parents separate. The direct impact of these proposals will be that, for instance, some 1,500 spouses a year would be kept separate from their spouse living in Australia and a large number of young children would also be kept separate. In terms of fiancees that would be separated, we are talking of 1,300 offshore, 670 offshore preferential family. In terms of dependants, we are talking about 210 dependent children who would be kept separate from their parents. We are not talking about big numbers here. Let us face it: we are talking about, in the whole scheme of things, something like two or three per cent of the migration program. For a government to be proposing such draconian legislation to fix up something which only needs tinkering with at the edges is something that the opposition cannot support. So the opposition will oppose schedule 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, the Democrats will not be supporting schedule 2 in its current form. We were under the impression that a negotiated settlement—the one that Senator Bolkus referred to—had been reached between the shadow minister and the minister on this issue. I said in the second reading debate that, if the government chose a path that was oppressive or harsh or discriminatory, we would seek to monitor it closely but we would not, as I said in my speech last week, be supporting such wide discretionary powers in relation to the family reunion category.

SPEECH.PARA: So our indication of support for schedule 2 was that a discussion had taken place between the opposition and the government and that a least worst arrangement had been arrived at in relation to the intake of aged parents in the family reunion category. I am sorry that so-called negotiated position has fallen through, because it was a position that the Democrats indicated that they were prepared to support. Obviously, as there are no amendments before us in this regard—and I have had it confirmed from advisers on both sides—there will be no qualification to schedule 2. We felt that the negotiated settlement had, in fact, alleviated some of the harsher measures of the bill. In line with our policy, though, we were still very strongly in favour of family reunions or at least allowing spouses and children—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you want everything, but you also want reduced immigration numbers.

—Minister, we are not discussing numbers. We are talking about how we determine who is coming into the country. I say again that the Democrat policy is not inconsistent in this regard. We recognise, and our policy recognises, a need for a population policy. We also, in relation to immigration, acknowledge that a reduced immigration intake is not an unreasonable policy suggestion. But how we determine those people who come into this country and how they are treated once they are here are matters that are yet to be debated in a fair and appropriate way by this government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats reiterate that we acknowledge that spouses and other people eligible under family reunions, such as children and even aged parents, have a valuable role to play in our society. We believe they value add to our society. We reiterate that we are not in favour of some kind of social engineering in relation to inter‐reunion and immigration intake in this country.

The government's objective that has been touted in relation to schedule 2 is to provide more flexibility and so-called fairness in relation to the system. What I can see from the broad ranging nature of schedule 2 is that it simply offers the minister wide discretionary and unfettered powers, certainly with uncertain scrutiny arrangements. For that reason, all of my colleagues have expressed their concerns regarding the wide discretionary powers that this particular schedule gives the minister.

My colleagues have listened to the debate and have given consideration to the arguments proffered on all sides of the chamber and have decided that the issues are significantly more complex, particularly as they relate to unfettered power for the minister and in many ways abrogate the supervisory role of the parliament.

In relation to the issue of capping and queuing, as opposed to capping and killing, we had some sympathy for the government attempts to try to provide a more compassionate system. But we find that schedule 2 in its current form is too harsh and too oppressive and will not be supported in that form. I again lament the fact that the government apparently is no longer supporting a settlement. I am happy to be corrected on this if there is a different story as to why this has fallen through. Again, we were prepared to support that negotiated settlement at least as one way of alleviating the harshness of schedule 2 in its original form. The Democrats will not support it in its current form. However, we were prepared to support it with the changes to aged parents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise, Senator Stott Despoja, that I was not able, because I was otherwise occupied, to be here for, or listen to, the speech you gave during the second reading debate. As I am advised, during the second reading debate you indicated that you would be supporting schedule 2 and did not make reference to agreed amendments to it. You simply said you would be supporting schedule 2. Is it the case that you now come in and say that you only said that because you thought there were some changes that were going to be made, or did you give that qualification in the second reading debate?

—If you take the in continuation comments that I made today along with the comments that I made on Tuesday in this place, it is clear that the Democrats had concerns in relation to the family reunion category and the consequences of schedule 2. I perhaps should have qualified more strongly; in my comments today I acknowledged the condition on which we were prepared to support the capping and queuing mechanism, but I did take for granted—incorrectly so—the idea that the schedule was to be amended. So I apologise for causing any confusion in that regard. If you look at the Hansard from last Tuesday, I made clear that we were very concerned about schedule 2 in its original form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate on this matter. I will indicate that, when you are trying to manage a program, it is very difficult when an indication of support is given for a particular schedule—with a few concerns expressed but, nonetheless, support—and then we have a senator tell us that that was only said because she was counting on some amendment getting through. She was not, as I understand it, told that by the government. In fact, that came from discussions that other non-government parties might have had. This really does not seem any way to run the show.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, I want to talk briefly on this and indicate that this amendment will have the effect of entirely negating our proposals to have a visa cap and queue extended to those areas where it is currently unavailable; that is, to aged parent visas, to spouse visas and to dependent children visas. We obviously oppose the amendment. We believe the measures are essential for orderly management of the program.

It is important to understand that the previous government had, and this government has, cap and kill mechanisms already. What we are asking for is, yes, some enhancement of that but, more particularly, cap and queue, which seems much more orderly and much more sensible and much fairer. If senators are not of a mind to support that, be it on their heads to answer for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that you have a very important principle here, and it relates to the bonds of marriage and family being the foundation of any civilised society. I do not propose to go over the matters that I raised on the previous occasion when there was a disallowance motion on Migration Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1996, No. 211. I do not propose to delay the chamber on this, because that had been said. I advanced the arguments then and I do not propose to advance them now, because they are the same arguments. In short, just so that the committee knows where I am standing, I am supporting the amendment that is being proposed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That schedule 2 stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: (Senator West did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)

SPEECH.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment (by Senator Vanstone) proposed:
(3) Schedule 3, item 1, page 13 (after line 21), at the end of clause 507, add:

(2) To avoid doubt, subsection (1) does not prevent the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 from applying in relation to the marital status of persons making or administering regulations covered by subsection (1).

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that the people who will actually administer this act are protected by the Sex Discrimination Act. Why is it that we are concerned about one group of people but are not concerned about another group of people? Why can the Sex Discrimination Act be made non-operable for one group but is left to operate for another group? Does the minister concede that this particular proposal does two things: one, that it does see to the non-operation of the Sex Discrimination Act in certain circumstances; and, two, that it gives subordinate law‐makers the ability to pass regulations which would be in conflict with the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 if in fact it was able to operate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, this amendment basically implements an election commitment. As you know, it relates to schedule 3 of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) and addresses concerns raised by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in relation to aspects of the proposed exemption. The committee recommended that proposed section 507(b) of the migration legislation be redrafted to limit the field of operation of the provision. The committee's concern was that administrative practices could be authorised under section 507, with the effect of allowing discrimination to occur in relation to the marital status of persons dealing with visa applications from persons in de facto relationships.

SPEECH.PARA: The government wants to make it clear that we could never contemplate this. However, we are prepared to move an amendment to put the issue beyond doubt. The third amendment, therefore, directly addresses the committee's concern by putting beyond doubt that the Sex Discrimination Act continues to apply in relation to the marital status of persons making or administering the relevant regulations.

In addition, the explanatory memorandum has been amended to make it absolutely clear that the Sex Discrimination Act applies except to the extent required to administer those regulations. As the government indicated in the statement foreshadowing this amendment, another area of consideration has been the government's intention to require a mandatory period of cohabitation for people seeking visas on the basis of de facto and interdependent relationships.

Honourable senators can be assured that the government intends that the period of cohabitation that will be required under the regulations in de facto and interdependency cases will not exceed 12 months and that there will be provision to waive this requirement if there are compelling circumstances to do so.

For example—and without intending to be prescriptive about the content of future regulations—the regulations might make provision for waiver of the cohabitation period where a de facto couple has a child of the relationship or where cohabitation by interdependent applicants is contrary to the law of the country in which they reside. In conclusion, the government moves these amendments with some reluctance. As a matter of principle, we are committed to the user‐pays principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister might just clarify something for me. She said that there is no concern about the Sex Discrimination Act. I thought the changes the government was making were, on the face of it, infringing the Sex Discrimination Act—that is, that de facto couples are going to be treated differently from married people when they put an application before the government to come into this country—and that that is why you had to do something about it.
—Yes, the government treats married and cohabiting couples differently.

—That is where I take umbrage at the legislation. No doubt the statistics can fly, but if you want to make an analysis of married couples under the headings of couples with one, two, three, four, five children or no children, their age groups or where they got married, you will find there are different statistics as to how long those marriages last.

SPEECH.PARA: The government's notes say that it wants to make it harder for de facto couples to come to this country because their rate of staying together is not as good as it is for people who have a marriage certificate under their arm. But that is discriminatory. The minister should be able to say why it is that she has not broken down into subgroups the biggest group in this category coming into the country, married people, to see which sorts of marriages will last the best and apply the two-year test to the sorts of marriages which do not last as well as others.

The point of the Sex Discrimination Act was to stop this sort of thing happening. The point of this amendment is to allow the government to get around an act which has been on our statutes for 13 years to prevent discrimination. As we all know, once we allow a bit to be chipped away, the government will be back to have more chipped away further down the line. So, as far as I am concerned, I oppose this move by the government. I think it is fraught with difficulties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, we made it abundantly clear that we thought there would need to be a time test. We originally wanted two years. We have made concessions in that respect and come down to 12 months as a consequence of representations made by the opposition. This might be a situation where you and the government simply have a different view.

—I acknowledge that the amendment before us deals with a 50 per cent reduction in the original cohabitation period that the government wanted. It still does not fully address the concerns that the Australian Democrats have with regard to this area and in relation to the sexual discrimination legislation. We recognise the will of this chamber on this one, but we still have concerns over the one-year period as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the opposition's position, one of the things I was really pleased to do as minister in this area was streamline the area with respect to particularly interdependency cases. So I have been concerned that the government is imposing these sorts of measures and in fact overriding the operation of the SDA with respect to this.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition's position has evolved through discussions with the government, and I must say it has been made a lot easier because of the government's preparedness to cut back the period from two years to one and also to invest a discretion in the minister or delegated officer to waive such a requirement in circumstances where, for instance, a country's laws prohibit such cohabitation. That was one of the concerns raised before the Senate committee and reflected in the report of the committee on this bill. So those two measures make it somewhat easier for us to accept a measure which, in principle, we would have enormous difficulty in accepting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The difference that is being defined here is one on the basis of discrimination. I think the minister accepts that the measure is discriminatory and that it would be, as it stands, an infringement of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. I oppose it vehemently.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 3, item 1, page 13 (lines 5 to 21), omit the item, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1 At the end of the Act

SPEECH.PARA: Add:

(1) For the avoidance of doubt, it is expressly declared to be the intention of the Parliament that the terms of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 , to the extent that it applies to the status or condition of being married or being the de facto spouse of another person, prevail over the provisions of this Act.
(2) Nothing in this Act is to be taken to authorise:

PARA.TAB: (a) the making of any regulations that, for the purposes of dealing with an application for a visa, specify:

TAB.TAB: (i) the nature and incidents of the relationship between a person and another person; or
(ii) the period for which a relationship of a specified kind must have existed between a person and another person;
before the person is taken to be the de facto spouse of the other person; or

PARA.TAB: (b) any conduct that is inconsistent with the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 .

SPEECH.PARA: In my second reading comments I expressed our concern in relation to the changes that affect sexual discrimination law in this country. The amendment—and I apologise for its late circulation—is one which government and opposition members would be familiar with anyway, given it has been moved in a rather similar form in relation to bills in previous debates.

We do not support amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act, and we are proposing an amendment which essentially affirms the primacy of the SDA as it presently exists. Just as Senator Reynolds objected strongly to any attempts to tone down the SDA, we are making a commitment to that in amendment form.

We certainly believe in equality, and on at least five separate occasions our national parliament has spoken in favour of equality. In recent times these have been with regard to the Racial Discrimination Act, the Disability Discrimination Act, the Sex Discrimination Act, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act and the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act.

We believe that exemptions do not further human rights in this country but are political compromises which often have the effect of allowing safe havens for some people to discriminate against other people. The Australian Democrats strongly believe that racial, sexual and disability discrimination are equally abhorrent and should be given equal weighting and equal concern. So I have moved an amendment which is a modified version of what the ALP moved in relation to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996—I believe that was accepted by the government—and in relation to the Hindmarsh Island Bridge Bill 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not accepted by the government.

—Which was not accepted by the government; that is right. This same idea is proposed by the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, Mr Daryl Melham, in regard to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Native Title Act. I invite Senator Bolkus and his colleagues to show their support for an initiative that was arrived at by one of their colleagues and for equal opportunity and human rights by supporting our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment for two reasons. Firstly, it would simply overturn the amendment we have just passed, which would make us all look like a bunch of dills. It is completely inconsistent with what we have just done. Secondly, it is very hard to look at things on the run. Senator, I know the bottom line of the amendment circulated in the chamber with today's date reads `6.26 p.m.', but the one you have given me was sent to the Democrats on 25 February—that is a week ago. I do not know whether other parties had it earlier, but we certainly would have appreciated it earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We do have a problem which in a sense emanates from the fact that this amendment was circulated only some 20 minutes ago. We have not really had enough time to consider it at all, let alone in full. The objec tive is desirable. The implications are such, though, that one has to consider the whole diversity of migration law, and that is something that worries us at this particular stage. The principle is a good one. But, for instance, how does it affect married couples and how does it affect de facto couples in so many areas of migration law? That is not before us at the moment. For that reason, rather than objecting to it on the basis of principle, we do not at this stage support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone made a telling point. Having passed what we just did in terms of the SDA, how do we then pass this at this particular stage? That is something we really need to dwell on. I would like to see, though, the government give full consideration to the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act in relation to migration law. It is something that over recent years we did pay some attention to. But we think it would be quite useful to have a review into the migration law and its consistency with the SDA. That could be done, for instance, by the joint committee of the parliament on migration or maybe the Sex Discrimination Commissioner could be asked to look at this area. But it is an important issue and one which is diverse in its ramifications. For that reason, not having had a chance to test those ramifications at this stage, we are not inclined to support the amendment, though we support the principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a really dangerous point of view to take. What we know from the passing of the last amendment is that the authority of the Sex Discrimination Act is being put secondary to the government's intentions in this legislation. The minister knows that. She just said that, having passed that amendment five minutes ago, you would be a dill if you now supported this. The opposition needs to look further than that because, if it does not support this, it is effectively saying that it is putting the Sex Discrimination Act second to the government's new policy of limiting immigration and categories of people who can come to the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate: it is a very dangerous precedent to be allowing the government to get away with. That is why I spoke so strongly against the last amendment. That is why I spoke so strongly against the committee allowing the government to get away with writing into legislation that the Sex Discrimination Act will come second. I had thought that that was one of the flagships, if you like, of Labor's social justice innovations of the last decade or two. For goodness sake, let us not hear the Labor Party saying, `But here's an exception.'

In particular, Senator Stott Despoja has come forward with a very clear defence of the Sex Discrimination Act in this legislation. She has pointed to the fact that she is being incited to do this, if you like, by the fact that in the last few weeks Labor has been defending through this same mechanism other acts which protect our citizens from discrimination. So how could Labor not support this?

You cannot get away with saying, `We haven't had time to look at it.' Let us move to give you more time, if that is the case. But I appeal to the Labor Party to look at this amendment again. It is a very important principle and the government should not get away with pulling the first strings to undo the Sex Discrimination Act lightly. It is a very important matter. Those of us who are concerned, and I think everybody in this place is concerned about discrimination, ought to look to the legislation that this parliament has passed—very often hard fought for and hard won—and not take it lightly at all. To say, `We haven't had time to look at this,' is to fail to give it the seriousness that it ought to have.

Maybe I should not reflect on past votes—I do not know what the rule is—but we ought not in this place be passing specific infringements of the Sex Discrimination Act. The committee did that in a way. Here is our chance to recover. Here is our chance to make good that last vote if we, in consideration, do not think it was a good one. Making it legal to infringe the Sex Discrimination Act is not much different from infringing it in an illegal fashion. We have the opportunity here to think about it and we ought to be supporting Senator Stott Despoja's motion. It is clear cut, it is simple and it says, `Let's stand by the Sex Discrimination Act.' We should do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —One might make a mistake if one thought the reason for not supporting it was simply a matter of timing. It is a matter of courtesy that one does not waltz in here with amendments that one has been sitting on for a week, spread them around and say at the last minute, `Let's think about this.' That was the point that was being made.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether you see merit in this or not is another matter. I have seen plenty of amendments that have come in with quite meritorious intentions that on greater reflection have had flaws in them. It is all very well to say that you are satisfied, in whatever period you have had to look at this, there are no flaws in this. That may be the case in terms of Senator Stott Despoja's intention. It may not be the case. We have not had the opportunity to consider whether it simply does what she wants to do and nothing else, because we got it only a short time ago. And that is not the way to run a parliament.

Additionally, you might have seen, I think, the 1990-91 report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, chaired by Mr Theophanous. I have not read this report, but I am informed that it recommended a 12-month cohabitation period for de facto couples. So let us not pretend that parliament is doing something now that it has not understood and that it has not been considered by a whole range of people. It has and they agree. They might disagree with you, but other people nonetheless have a different view. That may be difficult to accept, but the longer we are here the more we all have to swallow it every now and then. We disagree. That is what the place is about. But a joint standing committee chaired by the previous government in 1991 recommended a 12-month cohabitation period for de factos. It is not as if this issue has not had a decent airing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —On that, I am voting according to the speech—a good speech, may I say—given by Senator Bolkus. To be fair, I think the point being made by Senator Stott Despoja is not so much the fact that there is going to be a 12‐month period to test whether or not people are in a de facto relationship; the real problem throughout all this is that schedule 3 specifically refers to the Sex Discrimination Act and uses language quite akin to section 6 of the act. It goes ahead and puts aside the operation of that act. I think that is what has got everybody concerned. It is not so much that you need rules as to evidence, but that this schedule 3 itself specifically sets aside the Sex Discrimination Act. That, I think, has people worried, and justifiably worried. It has been set aside to allow evidentiary provisions to operate. That, I think, has people concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

Bill agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Vanstone) read a third time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.56 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996 EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 December 1996, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister coming?
—Keep going, Senator.

—Senator O'Chee, I would not, if I were you, pursue that line. The opposition has considered the issues in relation to the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Bill and associated legislation. Given that since 1995 almost 81,000 overseas students have studied in Australia, some 15.6 per cent more than a year earlier, quite clearly the measures undertaken in this bill are important to Australia's international reputation and protection of the integrity of its overseas educational programs. The international student education industry brings a net benefit to the Australian economy of some $600 million annually. We believe it is likely to grow.

SPEECH.PARA: Legislation to ensure the financial and quality assurance of the provision of education to overseas students was first introduced in 1991 in the form of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act, the ESOS Act. This follows the development and concerns in the late 1980s about the credibility of much that was then on offer from the non‐formal parts of Australia's education and training system; that is, not including the universities, schools or the TAFE colleges but essentially other providers. Some major concerns emerged as to the financial viability and the quality of courses offered by many of these institutions.

A framework was established whereby the states and territories were responsible for primary accreditation of institutions and courses while the Commonwealth maintained a register of providers and their courses. It required non‐exempt providers to operate trust accounts for prepaid course fees; to submit to the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, as it then was, an annual return relating to the operation of these trust accounts; and to be members of a tuition assurance scheme. There seems no doubt that these arrangements have contributed significantly to the stability in the industry in the period since their introduction and have been a major factor in the growth of the industry during that time.

In view of the fact that the ESOS Act was due to expire at the end of this year, a review of it was undertaken earlier this year by Ernst and Young. In a climate of general deregulation it is interesting to note that the review found no stakeholder in favour of industry self‐regulation at this time. Concerns centred on Australia's international reputation in the provision of education services and whether the industry currently had sufficient maturity to self‐regulate. In addition, there was a stakeholder agreement that the Commonwealth should continue to have a regulatory role and that regulation entirely by state and territory governments was not desirable.

The sunset clause in the ESOS Act will now take effect from 1 January 1999. Given that there seems to be a genuine agreement about the appropriateness of the current arrangements and that it is vitally important that we ensure that such a very substantial export industry is protected by effective financial and quality safeguards, the opposition believes that it is not unreasonable for the Commonwealth to seek to recoup some of the costs incurred in the process.

The government proposed that a charge be levied on the basis of the number of students enrolled by institutions in the previous year, with the charge amounts ranging from $300 for up to 10 students, increasing to $5,000 for more than 400 students. The charge would apply for all enrolments of people in Australia on student visas.

I know that Senator Margetts had planned to move two amendments to take account of the length of courses as well as the number of enrolments at each institution. This is quite important, given the vast differences in course length—they vary from a period of weeks to years. It was Labor's initiative that encouraged the government to reconsider their approach to these regulations and as a result this has led to a discussion between various parties within the Senate. The way the legislation was previously framed discriminated against the providers of shorter courses many of whom are members of the English Language Intensive Courses to Overseas Students Association.

According to the information supplied by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the median course duration of students enrolled at ELICOS institutions in 1995 was 40 weeks. In other words, around half the students were enrolled in courses shorter than 40 weeks. Also according to DEETYA, around 20 per cent of ELICOS enrolments were people doing courses of less than three months duration who could therefore have been eligible for visitor rather than student visas, thus excluding them from the calculation of the provider registration charge.

That means, however, that 80 per cent of enrolments were not eligible for such exclusion, yet many were still doing relatively short courses. To take account of this and to try to treat such providers on an equitable basis with other providers such as universities, we are pleased to note that the government listened to the concerns put forward by the opposition parties and has sought to amend its bill in a way which counts people doing courses of less than 26 weeks as half an enrolment for the purpose of the charge, with students in longer courses counting as one enrolment. We will therefore be supporting this amendment. I note that the minister has yet to arrive.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is here.
—Where is the minister?
—Here.
—He is the minister on duty.
—You are the minister on duty, are you? I understand that Senator Vanstone has coverage of this bill. So, Senator Minchin, you have coverage of this bill, do you?
—You cannot pick and choose. This is not a smorgasbord.
—The opposition will be supporting the amendments, but it would be easier for this bill to proceed if the minister who had coverage of this bill was in fact present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to discuss the education services for overseas student bills, both the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Bill 1996 and the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: The ESOS act, as many of us are aware, allows for the regulation of the overseas education industry in this country. Many will recall that this arose from a situation in 1991 where the government was forced to refund the fees of 12,000 international students affected by the closure of private educational services in this country.

ESOS also provides for quality and fairness within the industry. These bills establish the administrative arrangements required of providers under the ESOS act. These bills also extend the sunset clause for a further two years while consultation continues with industry regarding service provision for international students.

One million dollars per annum of the estimated $1.9 billion in export revenue is expected to result from the passage of these bills. I note that an article appeared in the Australian last year—I think it coincided with the original timetabling of this legislation, when we were first due to debate it—in the higher education supplement entitled `Education top in export growth'. In that article I learnt that Steven Kemp had conducted the research for a report which found that more export dollars come into this country from overseas higher education than from wheat. I believe the figure stated was around $1.9 billion this year alone.

This is obviously an incredibly huge industry. It is little wonder that people involved in that industry as well as people involved in the higher education sector generally were very concerned about the impact, both economically and academically, of comments made last year by a certain Independent member in the other place and were very worried that export education and its expected revenue might be somehow harmed in that way.

Between 1988 and 1995, the number of overseas students in Australia increased nearly fourfold to more than 800,000. Mr Kemp also observed this and further observed that universities were increasingly nervous that their funding would become more dependent upon overseas student income. As a result of his research, he says, `If there were to be any abrupt changes in policy or fall off in student numbers, they would really feel it'—`they' being the higher education institutions, which are increasingly reliant on independent fees and charges these days that they secure not only from overseas students but also from domestic students in this country.

To date Australia has captured a larger market share than either the US or the UK, but this could change obviously if there are detrimental or negative changes policywise in this country but also if they realise—and I am sure they do—the potential export earnings.

I think Australia should not lose the hard work put in by universities. There has been a lot of effort put in by institutions around this country over the last decade, certainly in regard to providing bridging courses, orientation courses or what have you for overseas students. Certainly that should not be sacrificed for the sake of short-term measures, be those measures to slash and burn or what have you.

Each international student is estimated to spend around $23,000 per annum in education on a range of expenses—obviously living expenses as well as education expenses. In 1995, there was $1.88 billion in direct expenditure by international students—a huge amount—and, I believe, $125 million generated by other education export earnings from offshore programs.

Mr Steven Kemp said that the only limitation to this growth is the potential of the higher education sector to cope. That brings into debate a whole range of issues regarding changes and reform in the higher education sector generally. Obviously, the impact of budget cuts to operating grants, cuts to discretionary funding arrangements and the resultant cuts to programs, schools, departments, staff and resources have seen the first dominoes fall.

I note—and many in this chamber would be aware of this—that international students have been calling meetings. They have been concerned and they have spoken with vice-chancellors. This has been reported in the media which has filtered through—not only in domestic papers around this country and the mainstream press, but media in different countries. It is a simple premise: if you cut resources to a university system which is already feeling the strain of 13 years of chronic underfunding, you will undermine the quality of the sector.

I remind honourable senators that we have seen the closure of campuses already in this nation: the St George campus of the University of New South Wales and the Salisbury campus of the University of South Australia in our home state, Madam Acting Deputy President. We had news only last week that that same institution is considering closing the doors of its regional campus in Whyalla, obviously in the face of the harsh budget cuts that have been undertaken by this coalition government.

We have seen other universities merging their departments. They have retrenched staff, and I am sure they will continue to do so. Of course we are all familiar with the up-front fees proposals that have been rammed through by this government. The University of Melbourne is considering $110,000 for a dentistry degree. All of these will impact upon the quality offered in institutions. The quality and the reputation of these institutions will determine whether or not they can attract overseas students and overseas student dollars.

The Howard government has cut universities by 4.9 per cent over the next three years. These cuts are compounded by a failure to maintain an election pledge by this government—that is, to address the NTEU wage claim. Basically, this means that the cuts to the higher education sector, to universities specifically, are around 10 per cent. If the resources and budgets are already strained and the government continues to cut further, then the reality is that international students will look to other places. They will look to countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom to pursue their study.

Around this country we are losing academics with expertise in many fields. Once they have gone, their experience will no longer be available to the minds of future, up and coming students. The university funding cuts in this nation are as short-sighted in an economic as well as academic sense as they are unpopular.

This weekend the Sydney Morning Herald printed the results of an AGB McNair poll which failed the performance of the Howard government on higher education. Forty‐six per cent of those surveyed disapproved of the coalition's treatment of higher education. But I am sure that many of us on this side of the chamber could have told—indeed, have told—the government that, as every debate regarding higher education has come to this chamber.

It is worth noting that this was the highest disapproval rating of the entire survey. It probably reflects similar surveys which have been conducted recently showing that the minister's performance is considered I think the bottom or the equal bottom rating with that of Alexander Downer, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, when it comes to the public's perception of performance of ministers in this country. It is worth noting also that that approval rating, which did rate Senator Vanstone more highly than Mr Downer, was taken before the means test debacle—and I am sure that Mr Downer is taking comfort from that but certainly minister Vanstone is not.

Certainly the electorate could have expected to be able to put some faith or hope in the government holding true to some of its policies—certainly its pre-election promises that it would not cut funds to this particular sector, that it would not cut operating grants, that it would maintain Austudy, that it would not change fees and charges and that it would strengthen rural and regional institutions. I would be very interested to see the overseas student take‐up rate in regional and remote campuses around this nation, especially when many of those campuses are facing the threat of closure. The population had a right to believe that they would not be facing up-front fees and charges of the magnitude they now expect, just as they believed that this government really did have a commitment to education, as stated in its pre-election policies.

But there is a litany of broken promises from this government in regard to higher education funding. International students also have the right to believe that, once they enrol in an Australian university, they will receive a quality education; that the government will ensure that, within those universities, the buildings are not falling down, the libraries are well stocked and there are sufficient staff, resources and infrastructure; that the computers will be adequate for the number of students in those institutions; and that the campus environment will be a safe one. Students who come to these shores, who pay up-front fees—full cost fees, in many cases—have a right to expect such arrangements.

Yet many international students, overseas students—not just their formal organisation—have been contacting my office with complaints about the animosity they receive when referring to administrators, be they vice‐chancellors, registrars or what have you, when they bring up issues such as a shortage of resources, and so on. Ultimately, any shortage of resources is the responsibility of the government.

This government has been particularly quick to slash education budgets and boast of its budget cuts but very slow to recognise that education is not a cost. Education in this country is an investment, an investment in our future. Also, economically speaking, it is a good investment. When we talk about the revenue from export education creating more money in this country than wheat, then obviously that investment is giving a very quick return.

The funding cuts in many institutions will rebound on overseas students. It seems that many institutions will be forced to make tough decisions as a result of the budget cuts. Those tough decisions include offering no counselling; cutting back on assistance regarding English skills, bridging courses and orientation courses; cuts to child‐care centres and accommodation—again, issues that affect overseas students; and lack of resources, library and other education materials. The proposed cuts could make these resources virtually non-existent, especially on those campuses already suffering from chronic underfunding. Our international reputation depends on these resources and services being of a high and competitive quality for all students—another issue which threatens Australia's reputation as an international education provider.

International students have been hurt not only by government attacks on the higher education sector but also by the needless, inciteful and ill-informed race debate. Many of those students—and this is shown in surveys and polls that have been conducted in institutions around the country—do fear increased racism. They believe that it is of increased proportions on campuses. This belief—this idea—that is and has been perpetuated by the government that somehow overseas students have been displacing, or taking the places of, domestic students is a furphy.

Perhaps the minister on duty, Senator Minchin, might want to explain the rationale that was put forward during the higher education debate by the minister for higher education, Senator Vanstone: this idea that we are offering up-front full‐cost undergraduate fees now because they were previously offered to overseas students and thus, if not displacing domestic students, somehow domestic students should be offered that `choice'. I use that term loosely because I think the choice debate in this whole issue is a complete furphy.

It is not the case that overseas students have taken places from domestic students. As I and many of my colleagues have expressed in this place on many occasions—be it during the immigration and ethnic affairs debates we have had or on a range of issues—again, we express our concern that the government did not instantly, wholeheartedly and entirely repudiate many of the comments made by Ms Hanson, the Independent member for Oxley. In fact, the government has allowed, almost encouraged, this urban myth, if you like, of the displacement of places to be perpetuated in our community. It certainly is the responsibility of this parliament, this government and certainly of the minister—be it the minister on duty or Senator Vanstone—to correct that particular issue and set the record straight on racism.

Yet the government's budget has also cut campaigns to combat racism and build a more tolerant society. Again, the Democrats lament those particular changes—not only lament them but find them absolutely shameful. We believe that we must start acting more responsively towards international students—in fact, towards all students in our society. This bill will go some way towards that goal.

However, I urge the government to reflect on the impact of its funding cuts to the higher education sector, and to assess the social deficit its zealous pursuit of its budget black hole has created. I would hate to think that we are creating some kind of intellectual, moral or what have you range of deficits in this country in a bid to address the so-called budget deficit.
