DEBATE.TITLE:
PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES BILL 1997 HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES) BILL 1996
MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE INCENTIVES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is con sidering the motion for the second reading of the bills to which Senator Neal has moved two amendments and Senator Lees has moved two amendments to the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The aim of the government in this bill is to reverse the decline in the private health insurance system by giving a subsidy to low and medium income earners towards the cost of private health insurance and by penalising high income earners without private health insurance by a one per cent surcharge on the Medicare levy. There are some problems at the outset with the implementation of this scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, income thresholds are not graded and this will lead to significant marginal tax rate effects. Secondly, income thresholds are not indexed, so the numbers of lower income earners eligible for the subsidy will decrease over time and those higher income earners subject to the surcharge will increase. Thirdly, people who self‐insure are not eligible for the subsidy or to be exempted from the surcharge. That is, the bill pushes people from self‐insurance into the private health funds.

What is the likely effect of this? Currently about 33.3 per cent—one in three—of the population is covered by private health insurance. Significantly, as other speakers have said, this is a halving of the percentage, two‐thirds of the Australian populace having been covered in 1983 before Medicare was introduced.

What will be the effect of this stimulus for people to join private health insurance? It is estimated that it will be very limited. The coverage due to these bills may be increased by two per cent or three per cent, or, according to the Productivity Commission, at the high range, 5.2 per cent in the percentage of people who have private health cover.

Some points need to be made about the issues in this legislation. Firstly, Medicare is popular, that is very clear, and the declining membership of private health funds is not necessarily a problem—except, of course, to the profit line of the private health funds and to the wellbeing of those funds themselves.

BREAK.PARA: The cause of declining membership of those funds, besides Medicare being as popular as it is, has been pointed to by earlier speakers. Firstly, there is a high level of out of pocket payments for doctors' fees during hospital treatment, and then there is the rapidly increasing premiums themselves. I think anyone who has got an acquaintance with this system can instance some stories like those referred to by Senator Carr. People have gone to their health fund expecting to get 70, 80 or 90 per cent of their money back, thinking that they would be covered under private health insurance for doctors' services, and they have found they were getting less than 20 per cent of the amount of money expended. So they immediately throw their hands up in the air and say, `What is the point? I am paying $250 or $300 a quarter'—that is for single people; it is much more for families. `Where is the benefit in paying $1,000, $2,000 or $3,000 a year if I am not going to get most of the cost of my health care returned?'

There is a fear that as more people drop out of the private health funds they will place an increasing burden on public hospitals. But that fear is not well founded and certainly has not been well tested. While everybody agrees that public health systems are creaking and groaning in most areas of the country, the change in the percentage of people with private health cover has not led to the end of the world as far as our health systems are concerned. A significant number of people are choosing to self‐insure: 15.6 per cent of patients who go to private hospitals, for example, and 42.7 per cent of those using private day surgery. I reiterate that those folk are going to face a heavy disincentive as a result of the legislation now before the Senate.

To the extent that declining levels of private health insurance are a problem for public hospitals, this ad hoc package of incentives and penalties will not solve the problem because it does not solve the structural issues which are causing such pressure on public hospitals in this country. Direct and explicit subsidies for private health insurance are new and the money could be better spent on other more urgent priorities in the health care field.

The cost of the subsidy inherent in this legislation is over $600 million per annum once the scheme is fully implemented; it will be $1.7 billion over four years. That compares with a total expenditure on health of $38 billion, of which $4 billion is through private health funds. They are a pretty small component of overall expenditure. So the government is now proposing to contribute directly a sum which amounts to 15 per cent of current health expenditure through the private system.

The $600 million per annum could be better directed to community based health improvement programs rather than directly subsidising the private system. That will be very clear to people who have had much to do with the health delivery system in this country. Maintaining and strengthening the public health system allows the government to directly address causes of ill‐health. If you look at the example of air quality, you see that in Melbourne 20 per cent of asthma attacks are related to ozone from traffic, as are a significant proportion of the 300 deaths from respiratory problems associated with particulates which are generated from traffic, basically coming out of the exhausts of vehicles in the inner city region.

What could $600 million per annum or $1.7 billion over four years do to ameliorate those statistics? A heck of a lot. There are so many ways in which primary health care could be boosted by this huge amount of money which instead the government is using to try to boost the private health insurance industry.

In summary, the Greens support the Medicare levy surcharge. We oppose the link to private health insurance, which cuts out self‐insuring people. I need to just say here that it is a tax—a tax on higher income earners. I do not cavil at that, but I think the money is being hypothecated across to the private health system and it ought not be. It is stimulating the private health system. The government would be better putting the money from the surcharge, as well as the incentive from the levy, into generating a better public health system and into taking some of the pressure off the public health system that we currently have.

We oppose the private health insurance subsidy. So there it is. On the final summary, we oppose the subsidy because it is good government money basically being given across as a stimulus to the private health system instead of going into the public health system. Let me say that again. We oppose the subsidy—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you got it right.
—Yes, I did. Thank you, Senator Neal. We oppose the subsidy and we believe that the Medicare levy surcharge is the wrong way to be going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, I appreciate your assistance in taking the chair to enable me to contribute to this debate. These private health insurance bills introduce this change by the coalition government to very significantly alter the funding arrangements of health care in this country. They do so directly breaking a number of election promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, there were promises that there would be no new taxes. The people who earn more than the specified income level and who do not have private health insurance will certainly be enjoying, as the expression sometimes goes, a new tax. That is breaking a promise, deliberately and directly. Secondly, there were promises that Medicare and funding to public hospitals would be preserved. That is exactly counter to what this government have done. They have done it in a most wasteful and ineffective way. I would like to spell out some of those points in the time available to me.

I note that it is very interesting to recollect what Premier Kennett had to say on this matter. I notice that the best defence that the coalition government can mass against what Premier Kennett has had to say is that sometimes Premier Kennett gets it right, which is a pretty feeble defence. Premier Kennett has said that this is good money after bad and that it is a very ineffectual contribution towards private hospitals. The best the Treasurer (Mr Costello) or the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) can do is find other quotes where Mr Kennett said differently.

BREAK.PARA: So what this clearly shows is that Mr Kennett is confused and the coalition government, Mr Howard's government, is embarrassed. They ought to be. They have offered incentives to people to take out private health insurance. These incentives total $1.7 billion over four years. What the evidence already shows is that people are continuing to leave private health insurance in the face of the promise just around the corner that will help them stay there.

Why are people leaving private health insurance? It is very simple. Senator Brown said it: the only way you can get a bill in this country is if you have private health insurance. If you are covered when you go to hospital under Medicare, you get no extra bill or costs. The only way you get a bill is if you have private health insurance. You would think that the coalition government—which claims to be very au fait with the free market and the importance of small business and what goes on out there in the real world of economics and so on—would understand that, if you are trying to sell a product that is directly and deliberately doing counter to what it is set up for, people would not want to buy it. And people do not want to buy it.

As Senator Brown said, many of us can come in here and give examples, as I have done before and I will do again. Many a time people have written to me and said, `Look, Senator, I've been paying my private health insurance premiums for 30 years. After all this time I suddenly need to use them. I have been to hospital. What do I have? I have a bill for $3,000, and I do not know how I am ever going to pay it. Senator, what can be done?'

The answer is, `Well, private health insurance is no longer delivering what it was set up to do.' It was set up, way back, to protect people from high health costs, from significant health bills that would put them into financial straits. Worse still, for people who did not have health insurance, those bills were so worrying and frightening that they refused to go and see the doctor. We know that because of the millions of people who were without insurance prior to the Labor Party coming into government in 1983. With the introduction of Medcare, suddenly all those people who had no health insurance were free of the worry of big health costs. The only people who still have big health costs are those with private health insurance.

How long is it going to be before this government recognises that this is a really daft product? Firstly, if you want to get a health bill, get private health insurance. It does not protect you; it guarantees you get a bill. Secondly, the premiums that people have to pay just continue to rise. In the face of promises that those premiums would be kept down, we have seen this government dealing with the embarrassment of—having given a promise that they would assist people with the cost of their private health insurance—seeing that promise eroded before it was even delivered, with the cost of the private health fund premiums very significantly rising in the last 12 months.

So we have a product that fewer people want to buy. We have a product that is terribly expensive and getting more so. We have a product that does not do what it is set up for, which is to protect people from big bills. Of course the citizens of this country are saying that that is a very silly thing them for them to be pursuing. Of course people are leaving in droves.

What this is doing is giving some people a worry. Now that the coalition is in office, it might find that it has to change the language and the fear and the loathing that it spread for 13 years while it was in opposition. The coalition kept frightening people about what would happen if they did not have insurance—that there would be very long waiting lists and so on. They kept avoiding the fact about waiting lists and they kept insisting on frightening people so that some people still feel it is essential to have private health insurance to avoid long waits.

For very few conditions do people have to wait very long at all. The conditions for which people have to wait are the same conditions that they had to wait for during the 1980s, 1970s, 1960s and 1950s. You can go right back and see that the longer waiting lists have always been in orthopaedics; ear, nose and throat; and with eye specialists. That still the case. Of course, that is no reason to be complacent, but it is also a reason to assure a lot of people that their fears about the need for private health insurance are probably largely unfounded.

In the end, if you were trying to assist many of those people you would actually be doing what you promised to do in the run-up to the election and maintain your funding for the public health system, because that is where so many people are turning for the elective surgical procedures that their doctors judge or diagnose that they need. Please do not misunderstand that or come back at me by saying that I really said that doctors are making people have surgery that is not necessary. I am not saying that at all. If a person's general practitioner makes a diagnosis that they need this specialist care or specialist procedures, then that is what they will seek.

But in elective surgery people are now turning, more and more, to the public hospital system, just in time to find a coalition government which has actually slashed grants to the states by $1.5 billion over three years. That is a cut of about $500 million to the states' health funding, about one-third of health expenditure. They have also made direct cuts to public hospitals of more than $300 million over four years and they have taken other massive amounts out of health totalling more than $3 billion over four years. This is a direct contradiction of what people were promised by the coalition in the run-up to the election.

Not only have they decided to put $1.7 billion over four years through private health insurance subsidies, but those subsidies are going to be funded by those cuts to public hospitals of $800 million over four years, cuts to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme of $500 million over four years and the abolition of the Commonwealth dental program, saving $400 million.

The cuts to the public hospitals alone are equivalent to closing 1,000 beds or turning away 66,000 people who are waiting for operations. It is interesting that, at a time of bolstering private health insurance with these incentives, private health insurance and the use of private hospitals for private procedures have never been so large. At a time of falling private health insurance coverage, there has been increased use of private hospitals for increasing private procedures. Many of them are done in day surgery, but it is a measure of how many procedures are being done in the private sector through private hospitals. This certainly runs counter to any scaremongering that says that private hospitals were under threat by Medicare, which was one of the claims made by the coalition.

Consider: there are approximately six million Australians eligible for health care concession cards. About six million Australians currently have private health insurance. This policy takes funding away from the health care concession card holders and give it to the privately insured people. This policy is going to force pensioners to wait longer for elective surgery in public hospitals, pay more for their essential medicines and pay up to $200 for dentures in order to subsidise people with private health insurance.

To suggest that people who are not insured at the moment will actually be encouraged to buy private health insurance—that is, to find, for a single person, about $800 necessary to buy private health insurance so as to be eligible to get the government's $125 incentive—is really flying in the face of the evidence. This incentive may encourage people already with private insurance to stay in insurance, but it certainly is not going to encourage people who have decided not to find $800 to move into private health insurance. That is what people might have thought: at least it will stop the drain. But, indeed, the evidence is already counter to that.

Private health insurance figures continue to fall. The incentive that is there for people is not persuading anybody to make that decision. The evidence is counter in terms of the numbers of people in private insurance, and the premiums for private health insurance continue to rise very significantly. This incentive is really $1.7 billion straight down the plughole. It is doing nothing for private health, it is doing nothing for public health and it is doing nothing for any of those people who are so dependent on our public hospitals for all their care.

Senator Brown and, I am sure, others have said—the government may not want to say it; they might choke on it—that the people of Australia really value Medicare. They really like it, to the point where those policy‐free zones opposite actually adopted the slogan, `We too like Medicare. We too will not change Medicare. We too have become believers.' Well, if you believe that, as the community is beginning to discover, you would believe anything. But not for long.

You say that you support Medicare, but you are not serious. You have actually pulled billions of dollars out of the public sector, counter to what Medicare is about, and the community will not thank you for that. To take money from the public hospitals and from health care card holders and patients to put it into our private hospitals—not even into the private hospitals but into reducing private health insurance premiums—is already proving to be ineffective and is certainly not going to win you votes.

I suspect others have listed the increases in premiums. In August, the HBA in Victoria announced increases of six per cent and Australian Unity announced increases of 8.6 per cent. After these increases, as the coalition saw its incentives effectively wiped out, the Prime Minister intervened and set up an industry inquiry—a new approval process in which he took personal responsibility for future increases and requested that funds not have further increases until the inquiry reported.

The funds paid not the slightest attention to the Prime Minister's plaintive call. We saw Manchester Unity announce increases of 17.5 per cent shortly afterwards. HBA in Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory announced premium increases of around nine per cent in October. In November, Australia's two largest funds, Medibank Private and MBF, announced passive increases of 12.9 per cent and 15 per cent respectively.

So the funds, even in the face of the coalition government's intervention and the Prime Minister's personal intervention, continued to raise their premium prices by very significant amounts. In the face of that, they knew that people would once again take a decision to desert private insurance. Premiums are just too much and they do not give people the security, assurance and comfort against big bills. As I said in opening my comments, the only way you get a big bill is by having private health insurance.

Last month's private health insurance figures showed that people continued to drop out despite the fact of the imminent incentives. Last quarter, over 150,000 people dropped out of private insurance. Now we have the AMA, or some parts of it, urging people to give up private health insurance, to set aside some money or make private arrangements so that if they do have outlays in health they can pay for it themselves. They are saying that buying private health insurance is no good judgment of how best to protect yourself against those costs. In other words, what they are saying is that premiums are far too much and that people would be much better putting those premiums aside and spending them, if they need to, on any health charges they might incur.

One of the things I wanted to ask the minister goes to the administration and the understanding of definitions. Clause 3-3 of the explanatory memorandum is headed `Income test—policies covering only one person'. Clause 3-3(2)(b) states:
This subclause provides that the persons whose taxable incomes are to be taken into account when determining eligibility for the scheme in respect of a policy covering one person are:

if the person covered under the policy is a dependant child, the incomes of each parent who is paying premiums for the policy or arranging for a third party to pay premiums for the policy and of any partner of each such parent.

I would like an assurance that the words in this clause do not allow for the incomes of the partners of two separated parents with a dependant child, who are both contributing to health insurance for that child, also to be involved in the income assessment. Can I have that assurance? As it stands, the clause reads:
. . . and any partner of each such parent.

As I read the bill and the explanatory memorandum, I believe that two separated parents contributing to the cost of private health insurance for a child, both of whose incomes were taken into account, may under this wording find that each of their new partners may have their income taken into account for the purposes of this assessment. I would like an assurance that that is not what these words mean or at least that these words are not open to that interpretation.

I believe the administration of this whole area will be a real nightmare. People are going to have to complete a 15-page form. I wonder whether it is the same 15-page form that they had to complete in order to get Austudy, or is it a slightly different form? Can we be assured that this 15-page form will not cause the same trouble, confusion and anxiety we have seen caused in the area of Austudy?

Previously, you could pay your contribution for Medicare at the end of the year or out of your tax through PAYE. You were covered then, all your bills were paid and you did not have to worry when you went to hospital. Now, to even get the incentive, you have to roll up and fill out a 15-page report. This is a nightmare! It is a total policy disaster. Senator Heffernan, you can say that I am getting wound up. But I do not really have to. You have actually committed the greatest balls‐up in Medicare history since you were last in office. You had seven years in government and five different health policies under Prime Minister Fraser. You are at it again. The people of Australia are already walking and telling you that they do not like this incentive at all. The premiums are going up. Their costs and their protection are not there at all. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want firstly to thank senators who participated today in the debate on the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill and associated bills. The contributions from various senators have been considered and thoughtful, irrespective of the views they have taken and notwithstanding the government's opposition to a great deal of what they have said.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, let me say to Senator Neal that the government will oppose those second reading amendments put by the opposition and by the Democrats. We on this side make no bones about fostering and supporting the private health system. This is not simply because we believe the private sector offers Australians choice and flexibility in their health care but because the services, infrastructure and financing of the private sector actually complement the efforts of government through the public hospital system.

While it is only an indicative measurement of this contribution, I note figures released recently by the private health industry which show that private health benefits injected over $4 billion into the Australian health care system even while the number of contributors continues to decline. This clearly is a significant contribution.

Indeed, there has been some revived debate of late about the efficacy of private health insurance in the late 1990s, including comments by leading members of the Australian Medical Association and some others. It has been suggested that fostering private health fund membership is a waste of money. The government rejects this entirely. At the end of the day, private health insurance remains the path of affordable choice for most Australians, particularly for those members of the community for whom a large medical and hospital bill is hardly something which can easily be absorbed from their savings or other assets.

This does not take into account the pivotal role that the private sector plays in easing the pressure on strained public hospital resources. The Department of Health and Family Services has estimated that people who dropped private health insurance between July 1993 and September 1994 actually used the capacity equivalent to two metropolitan public hospitals for one whole year; that is, for every day of one year they could fill two metropolitan hospitals. To reduce such stress and strain on the public system the government is firmly committed to its policy strategy to better spread demand across the whole hospi tal system, public and private, and maximise the totality of the community resource rather than build otherwise unnecessary new public hospital capacity.

Let me now turn to the Democrat position, which was put forward by Senator Lees. We understand the point of view underlying Senator Lees's foreshadowed amendments and that they reflect Democrat policy that is well established and on the record. But, clearly, we differ with the premises that she has put forward. We look forward to seeing the Democrat amendments and considering them in the committee stage. I restate that the government believes that its proposed measures actually do what the Democrats have always stood for: actively encouraging those who can most afford to do so to make a more appropriate contribution to covering the cost of health care for themselves and their families.

With respect to the position of the opposition, let us look at what they have had to say. We have before us now Labor's second reading amendments to the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2). These amendments encapsulate the differences between the government and the opposition, who, for all their posturing now, had 13 years presiding over the health system of this country and left it breaking at the seams.

Let me say something about this second reading amendment and the opposition's view that the commitment to these incentives is at the expense of the public system. Firstly, I am pleased to see that the opposition will not oppose the passage of these incentives. Secondly, this at least recognises that this is a commonsense approach to a community's mandate for the greatest range of flexibility and choice when it comes to the medical and hospital system. But finally I would add: given that Labor in the last election was offering low and middle income families up to $350 towards their private health insurance costs, saying `many families who would like to take out health insurance to better manage their health care would find the premiums too high', Labor can hardly say anything else without compromising their leader and their record.

In their own offer to the Australian people, Labor recognised the coalition was right in identifying that what people want is choice and that what the system needs is a safety valve that relieves the pressure on public hospitals, particularly in relation to elective procedures that are at the core of waiting lists. I am sure the opposition cannot begrudge us making the assistance of the incentives available to a great many Australians, including some 80 per cent of Australian families as well as aged pensioners and fixed income retirees, who will benefit from the fact that they do not have to be an income tax payer to be eligible.

The opposition also talks of the government undermining Medicare and the public hospital system. What we are doing is in the wider national interest. I say again: the public hospital system is in disarray because of the extra demand placed on it by people leaving private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your cuts haven't helped either.

—Only recently, Senator Neal, we heard Bob Carr, the Premier of New South Wales, complain about these pressures—after having kept his mouth shut when his federal Labor colleagues were in power and when his factional ally Senator Graham Richardson sought to do something to put a floor under private health insurance membership in 1993. What did he say then?

SPEECH.PARA: To say that we have shifted money into the pockets of private insurers at the cost of public hospitals, of PBS outlays and the like is another furphy. The fact is the budget required decisive measures to deal with the unconstrained growth in Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits scheme outlays. We have acted to ensure that Medicare, public hospitals and the PBS remain capable of meeting the needs of the community. We have acted to ensure that they will not in a few years time fall over under their own weight of both demand and cost. These measures will not only complement Medicare but keep it strong and healthy.

BREAK.PARA: Let me now turn to the Medicare levy surcharge. I actually thank the opposition for their second reading amendment for, while they put strings on the surcharge, they do not actually reject the concept, nor the need to encourage higher income earners to make a contribution to their health care through private health insurance. This will free up as many public hospital waiting list places as possible for those for whom private health care is a far less affordable proposition.

We believe that the surcharge is an integral and essential component of the whole package which cannot be treated or, as the other side would prefer, knocked off in isolation. What we on this side cannot understand is why the Labor Party and others are so actively against this measure. We are not talking about a two-tier Medicare system. The surcharge does not undermine the universality of Medicare. All eligible people will continue to pay the basic levy. The surcharge will be asked of only those who can afford it yet still opt not to provide themselves with even the most basic private cover. As the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said at the time of the last budget, `this is a surcharge that we prefer no-one has to pay'.

What is more, we are not stopping those affected by the surcharge from accessing Medicare or public hospitals if that is their choice. I thought that the Labor Party stood for battlers, for the people who struggle—not the truly wealthy. Their opposition to this measure shows just how much the political landscape has changed since March last year.

In relation to the opposition's second reading amendments which I have mentioned, the government rejects the opposition's contention that any revenue raised from the surcharge should be hypothecated to public hospitals. I remind the opposition that, when they set up the Medicare system in 1984, from day 1 all receipts from the levy were paid into consolidated revenue, not a Medicare account. The levy contribution roughly equates to about one-quarter of these outlays. Proportionally, the levy pool would be slightly augmented by the surcharge. But, at the end of the day, we will continue to honour our obligations to Medicare and to the nation.

The opposition amendment should be seen for what it is: a base political stunt. The opposition stance on this matter is discredited by their record of 13 years in government and what they did, or did not do, for the public health system. In conclusion, today is an important day for Australian health consumers for it is a milestone on the road to greater choice, greater quality of care and greater quality of health insurance protection against illness and injury.

In summary, I want to take up one other point raised by the shadow minister for the opposition in that other place, and that was an implication that these incentives were in fact a benefit for the wealthy and that the roughly six million-odd pensioners and concessional card holders would be mutually excluded by the health fund contributors of roughly the same number. The government's reply to that is that they are not mutually exclusive groups. As we stated in our policy statement `A Healthy Future', which was based on ABS data, over one million Australians in 1992 on incomes under $20,000 to $21,000 per annum, which included some 600,000 singles, had private health insurance. This proportion probably has not changed. In fact, it is probably even greater today.

These are the battlers, many of whom made great sacrifices to keep up their private health insurance because they are frail, ill or old. They are the ones who most deserve these incentives. Because we have ensured that people do not have to become an income tax payer to get the incentive, they will benefit. We do not intend to let them down. I hope those opposite, in considering their position on these bills, have turned their minds to these people, the people who deserted them in March last year.

These measures are not the whole answer to the health problem we face as a nation, but the government sees them as an integral part of a strategic approach to solving them. They will go a long way to creating greater stability in our health care system by halting the exodus from private health funds. Hopefully they will encourage some growth in membership of private health funds. They will also enable services to be planned and delivered on the full range of capacity available, both public and private. I commend the bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Senator Lees's amendments to Senator Neal's amendments be agreed to.
—I just indicate that the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats are accepted by the opposition.
—The question is that Senator Neal's amendments, as amended by Senator Lees's amendments, be agreed to.

—I ask that the two amendments proposed in the second reading debate be put separately—the first one being to the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill and the second one being to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2).

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Neal's ) to the Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1996, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: (Senator Faulkner did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Neal's ) to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: (Senator Faulkner did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)

Bills read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bills in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: SYDNEY 2000 GAMES (INDICIA AND IMAGES) PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 February, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the amendment to the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Act 1996. The amendment to the principal act has two main purposes. Firstly, this bill seeks to enable the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee and licensed users to take action against all parties who may be involved in the supply of goods and services to which protected indicia and images have been applied by an unauthorised user.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, this bill will make it easier for the organisers of the Sydney 2000 Olympics and Paralympic Games and licensed users to take action against those persons who are engaged in ambush marketing. Ambush marketing is the unauthorised association of a business with the marketing of an event such as the Sydney Olympics. The ambush marketeer seeks to gain some benefit by suggesting an association with an event without paying for the marketing rights or the licensing fee.

The amendments contained in this bill will enable games organisers and the licensed users to take action against retailers, distributors or other parties in the supply chain rather than having to pursue through the supply chain the unauthorised person who applied the indicia or images to the goods or services.

Secondly, this bill will provide that action may be taken against those who aid, abet, counsel or procure breaches of the principal act. This will enable the Sydney organising committee and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee and licensed users to take action against persons whose involvement in the contravention of the legislation is in the nature of assisting the unauthorised application of indicia and images rather than in their direct application. These measures will help ensure the preservation of the games marketing revenues.

As well as protecting the revenue of the games against ambush marketing, they help ensure that the interests of legitimate retailers are protected from less scrupulous competition. Retailers, distributors and other parties will need to check to ensure that persons who applied the indicia or images to the goods or services are licensed. To do this, they need to check the register of licensed users located at the Sydney Olympics organising committee office in Sydney or the state offices of the Australian Industrial Property Organisation to ensure that the person is entered on the register. The Sydney organising committee proposes to provide easy access to the register of licensed users of the indicia and images and to provide a sophisticated identification system for genuine products.

The Sydney organising committee will also conduct a public awareness campaign and will be advertising in the various media. Retailers and other industry associations have agreed to cooperate with the Sydney organising committee in the dissemination of information so that the public is aware of and understands the legislation as it relates to the licensing of users of the protected indicia and images.

The provisions contained in this bill, together with those in the principal act, will cease to operate after 31 December 2000, following the completion of the games. The Olympic Games is going to be a substantial event in Australia's history and the benefits which will flow to Australia because of it will be outstanding.

I again indicate that we have absolutely no objections to the proposals contained in the amendment. I commend the government for taking the necessary action to protect those retailers and others who have paid considerable sums of money for the rights to produce material for the Olympics that contain the appropriate logos and images. They deserve the protection of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also be brief tonight as the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill 1996 is non-controversial legislation. I think all of us in this chamber agree that legitimate retailers, legitimate licensed businesses, should be protected in this way. We should be making sure that unauthorised use of logos, motives or images for gain is not allowed at whatever stage of the retailing system that illegal unauthorised use occurs. There should be the ability to prosecute; in other words, to give greater security to those people who are supporting the Olympic insignia for both the Sydney 2000 Games and also for the Paralympics.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go one step further and say: if only we could protect some of our unique national logos. Symbols of our native animals—for example, the koala—turn up on goods from Asia, giving the false impression that these are genuinely made in Australia. The kangaroo can be seen perhaps on Korean goods or those made in India, again giving the false impression that these goods are Australian made.

I commend the government for this move tonight. But I ask them to look again at the issue of Australian labelling so that we may protect our national symbols, our national logos, and give Australians greater confidence that when they see them they are buying Australian products.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Amendment Bill 1996 is an important part of what the Commonwealth government and the Commonwealth parliament have power to do to ensure that the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games are a success. The coalition when in opposition did take the initiative in this matter when it became clear, particularly to me as the shadow minister for sport at the time, that the previous government had not gone far enough to protect the games from ambush marketing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate, on my motion, referred this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for investigation. That committee took evidence from the New South Wales government—the then Liberal government as it was—SOCOG, a number of private enterprise organisations associated with the Olympics, and a number of other groups. To the credit of the Senate committee, it came down with a unanimous report urging legislation to effectively give the ownership of the name, symbols, indicia and images of the Olympics to SOCOG so that, if a corporation, business entity or even a private individual were to choose to become associated with the 2000 Games, then they would need to be licensed accordingly.

On the other side of the coin, if someone chose to associate themselves with the games, to make profit from that association and to do so without that licence and approval of SOCOG, the games organising committee, then they would be in breach of this legisla tion and could be pursued under this legislation.

The coalition as part of its election platform promised to introduce legislation to give proprietorial rights to the Sydney 2000 images and indicia when it came into government. Indeed, I remember being asked by SOCOG people at functions during the election campaign if we could write to the IOC ensuring that they were reassured that the coalition would proceed with this legislation. I am proud to say that this certainly made it into the core promise section of the coalition's election manifesto. As I recall, it was certainly one of the first five or six bills passed through this parliament.

I thank the opposition and Democrats who have made this non-controversial. I welcome the comments of Senator Carr, who I did not know had an interest in the Sydney 2000 Games. He is clearly a man with a wide range of interests. Anyone who reads this Hansard will see that Senator Carr has made a very constructive contribution to this very important debate.

I would also like to thank Senator Lees, who throughout the period of this legislation—the introduction of the principal bill and the development of this amending bill—has been supportive. It would not have been possible to legislate so effectively and so quickly without that sort of cooperation. I do thank Senator Lees and the Democrats for that.
Senator Brown did raise some concerns he had with an aspect of this legislation, but those concerns have been put to rest. I do thank all honourable senators for their contributions.

The amending legislation, as Senator Carr has quite accurately said, gives the games organising committee a far more effective instrument for tracking down people who would seek to ambush market in relation to the Sydney 2000 Games. It ensures that the games organising committee can go to anyone in the chain of supply of a good or service related to the 2000 Games. The original principal bill made it a little bit tortuous to find the correct culprit. This gives them broad powers to be able to go to a retailer selling a bogus Olympic t-shirt, for example, and to use the full powers of the act against that person and to then chase the culprits up the supply chain.

In these matters, as was very clearly demonstrated at the Atlanta Games I am informed, you need to be able to move quickly because people who are coming in to sell hats, t-shirts and all the other paraphernalia that go with major sporting events, can often import materials, set up a stall near one of the games' venues and start flogging off the material, to use a colloquialism. You do need very quick and flexible legislation and laws to be able to catch these culprits.

I am sure all Australian citizens wish the Sydney organising committee all the very best in the coming couple of years. It is crucial that those people who put up money, particularly from the private sector, by way of sponsorship have that sponsorship protected by this sort of legislation. This amending bill will ensure that the coalition's promise to deliver this protection is honoured in full. I conclude by again thanking all honourable senators for their contribution tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning in the other chamber my colleagues Michael Cobb, the member for Parkes, and Jackie Kelly, the member for Lindsay, moved and seconded a motion, under private members business, of profound significance to Australia's war history. The motion calls for a greater historical recognition of the importance of the Kokoda Track campaign in World War II, and pays tribute to and seeks recognition for the Koiari people known as the fuzzy wuzzy angels.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening I lend my support to that motion and the endeavours embodied in it. I do so because I, along with some of my political colleagues, joined a group just some four weeks ago to walk that historic Kokoda Trail. Anyone who saw the very high rating television show last year in regard to the celebrities who walked the Kokoda Trail will recall that very famous scene where Angry Anderson `lost it'—where that very tough guy Angry Anderson embraced his Australian guide and was unable to go on, so difficult was the trek.

I must say that in our endeavours to walk the track it was evident very early just how tough it was going to be. As the plane hovered over the Owen Stanley Range preparing to land—looking for a gap in the clouds so that it could land—at Kokoda, I started to have great empathy with Angry Anderson because those mountains, the Owen Stanley Range, looked merciless.

Everyone in the group—and it was a group of some 23—had a different reason for taking on the trek of a lifetime—and, indeed, it was the trek of a lifetime. Some members of the group had fathers who had fought in Papua New Guinea and were making the trek in their memory. By the end of the ordeal, they said that they understood and appreciated far greater their fathers' lives and what they had had to endure in World War II.

For the politicians, who usually get front row seats at Anzac Day ceremonies, this was a chance to get a better feel for the Anzac tradition by retracing the steps of our troops. From the very first day it was obvious that the land would live up to its very harsh reputation of unforgiving hills and drenching rains, and the trekker was given some idea of and insight into the conditions under which the soldiers had had to fight.
But really it was Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Honner, a commanding officer at the time, who best set the scene:

Worn out by strenuous fighting and exhausting movement, and weakened by lack of food and sleep and shelter, many of them had literally come to a standstill. Practically every day torrential rains fell all through the afternoon and night, cascading into their cheerless weapon-pits and soaking the clothes they wore—the only ones they had. In these they shivered through the long chill vigil of the lonely nights when they were required to stand awake and alert but still and silent.

The reward for the intrepid trekker, the modern day trekker, was to stop at these historic sites and be lectured on their significance—such sites as Isurava, which has been dubbed Australia's Alamo. It was here that the Australians made an epic stand against the full onslaught of the Japanese army. Although they were ungunned and outnumbered, they held up and inflicted massive casualties upon the Japanese army. It was here that Private Kingsbury was awarded Australia's first Victoria Cross to have been awarded on Australian territory.

The Australians were still in retreat when they made another stand which became known as the Brigade Hill battle where some 1,000 diggers faced a force of 6,000 Japanese. With great courage, the diggers were able to hold up the Japanese long enough to exhaust their supply lines. Eventually this tactic turned the campaign into an Australian victory.

But what we trekkers felt we had in common most with the World War II veterans as we retraced their steps was the bond that they personally forged with the local Papuans whom they nicknamed the fuzzy wuzzy angels because of the help they had given in a time of great need. At many of the villages where we camped, we were greeted by the original fuzzy wuzzy angels. It was a very moving experience to know that these quiet old men had at one time extended the hand of friendship and help to our embattled soldiers. The gratitude felt for the fuzzy wuzzy angels was beautifully put in a poem by Bert Beros:
Many a mother in Australia
When a busy day is done
Sends a prayer to the Almighty
For the keeping of her son,
Asking that an angel guide him
And bring him safely back—
Now we see those prayers are answered
On the Owen Stanley track.
For they haven't any haloes
Only holes slashed in the ears,
And with faces worked by tattoos,
With scratch pins in their hair.
Bringing back the wounded,
Just as steady as a hearse,
Using leaves to keep the rain off
And as gentle as a nurse.
Slow and careful in bad places
On the awful mountain trace
The look upon their faces
Makes us think that Christ was black . . .

Before it is too late and the last `angel' dies, we must recognise their efforts by at least striking a remembrance medal. The medal would be a great source of pride to the fuzzy wuzzy angels who are still alive—and, really, that is all they ask for.

After the 10‐day walk along the track we felt like giving the fuzzy wuzzies a medal because they truly deserved it for the number of times they helped us ragged and exhausted trekkers. Because of what happened on the Kokoda Track, every Australian should regard it as sacred ground. This story really does rival the legend of Gallipoli. We were then defending our own territory and, indeed, our country. We were in command, they were our tactics and we ultimately won. Against the odds, we won by nothing more than raw, awe‐inspiring courage, with the help of the fuzzy wuzzy angels. That is why it is sacred ground. That is why I support the motion moved in the House of Representatives today. It is a story waiting to become a legend for generations to come.

I believe that the motion moved by Michael Cobb and seconded by Jackie Kelly does have the private support of the minister, for he knows only too well what a spartan effort the Australian soldiers carried out in World War II. What is embodied in that motion, in particular, is the striking of a medal for those fuzzy wuzzy angels whom we met along the track and who are still alive today. As I said before, it was a most emotional occasion to meet these quiet men who we know at one stage had lent a hand to our soldiers.

I should add that Senator Jim Short's brother served on the Kokoda Track. I believe that Trish Worth's father served in Papua New Guinea and her uncle served on the track. It is surprising how many of that generation are still alive today. As I said, this legend rivals Gallipoli, and we won. It deserves to be put to the forefront of Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would like to add my condolences to the family and friends of Edna Ryan. In doing so, I also extend this to the Australian community, which has lost such a remarkable woman.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect that this woman has had on my life is tangible. She was one who opened many doors. I believe her life exemplifies the very real contribution she has made to all of our lives. The death of Edna Ryan has given many Australian women reason to contemplate feminism and what it means to be an activist on behalf of women in 1997. It certainly has provided a stark and timely reminder to me that the position that women currently hold in our society has not evolved naturally but has come about because people like Edna stuck their necks out.

Edna Ryan was a woman who demonstrated an enthusiasm, drive and commitment for women's rights and social justice principles that have left many of us reeling in her wake. She has been described as a visionary who remained a contemporary—a strange juxtaposition, but one that suits a woman who has inspired so many women, including me, and who has also remained one of the most informed and relevant contributors to feminism in the women's movement in Australian history.

Her commitment was born of life experience. It was not acquired through extensive formal qualifications but it was academia and influential Australians who turned to Edna for inspiration and advice. Recognition of this contribution came in the form of an honorary doctorate from Sydney University in 1983. Edna Ryan had a knack for being able to anticipate where the barriers to women's equality were going to emerge. This foresight enabled her to get in early to inspire others into supporting her campaigns.

As Australian women and men collect on 8 March 1997 to celebrate International Women's Day, we should do so remembering that it was a 24‐year‐old Edna Ryan who first joined the International Women's Day demonstration in Sydney's Domain in 1928. This rally was for equal pay, and it fuelled the fire in the belly of a woman who continued to demonstrate on behalf of all Australian women for almost all of her full and extraordinary 92 years. She was a feminist when feminism was not a mainstream movement. In 1997 she was a feminist when it is still not considered a part of mainstream Australian society. Or is it?

The relevance of feminism today is an issue explored by many recently. So, without being too philosophical or complicated, in Edna's memory, I would like to make a small contribution to the commentary on the issue. For me, when I was growing up I did not know that there was any difference between genders. As far as I was concerned, there were no barriers. That was how my parents raised me. I was employed in a non-traditional area for women at a comparatively young age and was paid equal pay and was expected to do equal work. No problem! I coped with varying degrees of success, like everybody else, and I did not see much in the gender equity thing at that time.

Imagine then the dawning realisation that I did not really get this job because of me but because there happened to be a union campaign to encourage more women into the building industry. Imagine the dawning realisation that I did not get paid the same because I did the same work but because so few women had ever worked in the industry that there had never been the need to insert a clause to differentiate rates of pay or, perhaps more poignantly, never the opportunity for inequitable wage parity to evolve. Imagine the dawning realisation that I was not valued as greatly as my male colleagues when I was made redundant before them, even though I had heaps more experience. Imagine finally realising, after all that happened, that there was substance in gender equity and that genuine equality for women, despite being a reality in my mind and the minds of many in my generation, was still something to be sought—and, in the current political environment, something to be defended.

I often wonder if the experience I have described is specific to my generation, which can be loosely described as our having distant echoing memories of I am woman being played by our parents, or if this is how it happens regardless of your life span or your experiences. Here's looking towards the day when dawning realisations are nothing but conspiracy theories. I do wish it were so. Edna Ryan knew it was not so. Many other Australian women and men know it is not so.

Edna Ryan, during periods of her life, could not vote, was not paid half of what her male counterparts were paid, was on a pittance as a single mother raising children, had limited educational opportunities and fought her way into local politics in the trade union movement, despite public perceptions of these professions being dominated purely by men.

Many years on, there is still gender inequity in Australian society and women of all ages are experiencing these dawning realisations, whether or not they think of themselves as feminists. In paying tribute to Edna Ryan, I want to say that, despite whatever label is attributed to any type of political activity designed to progress the status of women to a genuinely equitable position in our society, we need to recognise this contribution for what it has achieved and what it can achieve in the future.

I choose to call myself a feminist because this embraces the thoughts and feelings that I have. I hope to continue to convey these sentiments as they evolve because I know that the quest for equality is a dynamic pursuit.

I am proud to say that in this country we have had the privilege of knowing, despite her modesty, a woman that can only inspire people—in particular, young women—to become more politically aware and, hopefully, politically active. I feel proud that many women can use the channels of change that Edna helped dig and constantly clear throughout her life, including those involving the formal parliamentary process. The women's movement, led and encouraged by Edna, has demonstrated the impact that the movement can have on spreading these messages and building even more channels of change.

My feminism is as I interpret it. I have no illusions as to the massive challenges that existed when Edna Ryan sussed out her lot in life, as I have no illusion now as to the lot in life in which we find ourselves under this conservative government. I will continue to draw from the strength provided by women like Edna and hope that I am also inspired by the sight of the light at the end of the tunnel that inspired Edna to fight for equality.
I would like to close by reading the last words of Edna Ryan, which profoundly say so much about her. They were:
I would like to thank all the men and women, people in all walks of life who gave me help and information.
I found the formerly unknown circles of academia and the very much maligned bureaucracy and government institutions very responsive.
I consider myself lucky to have worked with excellent colleagues, particularly in Women's Electoral Lobby who put so much trust in me.
Don't mourn but rejoice as I've had a good innings as my mother would say. Not able to work, I prefer to leave.
Thank you all for brightening my life, especially my children and Margaret. I love you all very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite an honour to follow Senator Lundy's speech. It was great and I would like to think that many more people in this place would be willing to stand up and assert themselves as feminists in this chamber, especially on the conservative side of politics. Hear us roar.

SPEECH.PARA: It was also quite interesting to listen to Senator McGauran's speech but, unlike Senator McGauran, I will not be quoting poetry. What I do rise to speak about tonight is a book that I had the honour to launch two weeks ago with a colleague from the House of Representatives, Rod Sawford, the member for Port Adelaide. It is entitled Seen and Heard and nicknamed `A foolproof guide to the youth vote'. Undoubtedly, this has been targeted at politicians, both state and federal. It is a project undertaken by young Australians aged 15 to 26. It took over six months to compile a list of their responses to issues affecting them.

This book is a wonderful counter to some of the negative stereotypes we have recently seen perpetuated in the media, and in this place, of young Australians. It certainly is a book that celebrates the wit, diversity, humour, and talent and skills of young people, specifically in South Australia.

These young people were asked to pretend they were ministers and say what they would do if they were a minister, be it the minister for the environment, the minister for love or the minister for economics. They were also asked what they thought of politicians. Some of their responses as to how young people see politicians are worth noting. The words they used were: `get rich,' `mud slinging,' `have long holidays,' beef themselves up,' `mostly male,' `tell lies,' `make promises,' `get to the top and then get toppled,'`stress out,' `are boring,' `act like kids' and `their travel allowances are too high'.

I think no‐one in this chamber would deny the fact that young Australians, and perhaps Australians generally, view politicians with a degree of scepticism and perhaps disillusionment. That is something, of course, we all should be working to counter, along with families, teachers and parents. On that note, I do express my concern that civics education funding has been frozen under this government, albeit, I acknowledge, with a promise that a new program will start. Certainly, we will not start to redress the lack of electoral awareness in our community, and especially among young Australians, if we do not have such programs operating in schools.

The Seen and Heard project mostly used the visual medium of cartoons and some drawings. These were displayed in the Port Adelaide Community Youth Centre. They were over six feet high, beautifully and wonderfully coloured. I would like to think that perhaps that exhibition could be a travelling one and we could see it here in Parliament House at some stage.

I seek to leave to table this booklet because I think it says much more than I could about it. Of course, that is the idea of it. I imagine all politicians in this place will be receiving a copy from the Youth Affairs Council of South Australia.

I do ask politicians in both houses to acknowledge some of the comments that these young people have made in relation to participation. Some of the comments include: `young people are not acknowledged on a political level;' `many of us feel that we do not know enough about our choices when it comes to voting;' `a lot of us just tick any old box.' I appeal to many colleagues to read the document. I end my contribution this evening with a quote from a voice bubble in one of the cartoons in the book. Someone says:
`If I had the chance to be a politician, I wouldn't. I would go and play basketball.
I seek leave to table this booklet.
Leave granted.

Under Regulation 9 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, this licence is subject to the conditions and restrictions specified below.
John Anderson (Signature of Minister)
21/12/96 (Date of Signature)
DEFINITIONS
1. In this licence:—
"agricultural clearing" means clearing of native forest for the purpose of undertaking agricultural development excluding plantation establishment;

"Interim Forest Agreement" means the Interim Forest Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the State (executed by the State on 16 January 1996), as amended and notified in writing by the Commonwealth to the exporter from time to time;
"Interim Forest Area" means the area that may be required for a future comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system, as specified and referred to in the Interim Forest Agreement;

"Interim Forest Assessment" means the document entitled "Interim Forest Areas Tasmania Report of the Interim Forest Assessment Process December 1995", a copy of which has been provided to the exporter;
"Department" means the Department which is responsible for advising the Minister in respect of administration of the Export Control Act 1982;
"exporter" means the General Manager (Commercial) Forestry Tasmania, the office of which is located at 199 Macquarie Street, Hobart, Tasmania, or any person authorised to act on his behalf;
"hardwood" means wood derived from trees of native Australian species that are botanically hardwoods;
"Minister" means the Minister responsible for administration of the Export Control Act 1982;
"old growth forest" means a forest that is ecologically mature and has been subjected to negligible unnatural disturbance such as logging, roading or clearing;

"Regional Forest Agreement" means a Regional Forest Agreement within the meaning of the Regulations covering the region to which this licence relates, which has been entered into between the Commonwealth and the State;
"residue wood" means hardwood derived from sawmill residues or silvicultural thinnings;
"sawlog-driven harvesting" means timber harvesting operations for which the primary purpose is the production of sawlogs or the maximisation of the sawlog production potential of a forest;

"sawlogs" means logs graded as sawlogs, or where logs are not subject to a grading process means logs that are suitable for economic use for sawing, veneers, poles, girders and other products of higher value than pulpwood and wood chips;

"sawmill residues" means waste material resulting from: (a) the production of squared timber in sawmill operations; or (b) rejection by a veneer mill, sawmill or other processing plant (other than a wood chipping plant) of a log found to be defective for the purposes of producing a commercial timber product, where the defect could not have been found on any reasonable inspection of the log before its arrival at the plant for processing;
"silvicultural thinnings" means waste material resulting from the thinning of a regrowth forest for the purpose of improving the production potential of the forest;
"Tasmania Region" means the Tasmania Region as defined in the Regulations;
"State" means the State of Tasmania;
"tonnes" means green metric tonnes; and
"wood" means fibrous materials between the bark and pith of a tree or shrub.
QUANTITY
2. The quantity of material exported under this licence shall not exceed 40,000 green tonnes of hardwood billets.
SOURCE MATERIAL
3. The exporter shall not export under this licence hardwood billets unless those billets are produced from wood harvested from the Tasmania Region.

4. The exporter shall take all reasonable steps to ensure it does not export under this licence hardwood billets produced from wood harvested in an area (including an area on the Register or on the Interim list of the Register of the National Estate) which is at the time the wood was harvested:
(a) in an Interim Forest Area (except for any areas in relation to which the Commonwealth has approved completion of timber harvesting pursuant to clause 6 of the Interim Forest Agreement); or
(b) in an area not available for timber harvesting under a Regional Forest Agreement.

5. The exporter shall take all reasonable steps to ensure it does not export under this licence hardwood billets produced from wood harvested in old growth forest, unless produced from sawlog-driven harvesting operations.

6. The exporter shall not export under this licence hardwood billets produced from wood harvested from agricultural clearing unless it has taken all reasonable steps to ensure that such wood is harvested in accordance with State and Local government laws relating to agricultural clearing.
7. The exporter shall take all reasonable steps to ensure it does not export under this licence hardwood billets produced from sawlogs, other than as sawmill residues.
8. (a) The exporter shall not export under this licence hardwood billets derived from residue wood from areas of rainforest on Crown Land.

(b) In this condition `rainforest' has the same meaning as the term has, for the purpose of the 1996 harvesting operations, if item 6 or 7, which ever is applicable, in Schedule 1 to the Interim Forest Agreement.
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION AND ENDANGERED SPECIES

9. The exporter shall take all reasonable steps to ensure it does not export under this licence hardwood billets produced in operations not conducted in accordance with the requirements of the Interim Forest Assessment and Interim Forest Agreement or Regional Forest Agreement in effect at the time the operations are conducted.

10. The exporter shall ensure all of its operations for the production of hardwood billets for export under this licence do not threaten with extinction, or significantly impede the recovery of, a species listed in Schedule 1 or an ecological community listed in Schedule 2 of the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, and that the operations comply with any measures in the Interim Forest Assessment and Interim Forest Agreement or Regional Forest Agreement in effect at the time the operations are conducted, concerning such species.
COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS, ETC
11. The exporter shall:
(a) comply with all Commonwealth, State and local government laws; and

(b) take all reasonable steps to ensure that all operations for the production of hardwood billets for export under this licence comply with the relevant codes of forest practice and management plans.
INSPECTION

12. The exporter shall take all steps within its power to facilitate the inspection by officers of the Department, and of the Government of Tasmania of any area where the exporter is carrying out operations connected with the export of hardwood billets under this licence.
REPORTING
13. The exporter shall provide the Department with a report, by 31 March 1998, in relation to compliance with the conditions and restrictions of this licence.

NOTE: Failure to comply with the conditions or restrictions in an export licence is an offence under the Export Control Act 1982. Under the Regulations the Minister may also suspend or revoke the licence in certain circumstances.
END OF LICENCE
